This stout does not overwhelm your palate and quite refreshing and enjoyable. Would be more interesting if they cranked
the ABV up a little.....but still very nice chocolate stout from Rogue, cannot wait to try their double chocolate stout.

Sample. Poured a near black with a thin film for a head. Aroma mild raosted malts and... chocolate. Taste: lots and losts of milf chcocolate (think milk shake), mild roasted malts. Body was a little thin to me. Finish was sweet milk chocolate, with just a mild bitterness. Not really my thing.

Bottle...It pours pitch black with a large very creamy tan head.....the flavor is very pleasant chocolate, milk chocolate.... the flavor is milk chocolate, light coffee and roasted malts..... I sense some cigar flavor in the finish.... very nice.... :)

Arrived with a one finger dark tan head. Clear dark brown.

Smells of cocoa and maybe a touch of roasted malt. The cocoa really dominates.

The taste is also dominated by chocolate. There is a slight roastiness detectable but it is upstaged by the cocoa. A moderate bitterness comes in at the end. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and slightly sticky.

This is one of the better chocolate stouts I have had. I would definitely get it again.

Serving type: on-tap
Bitter chocolate. This is a pretty heavy stout, but just perfect if youre in the right mood.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2014 Draft- Nice chocolate color, with a frothy tan head. Smells of chocolates and roasty malts. Taste is pretty big, slight burned rostiness at the beginning evolving into a sweet chocolate coffee finish. Excellent beer......

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 Draught. Pours an opaque black with a tan head. Smells strongly of chocolatey goodness. Tastes of semisweet chocolate and maybe some toffee. The chocolate flavor seems to disappear over time, leaving only the bitterness. Medium body. Texture is creamy. Finishes dry.

Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, vanilla and heavy chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. This is chocolate all the way. 221111
Bottle. Almost black with small brown head. Aroma is roasted malts and strong dark chocolate. Flavour is roasted malts, strong chocolate, medium sweet,, little coffee and a little bitter.

Looks like chocolate, smells like chocolate and tastes like chocolate.  I think willy Wonka made this, hahahaha.  Seriously, its a good chocolate stout and I find it to be a good balanace of dark bitter chocolate and milk chocolate.  this beer would make an awesome stout float!

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2011 Smells amazing, like a really chocolaty coffee. Pours very dark and has a nice thick mouthfeel. The only real problem I had, was that I started having trouble drinking it after about 10 ounces. It started to get way too sweet for my taste, but before that point it was fantastic. I liked Youngs Double Chocolate a bit more.

Aroma is dominated by milk chocolate. Pours black with a tan foam. Flavor is heavy on the chocolate. Nice body as the chocolate sticks with you in the aftertaste. Excellent beer. A dessert in a bottle.

From the sound it made when I poured this beer into my glass, I knew it would be thick and creamy.

The head dissipates disappointingly quickly, but while it lingers, notice the rich red tinge.

The aroma is like smores made with marshmallows that have been allowed to catch fire, just for a moment.

Deep, dark chocolate and toasty grain flavour and even a little rum & raisin on second tasting.

Aroma of milk chocolate. Pours a thick chocolate black. Minimal head, but a nice brown color. Smooth beer start to finish, light bitterness on the back end. More of a roasty cocoa flavor than chocolate. All around another good beer from Rogue.
The smell of this reminds me of a good strong American ale.  I liked the taste and strong hints of chocolate.
Black with a thin mocha head, big chocolate nose, bitter dark chocolate and roasted malt taste. Thin and fizzy, with a light bitter finish. Nice desert beer. LF (Lagerboy Friendly)

Bottle @ Ølkonsortiet chrismas beer tasting. 2005 vintage, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of mild coffee, dark and milk chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, light coffee notes, loads of chocolate, quite sweet. Medium body, soft carbaonation. 051111

Aroma is sweet chocolate and coffee. Appearance is black with medium brown head. Poured like it was a thick beer. Taste is intense dark chocolate and coffee. Hazelnut and also a bit of cream. Sweet but with enough roast and hop bitterness to remain very balanced. You could easily confuse this with a iced mocha. Palate is full-. Dark chocolate lingers nicely. Overall an impressive beer. Heavy chocolate flavors with great sweetness, but still remaining dark and roasty.
Very good aroma of Chocolate and Coffee. Too much carbonated, finish too bitter.  Strange beer

Bomber.  Deep brown black, tall tan foamy head.  Powerful chocolate aroma,  overall very good with exception that this is a little watery for a stout.  Had everything going for it... I will try again, see if another batch is a little more complete.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2011 On Tap. Pours kinda black with a thin brown head. Aroma is huge sweet milky chocolate which seemed kinda perfumed in a way. Some dark caramel malts and maybe some cocoa. A bit one dimensional on the nose. Taste is the same but add a bit more roastyness along with some weak notes of hops and cocoa. Body is a bit on the watery side for a chocolate stout.
[Bottle at the Bootlegger, High Wycombe] Black with a large beige head. Dominated by fake chocolate, which ruins what appears to be a rather nice roasty stout beneath it.  Shame.

Pours black with a nice tan head. Aroma of chocolate, cocoa, brown sugar, molasses. Taste is roasted malt, cocoa, a sweetness that works into semi bitter chocolate that is very nice. Nicely balance with a semi dry finish. Nice stout.
On tap at WOB.  Midnight pour with a kaki head.  HUGE chocolate nose.  Dark roasted malts, bakers chocolate, and coffee flavors..

Bottle in Craft Beer Co. Pours black and thin with a small brown head. Nose is intense chocolate and cocoa. Milk and dark chocolate. Lovely. Taste is chocolate, touch of bitterness. Mouthful is light. Palate is not complex but like the simplicity of this. I wanted chocolate and thats what this delivers.

Nose is cocoa and chocolate with some lingering hops. Roasty as well. Poured nice and typically dark with a tan head. Taste was surprisingly bitter with hops to begin with. Followed by loads of chocolate and cocoa. An overall great chocolate stout.
(Brasserie 4:20)what a good stout...dark,clody...incredible chocolate aroma,massive and persistant...and the taste is similar,qith little hops notes..good body,very good balance..excellent finsh..

I remember the days when craft beer was a mystery to me and drinking a good beer was not a stress or a losing race between buddies to show the world you are the best bad-ass killer craziest ego maniac with billions of tasting skills and ten thousand ratings. at THAT TIME the rougue chocolat stout was my #1 ISO but We are beyond that now...
Bottle @ Bir&Fud bottega Roma. Black solid color, surprising almost brown good looking Head; a little bit frothy. Cool milk chocolate/cocoa aroma, very intense, that overpowers some cereal, herbs components. The taste is cocoa/milk chocolate mostly; some licorice on the background. Really smooth mouthfeel, a little bit watery. medium/low carbonation. The light body doesnt support the intense aroma and taste but it isnt a big issue; the beer is a lot enjoyable anyway. sadly The finish is really short. Im really surprised about this beer but i think the total score result has been too way generous this time. To summarize:  even if i had a lot of chocolate beers (ok, i love chocolate) better than this, the Rogue CS is definitely a must try

A: Dark brown-black.. thick white head that slowly fades.. decent lacing...

S: Lots of chocolate.. sweet and bitter.. some caramel and vanilla.

T: Mostly dark bitter chocolate... not much in the way of the softer milk chocolate, caramel and vanilla i got in the aroma...

M: On the lighter end of the the full body spectrum... smooth. creamy.

D: Not too shabby... id certaintly have one or two in a night if its on tap.

Huge pour from bomber into Maudite glass. Blackish with 2" head. Intricate lacing, not dictated by sips. Aroma is more like milk chocolate or powdered hot chocolate, vs. the typical bitter dark chocolate you get with these stouts. Flavor is more like dark chocolate milk. Pleasant mouthfeel. Good chalkiness from the hops. Stays balanced with bitter even though its sweet. Just a good stout. Looking forward to pairing with brownies and vanilla ice cream.

From notes: Pours opaque black, with a thick, creamy dark tan/mocha- colored head.  Aroma is cocoa/chocolate.  Deep, medium-thick with a slight oilyness.  Chocolate taste that lingers nicely on the tongue with some bitterness from the chocolate.  A mild grainy note appears as it warms.

Black as oil with brown head.  Aroma domintated by roasted malt.  Taste - roasted malt and chocolate.  Lots of chocolate but this isnt overly sweet.  Also notes of espresso, hazelnuts and vanilla.  Bitter finish.  Full body.  This is very good.
pitch dark, small smooth light brown head3 strong chocolate roma, some toffee and caramel too.7 flavor is chocolate , toffee, caramel. Guld karameller, roasted malts, 7

Pours a nice deep black with a thin brown head that disappeared very quickly. Aroma consists of roasted nuts and espresso. The chocolate has a very nice presence - very bitter and dark. The bitterness is almost too much though, especially in combination with the hops and bite of the alcohol. Though still a well-crafted and tasty beer, not my favorite stout.

65 cl bottle @ ISKTR. Rated on 20.03.2011
Aroma has vanilla and sweet chocolate. Flavour has sweet, artificial-like chocolate from an easter egg. Too much CO2 on palate. Nice stuff with lots of chocolate, but the artificial aromas disturb here a bit.
Date: September 24, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Minneapolis Beer Fest.  Full description not available as I sampled way too many beers in 4.5 hours!

From tap. Poured a dark brown with a lighter head. Lots of chocolate on the nose, over some malts. But mostly chocolate. Same with the flavor. Sweet and no more bitter than youd expect from milk chocolate.

22oz bottle picked up in Evanston 
Appearance: Pours black with a medium sized tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, rich milk chocolate and roasted coffee 
Taste: Roasted malts, grainy, ashy, roasted coffee and milk chocolate 
Very nice and smooth.

Draught @Kaisla, Helsinki 14.9.2011. Poured black color with a brown head, lookin delicious. Strong milk chocolate aroma, with some roasted malt as well. Flavor is chocolate, hoppy notes, roasted malt. Quite sweet, but in this case it fits perfectly. Dry, long chocolaty finish.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Tap @ Beer Temple, Amsterdam 11/09/11. Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a large, pillowy, latte head. Aroma is chocolate, milk chocolate, mocha, tones of vanilla. Taste is mocha, chocolate, milk chocolate, slight floral hoppiness. Palate is light.

(Draught at Kaisla, 20110912) The beer poured black. Its head was small and light brown. Aroma had chocolate, roasted malts and hops. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were bitter dark chocolate, roasted malts, hops, ash, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste had dark chocolate and bitterness. Despite the strong chocolate aroma and flavour this beer was well balanced and tasted nice.

Pours dark brown with a generous brown head.  Chocolate and malt in the aroma.  Taste starts sweet and finishes with a little hop bitterness, with chocolate present throughout.  Creamy texture throughout.  Really good.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2011 Refrigerated 16.9 oz. bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours black as my soul with two inch medium creamy brown head.  Velvet smooth texture, good lacing, and thick body.  Taste is burnt malt, some chocolate, and finishes dry with some hops.  Pretty good.

66cl bottle from "A Tutta Birra". Served into a snifter. Pours a black colour with a huge dark brown head that leaves a very nice lacing on the glass walls. Aroma of dark chocolate, milk chocolate, vanilla, coffe beans and some alchool. Medium body, creamy texture. has a very nice drinkability, with a dry and very bitter finish, Nice!

poured from a 22oz from PCC in redmond, wa. poured a thick dark chocolate. head was a creamy, very brown colored. interesting it settled like a guiness with a flat line up. deep caramel flavors and tastes like a chocolate bar liquified. strong aroma of chocolate and sweet after tastes

22oz bottle.  Thick pour is completely opaque with short-lived bubbly tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, cocoa, bittersweet chocolate, and chocolate cake.  Chocolate.  To best describe the taste: imagine melting a Hersheys bar and drinking it.  Theres a slight dryness on the finish with a slight bitterness.  Sticky in the mouth but not as thick as the pour would have you believe.  I have generally been disappointed with much of Rogues offerings, but this is delicious.
Torr, syrlig och tydlig chokladsmak.

Bottle ---> Snifter. Black and smooth was the pour, with a huge promising head. The nose is full of chocolate, a little bit of coffee and even a hint of raisins. Flavors are a tad lighter, high carbonation gives to a dark chocolate character, with a little bit of coffee floating around to give a dry aftertaste. Finished nice and bitter-sweet, nicely balanced.
Nose is chocolate, roasted malt, milk, alcohol, feel is bottomheavy with a thin top, carb is mediumweak, taste is fat dark chocolate, mint, alcohol, mellow bitter hops finish.

Pours black with a dark brown, creamy head. Great look to this one. Aroma is full of chocolate, both milk and dark chocolates. The flavor has nice malts, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, and some coffee. Nice aftertaste of chocolate-covered espresso beans. Nice beer.

650ml bottle 
6.3% ABV 
I tried this beer on August 5, 2011 at "The Beerbistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a brownish black with a generous creamy brown head.  The aroma was dark chocolate, roasted malt, and molasses.  The mouthfeel is creamy and full bodied with mild carbonation.  The flavour is dark chocolate, with hints of vanilla and toffee.

A completely black beer with a thick brown head.  The aroma is heavy on chocolate with a bit of coffee.  The flavor has oatmeal and coffee notes, as well as the bitter cocoa taste in the finish.  Very nice.
A great chocolate stout, sweet, smoth and velvet. Lots of chocolate and it age pretty well, gonna save a bottle a many years just to see how it will continue aging.

Not big on stouts, but enjoy them ocassionally.A typical good stout, very good milk chocolate aroma,smooth mouthfeel chocolate and coffee roast taste balanced by a good amout of hop bittering that lingers with the dry roast, the aroma is the best feature for me its the best stout chocolate aroma  i have tried.Coffee like bitterness lingers. Kind of thin in the finish.Not my favorite stout but definatlely one of the better ones,glad i tried it wont get it anytime too soon.

Bottle from Beers of Europe.  At £7 something per bottle wont be buying too many of these but had to try it out.....
A fair bit of body with this stout, frothy tan head with excellent lacing on the pint glass.  Smells of bittersweet chocolate, bitter coffe, pepper, roasty walnuts evident.
I get alot of the walnut taste with this, a little chocolate, very earthy and its getting more earthy / roasty as this pint glass ends.
Aftertaste is fairly bitter and nutty.  I expected this a bit sweeter but a fine beer to relax with and watch a movie.
At 650ml per bottle, when you have finished your pint you have a few more litres to look forward to!!
Very pleasent.
Bottle from  Beers of Europe. Black colour, tan head. Nose is quite sweet, with milk chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, bit of vanilla. Dry, roasty finish.
Aroma and taste is chocolate. Shit loads of chocolate. However a bit to thin texture.
Pours dark brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate.  Taste of creamy milk chocolate with smooth creamy finish.  Thin mouthfeel. Tons of chocolate.

Bottle @ home. Deep brown brown appearance with a dark brown head. Huge bittersweet chocolate, dark chocolate malty nose. Creamy, cocoa, slightly milky, chocolate malty flavor. Huge chocolatey taste. Pretty awesome brew.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2014 drank at mondial 2011 in mtl. pours pitch black with a dark beige head, good retention and lacing. intense roasted malts - not quite ashy though, vanilla, cocoa beans, hint of molasses - some sweetness. moderate carboantion, light to medium body - oily and a tad sticky, spicy-resinous finish.

pours nice and dark with a big tan head, decent lacing in my glass, aroma is mostly chocolate and roasty, taste is nice chocolate and slight coffe with a slight bitter end, body is a bit thinner than i would like, but its still a really good beer, would love to try the double chocolate stout, i bet its much better.

My friends kept telling me to try this but I couldnt find it anywhere. So I leapt in joy when I saw this in a small liquor store in Cape May, despite the extortionate price. Perhaps the expectation got to me. I mean it wasnt bad. Big coffee, chocolate and oat notes, with a decent bitter finish. But it tasted blander than most stouts, was too strong, and goddammit not chcolately enough. Get Youngs Double Chocolate Stout instead.
Chewy full chocolaty aroma. Some dark roast coffee. Pours opaque black smallish tan head. Long deep milk chocolate finish. Hop bitterness tempers the residual sweetness.

Pour dark brown tan brown head good lace visible yeast floties in bottom of glass. Aroma cocoa, bakers chocolate, coffee, roasty and rich. Taste bitter, cocoa, bakers chocolate, vanilla, roasty, coffee, hop bitterness. MF medium rich body with mild fine carb. Overall very good not the super sweet chocolate like a dessert but rather a dark rich and bold flavor very well done.
Bottle. From notes. Black with a creamy light brown head. Chocolate, toffee, cream, some coffee. Medium-bodied and smooth. Will get this again if I see it.
Hopefully I have a bad bottle, smell and tastes like rotten froot loops and ash. Just gets worse and worse.

Great googly moogly, this beer smells like a warehouse full of Hershey Bars.  Chocolate on top of chocolate on top of Pacman yeast fits as the nose and the flavor, both having the bitter nip of pure cocoa coupled with a sweet, milk chocolate base.  The finish is lingering and dry, but provides proper balance with the initial fudge shop deluge.  Tasty, but gets a bit daunting during the second pint.  (1/09)

Appearance: Very dark brown. Lots of creamy, tan head.
Aroma: Lots of chocolate. Roasted.
Taste: Burnt, dark malt, coffee and of course chocolate. Nice.
Info: 650ml bottle, 21/5-2011
Simply amazing.  Just the right amount of chocolate and hops.  This is the chocolate mole of beers.

This is a good beer. Aroma is a bit one note. Chocolate. Appearance is what youd expect from any good stout. Black, nice head. Taste is first and foremost chocolate but the good coco kind not the sugary syrup kind. Nice think mouth almost creamy. Overall very nice but a bit one note. (I know its a chocolate stout)

A: Black with a sightly-browned creamy head.

S: Lots of chocolate going on and definitely some milk characteristics as well.

T: Lots of chocolate flavor, and nothing artificial--this tastes like real chocolate. The flavor isnt overly sweet, and has a nice balance.

M: Fairly-full bodied and somewhat dry. Quite nice.

D: Good toward the beginning, although a full bomber is definitely a little too much given the character of this beer. Definitely suggest splitting this one amongst two or three others!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-01-2009
Bottle. Pours tar black. Thick beige head. Nose and taste of melted chocolate, charred oats, chocolate malts, vanilla and nuts. Thick for a sweet stout with only about 6% ABV.

Big bottle; poured a black as night color with a generous frothy head that stayed well.  Aroma of chocolate, malts, vanilla, nuts, coffee.   Most of all chocolate in my opinion.  Taste was lite sweetness with a touch of bitterness.  Tasting milk chocolate.  Medium body, creamy texture.  Soft carbonation.  Had this before- liked it before and liked again now.  Smooth tasting stout.    Great use of chocolate.
on tap powers jet black.  Smell is of dark chocolate.  The taste is kinda a let down the smell is so great and yet the taste isnt as chocolaty as it smell.  Its a good beer.
Bottle. Color almost black with small brown head. Aroma milk chocolate. Taste milk chocolate and some bitter chocolate.

Deep brown body with thick chocolate root beer float head. Medium-roasty chocolate malt aroma with milk chocolate nuances. Easy chocolate flavor with solid malty backbone and a touch of melanoidin. Dusted chocolate finish.

Pours an opaque black color. There is a great, one finger, mocha colored head that has great retention. I was a little surprised it didnt leave as much lacing, but overall a great looking brew.

Smells of burnt malts with a hint of coffee but it is pretty strong.

Upfront in the taste there is bitter chocolate with a hint of coffee, this gives way to a creamier chocolate taste. After this, there is a slight hop taste a s a bitter chocolate taste, much like the initial tastes finishes it up.

Good thick mouthfeel for a stout, maybe a wee bit too much carbonation but this works great.

Appearance is nearly black with a nice medium brown head. Aroma is rich chocolate malts. Taste is a nice blend of chocolate malts and bitter hops. Overall a pretty good stout, but not the best I have had.

I poured this 22 oz. bottle into an imperial pint glass. The beer pours a deep, black nectar that leaves a milk chocolate head hanging off the rim of the glass. The aroma is nothing but choclolate, chocolate, chocolate! After the first sip, there is rich, chocolate lacing on the inside of the glass. After another sip, I can taste the rich imported chocolate, and then the roasted malts come in. The beer tends to finish a little sweeter than the initial sip. I recommend this brew as a great desert beer, or a great change of pace beer for the long term drinker. Cheers!

Aroma consist of chocolate, nuts, and roasted coffee. Black in color with a frothy, caramel head. Very spotty lacing(almost constallation). The flavor starts off with a bitter chocolate taste and ends with an abrupt coffee flavor. Has more of a thin texture which being a stout i was expecting a more creamy texture. I like rogue brewery and again i was not dissappointed.

The beer is black with a light to medium tan head rising about 2 fingers and falling to quickly. There is great lacing.

The aroma is awesome with tons of light better chocolate on the front, its like smelling a chocolate cake. At the end before being overwhelmed with just sweetness you get a nice bitter hoppiness. 

The taste is all chocolate. There front is sweet chocolate but then it fades it bitter chocolate all the way. The taste is too much bitter chocolate and one note for me to be great. Its a nice change of pace.

MMMM, here is a good stout- a mildly-sweet sweet stout with oats, roasted barley, and chocolate!  Dark with thin vanishing head that will reappear with aggravation.  Aroma is of chocolate and roast. Flavor is rounded chocolate, slight grain cookie, moderate hop bitterness in the finish, pine, slight burnt, slight sweet.  Yum!

Aroma: Very chocolatey, sweet - cheap chocolate.
Mouthfeel: hard, medium-bodied, watery at finish.
Taste: Not a porter for sure... Aftertaste is non-existent.
Overall: This is a joke from a good brewery. Nothing here to enjoy at all.

650 ml bottle @ ISKTR.
Pours a dark reddish brown, almost black colour. Aroma of chocolate which reminds me of Easter. Flavour of roasted malts, some hops, chocolate and mild mocca. Medium bodied with a thin mouthfeel and a slightly dry finish. Good.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2011 Bottle @ ISKTR

Pours black with a foamy beige head. Aroma has hints of milk chocolate and vanilla. Taste is a bit roasted with hints of chocolate and cocoa. Body is a bit light and finish is a bit dry. Not very sweet. 8-4-7-3-14 3.6

Re-rated on 9.9.2011. Draught @ Kaisla, Helsinki

Pours pitch black with a medium sticky and foamy beige head. Strong aroma has notes of cocoa, chocolate, coffee beans and roasted malts. Taste is quite sweet and smooth with strong notes of milk chocolate, coffee and slightly roasted malts. Smooth, sweet finish. Well balanced, enjoyable sweet stout.

Bomber. Like drinking a liquid chocolate bar. One of the most chocolate tasting chocolate stouts I have come across yet. Im actually surprised that I like this one so much since I usually dont go for the ones with the overly chocolate or vanilla flavors as they can come across as artificial or covering the real taste of the beer. This one though, they somehow get it right. The added chocolate flavor blends in perfectly and manages to compliment instead of mask. Cant wait to try the double version!
Ir pours a dark tan/black. It is very chocolatey, more so than many other so called chocolate stouts.

Poured from bomber, pours black with a nice tan head and lacing through out the glass, aroma of hershey chocolate, vanilla and a hint of cofee, the flavor is of chocolate with a nice bitterness in the finish, mmmmm, delicious.

Pours exactly what you would expect from a choclate stout. Dark brown color off white creamy head.  vanilla, caramel, choclate, and mild coffee scents. Perfect taste of all just listed. Kinda regret only having one.

This beer will always have a spot in the cellar - may not be as complex or as good as other beers but it was on the first that got me into craft beer - so thank you rogue. Bomber - pours a dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of hershey milk chocolate which is a little too sweet for my liking. Like the bitterness in the taste but thin bodied and a little too thin.

22oz bottle split.  Chalky blackened brown with a thin, oily beige head.  Big chocolate syrup/milk, cocoa aroma.  A top notch chocolate Stout.  Intense chocolate taste, balanced by a solid background bitterness.  Quite well done.  Mellow, not overly sugary and thick, but still refined and enjoyable.  Well done.

Beers of Europe. Truly massive chocolate aroma, with hints of tobacco smoke and vanilla., all combining well in the taste. Bitter cocoa to the fore, dry lasting finish, with roast malt coming in more and more towards the end.

Pretty close to black with a puffy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, oats, and a little nutty. The taste is mostly thin chocolate and maltiness with some hops standing out at the end. Its thinner than I expected, and the chocolate isnt as rich as Id hoped. Carbonation is pretty high, and finish is a little bitter. This is quite good, but I was expecting something fuller and smoother. A little disappointing actually...

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2012 Pours a dark brown with a big tan, creamy head. Aromas of cocoa, caramel, and a hint of coffee. Flavour is immense. The warmer it gets, the more the chocolate seems to fill the flavour of the beer. Huge, thick chocolate makes the palate perfect. Best chocolate stout Ive had so far

Another nice looking stout.  Pours very black, very thin head, not too much carbonation.  Aroma is sweet with a hint of cocoa and maybe a bit of caramel.  The flavor is fairly one dimensional to me.  Not very complex.  Just a hint of burnt maltiness.  I was expecting something more exciting.

Dark brown, tan creamy head. Strong sweet, caramelly chocolate aroma that lasts.
Flavour is sweet, hops in the end. A great sweet stout, probably the best I had since I use to drink beer.
This is s special beer from rogue. I didnt know the chocolate and beer would go so well with each other, but it is a perfect balance. Pretty much a chocolate bar in a bottle. Very tasty.
Draft at double windsor brooklyn. Deep black color. Minimal head and lace. Smells of chocolate, maple and nuts. Taste is the same with some coffee. Bvery drinkable and flavorful sweet stout from them

Bottle from Beer Ritz. Jet black pour with a creamy tan head. Chocolate milk, caramel, toffee and some coffee aromas. Full on chocolate attack in the flavour with notes of caramel and butterscotch. Nice, bitter edge. Very dry and smooth.

Pours a solid black with a creamy tan head.  lacing is still on the glass from last night. Smells of malt and chocolate (very strong chocolate).  very strong chocolate flavors with some malts and grains too.  It gets better the warmer it gets and the subtle nuances really start to show.  One of their better beers in my opinion.

This stout has a muscular and joyous Nestle Quik connotation in the aroma. Quite strong and pleasing. The head mimmicks that of freshly poured chocolate milk and the brew is so dark chocolately brown that its black. The taste, of course is chocolate, but it is such a strong, sugary chocolate that it forgot to be a stout. The brew is too focused on being chocolate. The palate is twisted between chalkyness and strong carbonization, leaving a film on the tongue. A novelty brew at best.

Poured a dark black with no translucent edges to be seen. Dark mahogany head that was about half finger and foamy; did not retain well. Smell was pure malt chocolate, with roasted cookies and raw cocoa in there. Taste was better still, with dark chocolate followed by a milky cocoa, which was then balanced by a nice happy middle that kept the beer from becoming alcoholic nesquik. Mouthfeel was thick and smooth, although a bit thinner than the other stouts Ive reviewed recently. Drinkability was phenomenal, as the abv somehow yielded so much taste that I dont know how they did it. Really awesome, affordable beer.

50cl bottle shared with friends.
Ive never met a Rogue beer I didnt like, this is a yummy stout :-)

It has an amazing creamy aroma with heaps and heaps of chocolate and some menthol hopiness.  In the mouth it is round and creamy with some delicious, dry smokiness and bitter chocolate.  The bitterness actually builds quite intensely. Very tasty though that menthol thing is sort of annoying.
Bottle at Pies & Pints. Black pour with a huge tan head. Aroma of chocolate syrup, creaminess and roasted malt. Milk chocolate flavor with bitter dark chocolate and a rich, bitter coffee finish.

Bomber from Sonoma Cellars.  Pours an inviting opaque black with a rich brown head (why do some opaque blacks look forbidding and some look inviting ....). Aroma is all cocoa powder.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate, a hint of fruit and some roasted maltiness.  Finishes a bit thick with more chocolate and some bitterness.  Bottle had a bunch of stuff on the bottom -- not expected in a stout, to me.  Nice richness, nice chocolate.

22oz bottle - split with my wife. 
Dark black color with a small amount of light brown head.  Smells and tastes like a chocolate bar, small amount of roasted malt.  A bit more of a hop bite than the usual chocolate stout which Im digging.  Is there a style Pacman yeast doesnt work with?

dark Brown almost black with mocha head. A: Chocolaty, almost like the smell of hot chocolate powder, caramel. F: Body is full finish is sweet with a nice bitter bite right at the end. O: A fun beer to drink well made a nice intro into the micro-brewery world.

Black appearance with a large light-brown to tan head with various sized bubbles. It seems to retain pretty well and leaves dense lacing. Strong chocolate bar and syrup on the nose, with oats, hot coca, and citrusy hops. The flavor is roasted malt upfront, with chocolate and hops catching up on the finish. Somewhat bitter finish seems to come from the malt and the hops. Pretty smooth on the palate, thick but light, with moderate carbonation.

nice, opaque dark brown with a light caramel coloured head. Roasted malt with a light hint of dark chocolate. Smokey flavour, if you can imagine mesquite smoked chocolate and malt, there you go. Very  very nice

22 oz bomber: Pours a deep black with a tan head. Slight coffee and roasted barley notes with apparent dark/bitter sweet chocolate notes coming through. Medium to full body with a slick mouth feel and slightly dry finish. Great balance with the chocolate, not too sweet or overpowering. A very enjoyable, well balanced chocolate stout. Overall (B+)

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2011 Poured into a 12oz. Rogue glass. Aroma is pure chocolate, I really cant detect anything else. Color is jet black, with a thick creamy head. Flavor starts off coffee like, then really transitions into a dark chocolate flavor. I am detecting some hops, and drinking it has helped detect the aroma of hops. Excellent balance of chocolate and hops. Also bitter at first, with a long sweet finish. This is a full bodied beer with a soft carbonation. Overall an amazing beer!! I will be enjoying more of this brew and highly recommend it to anyone.

Poured from a bottle. Appearance is black with a tan head. Aroma is dark chocolate and coffee. Taste is sweet espresso and chocolate. Sweet and delicious. Aftertaste is milk chocolaty goodness. Heavy bodied. One of my all time favorites.

Review from notes, sampled 12/27/2007
Picked up a bomber at the store.

Pours a solid black with a thick fluffy tan head that stuck around for most of the experience. Initially the smell was all citrus hops, but as it warmed a bit I started getting some chocolate and some coffee. As I write this the chocolate is taking over, smells like hersheys special dark. There is a roast bitterness in the taste, but I think some of that bitterness comes from the chocolate as well. I once home brewed a chocolate stout with pure cacao nibs, and this has that taste that I got. Taste has some hops in it as well as that silky chocolate taste. Mouthfeel gets better as it warms, I initially thought it a bit thin. Great brew, Im glad I chose it today.

It pours a jet black color with a creamy 2 finger mocha head. It has a good amount of carb and some nice lacing.

On the nose its all chocolate and some faint hop notes.

The flavor is dominated by chocolate which is to expected. It also has some roasted notes.  I guess it depends on what type of chocolate you like. This is very cocoa influenced. Its pretty creamy over all but very simple.

It finishes with some faints hops and a little dry but nothing that hangs around. Its hard to believe this even beer really. This is so easy drinking. I would have to say that this would be a stout to start with if you are trying the style for the first time.

Appearance:  very dark brown to black, shortlived beige creamy head.  Aroma:  chocolate, roasted coffee beans, dark malts, hint of resin.  Taste:  big burst of chocolate and caramel malts, with some coffee and a big dash of piney, sprucy hops.  Finish:  bittersweet dry chocolate and those resinous hops fade slowly, leaving a remnant of toasted smores.  Notes:  Very pleasant chocolate stout.  Makes a great ice cream float as well.  Very drinkable.
I found this beer too confected, great concept and of course great packaging, but the chocolate flavours were not integrated well enough for my liking.  A good experience though.
22 oz bottle...poors dark brown almost black with a very thick light brown head. Smells and taste like dark chocolate with a slight roasted flavor also.
Sampled at the BrewHaHa in Grand Rapids.  A solid chocolate stout that tastes strongly of chocolate, oddly enough.  One of the highlight beers of the night.

Poured into a pint glass.

4.0 A: Pitch black color. Two fingers of brown head, which starts out really foamy and dies down to frothy. Good retention and lots of lacing.

4.5 S: Nose is full of bittersweet chocolate. Real chocolate, not artificial. I feel like Im in Hershey, PA. Pretty one dimensional, but its a good dimension.

3.0 T: Taste is a huge letdown. The burst of chocolate in the nose is nowhere as strong as I expected or would have liked. I would liken it to drinking a Coke with ice and letting all the ice melt. The diluted coke is worse than either coke or water. Thus, this beer would be better if the chocolate were ramped up or completely removed. Suprisingly bitter and much less malty than I would have expected.

2.5 M: Light body, which is the exact opposite of what I would want in a chocolate beer. A bit overly carbonated too. Not creamy at all.

2.5 D: Based on the appearance and smell I was expecting something akin to ST Choklat. The taste and mouthfeel eliminated that thought on the first sip. This is a bad beer, which could easily be salvaged by ramping up the chocolate flavors and thickening the mouthfeel.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-09-2009 06:12:13

Pours dark black with very little head.  

Smells of chocolate/cocoa and mild otherwise.  Very exciting aroma.  A very distinct and mellow chocolate nose.

Taste is all cocoa, no chocolate.  Some roast in the back.  The dryness of the cocoa dominates this beer.  Each sip seems to evaporate in my mouth.  Despite the aroma theres really no sweetness to the beer.

You have to like cocoa to like this beer.  The taste took me back at first, but I grew to it as I went along.  It is a unique beer in its single-minded focus on cocoa.

Pour is jet black with a nice deep tan head. Nose is bittersweet and chocolaty, with maple and caramel notes as well. Taste is incredibly sweet, nearly of pure chocolate with different notes at the start and finish. Cant tell whether its hoppy bitter at the end or dark chocolate bitter or both. In either case still a damn good rogue beer.

Bomber. Pours deep brown nearly black with a small light tan head. Aroma is very sweet chocolate with a touch of maple and even a bit of coffee Lots of caramel and molasses, very sweet. Flavor starts very sweet, lots of milk chocolate, very candy bar like. Malted milk balls, with plenty of creamy cocoa, chocolate milk. Gains a strong bitter dark chocolate finish with a touch of earthy and herbal hops. Medium to full creamy body and a softer carbonation. Very nice stout.
25th December 2007  When cold this beer is noticeably bitter. On warming up its much smoother. A mild chocolatey stout with a bitterish finish.

Extremely dark brown/black color.  Extremely opaque.  Just a small thin showing of ruby at the very bottom.  A very creamy tan/brown/khaki colored head that has great lacing and retention.  Poured thick.  Looks tremendous.  The lacing was the best Ive ever seen.  Smells of roasted chocolate, cocoa and whole milk.  Very well balanced.  Pleasant on the nose.  Not overly sweet, but almost perfect.  The roasted barley comes through as a nice balancing act to tame the chocolate a bit.  Taste presents a wonderful flood of roasted, sweet chocolate.  Some bitter tinges at the back end and on the sides of the tongue.  The chocolate tastes more like cocoa, chocolate milk or a liquid chocolate bar.  The bitterness starts to fade after each sip.  Amazing!!!!  I love this taste!!!!  Medium to full mouthfeel.  Smooth, dry and good.  Coats the palate exceptionally  well.  Only got a very small, tiny bit of "chalkiness", but nothing to deter the taste or feel of this beer.  Its filling and comforting.  This is truly outstanding.  This is the best "all around" beer Ive ever had in my life.  There could be better Stouts out there, but as for right now, this beer has no competion in my eye.  Easily drinkable.  I would love to have a keg of this set up in my house.  I may have just found my new favorite.  Without a doubt, worth a try.  I took my time drinking this because I didnt want to finish.  I didnt want it to end.  I could talk about this beer all day.  Incredible.

Sampled from a bottle at Mondial de la bière.  Apparently Im the only person in the world who hasnt tried this beer.  Its black, of course, with a nice brown head.  There is more chocolate than roast in the aroma, and its on the sweet side.  There is grainy chocolate and roast in the flavour as well.  The body is very smooth and drinkable.  Pretty one-dimensional, but it works.
Very dark chocolate aroma. The overwhelming chocolate taste leaves no room for any other tates in the palate. Beside a slightly bitter hop aftertaste, there is not much variation in this stout.

22 oz Bottle. Pours dark brown/black with chocolate head. Aroma of dark roasted grain and bitter chocolate. Flavor of dark roast, bitter dark chocolate and seems to have a dirty, weedy bitter blended in. Mouth feel is medium body with medium carbonation. Overall, didnt seem very sweet to me and I did not care for the finish but its not bad at all.

One year overtipe bottleVery dark brown, like black at the glass. No head. Smell is chocolate. Taste also chocolate... a bit hops, but to much chocolate. Should have some more difference inside, a bit watery also.

Very dark to black color.  Thick tan head - creamy looking.  Definitely a chocolate smell upfront. Followed by the usual roasted malt character of a stout.  Roasted malt and some coffee flavor. Some hoppy bitterness also. Chocolate is in there as well, but I didnt think it really stood out.  Medium body. Pretty smooth. Not exactly creamy but close to it.
This is an awesome stout. Its a newly perfect stout. Very chocolatey stout. Very roasty and chocolate taste.
On nitro tap at Monteauxs - Black with a brown pillowy foam head.  Sweet aroma.  Chocolate flavor and aroma.  Roasted barley comes out a bit.  Very nice winter beer.

Pours a deep brown with a very thin brown creamy head. The aroma is delicious and strong with plenty of chocolate and malt. Chocolate and hops dominate the taste and are just right. The body is a bit too thin and non alcoholic though.

Bottle. Poured into a tulip glass a dark brown/black color with a tan fluffy 2 finger head. The aroma is pretty subdued with slight notes of chocolate, dark roast coffee, and slight leather. Medium mouthfeel. Light roast notes are the first thing I notice followed by sweet bitter dark chocolate flavors. Ends pretty cleanly. Minimal lace. Overall, not too bad but no as good as some other chocolate beers.

Before I get into the pour, i just have to say this beer is delicious. Pours a nice dark brown call it black with a nice frothy tan head. Aroma all chocolate. Taste the same. Do not drink this straight from the bottle, the new taste it takes on when poured in a glass is wonderful. This is a nice sweet stout. Highly recommended.
Dark bold creamy. Nice balanced dark coco flavor. Good maltiness. Very smooth. Goes down fast and easy.

At a tasting, thanks zvikar, small stable creamy brown head, extremely dark brown colour, aroma of cocoa and milk chocolate, flavour of roasted coffee, bitter chocolate and a strong hoppy bitterness that doesnt fit in, some light sourneess in the end saving this beer from a complete hostile hoppy takeover.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Black-colored with a big brown head. Aroma of lots of chocolate, cocoa and a bit of dark fruits. Roasty flavor, rather dry but with a bit of sweetness, with chocolate, coffee and some slightly sourish milky notes. Medium-bodied.

At a tasting, thanks Dada, pours brown to black with a nice brown head, aroma of milk chocolate, chestnuts, cocoa, butter cookies and touch of smoked coffee beans, flavor is dry and acidic with American hops, coffee and notes of cocoa, medium to full body, I dont like such an amount of hops in this style.

I dont know, Ive seen so many good ratings on this brew but I got to say Im dissapointed.  Taste like a weak ale with a shot of chocolate syrup.  I guess its just not my cup of stout!  No body very thin feel in the mouth.  Just not a pleasant drink.

I tried 3 sweet stouts tonight, this was by far the best one !!The beer pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is milk chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor is roasted malt, chocolate syrup and hops. There is some surprising bitterness, either from the roasted malt or from the hops. Medium-thick mouthfeel and a biting, high carbonation. I would guess this would be AMAZING on tap.... in a bottle; still top notch.
Hops Aromatic rich aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Taste is hops, aromatic, slightly burnt, with hints of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt. Nice!

Dark, black, good tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and very roasted, coffee malt smell.  Taste has bitter, dark chocolate flavors mixed with bitter, heavily roasted malt.  The finish has a bit of burnt bitterness to it.  A tad startling at first, but after a few ounces, you settle in and its a really good beer.

22oz bottle. Pours black - cant see through it. A nice thick tan head that lasts. Aroma of malt and hops, little or no chocolate. Very smooth mouthfeel, almost silky, from the oats I imagine. Just a hint of chocolate - I honestly expected more. Oh, and then theres the hops. Great hop flavor, but I wonder if they masked the chocolate or if there isnt much chocolate to begin with? Still, a nice stout - would buy again.

Sebbie Buhler from the bottle picture poured me this sample.  Just strong all the way around.  Chocolate aroma and flavor is strong but not cloying.  Alcohol strength is just right.  Good roasty notes at the end.  Spot on and not too sweet.
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 So the Mocha Porter was a man in blue on the label, and this Chocolate Stout has a woman in brown. Anyways, this one was good, but just good. Not even great, which saddens me so.

22oz bottle.  Poured a dark opeque black color with a thick dense and creamy mocha head.  Aroma is big chocolate and roasty malt in the backround.  Flavor is rich and chocolaty. Combined with the hop bitterness, the taste is somewhat like semisweet chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, oily finish with a lingering taste of bitter chocolate.

Pours thick and dark with a beautiful fluffy brown head. Aroma is hoppy and malty with hints of chocolate. The aroma is much more subtle thant the flavor which is hoppy, quite malty and lots of chocolate mostly in the back end. Clean moth feel. Very nice. Though I think I prefer the double.

Bottle. Beautiful black pour with an adequately small brown head. Aroma is thick with milky chocolate, vanilla, subtle roast, faint liquorice, milky chocolate, slight oak, milky chocolate, milky chocolate! Very delicious! Taste is much the same with lots of lovely chocolatey roast and lovely liquorice. This bottle is over 2 years old, and still retains a very lovely taste and aroma, which is nizzle. Remembering the low alcohol, this has an amazingly big body and is generally quite epic.

30-OCT-2010, bottle @home, with Morten, from "Ølkonsortiet".
Black, nice brown head.
Chocolate (!), and a very fine one.
Underneath is a very fine stout.
A bit simple and one-dimensional, but if you are into chocolate (arent we all?) this is one of the best.
Absolutely delicious.
Thanks to MPA for help on obtaining this.
Pours a dark brown with a nice thick head.  Aroma of malt and chocolate and same on the taste.  Really tasty, but not all that complex.  Not as sweet as the Southern Tier chocolate stout.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a nonic pint glass.

Appearance: Pours a coffee black color with a 4 finger creamy chocolate brown head. Excellent lacing. Looks amazing and perfect for a stout.

Smell: Sweet milk chocolate with just a hint of roasted malt. Aroma is very much like hot chocolate. Smells delicious.

Taste: Chocolate flavor abounds throughout. Semi-sweet chocolate up front followed by roasted malt in the middle and burnt toast at the finish. Hop bitterness is mild. Aftertaste is a nice mix of smoke and dark chocolate. The flavor is quite dry but very chocolaty. Not as sweet as the aroma would indicate but it is quite good nonetheless.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a low amount of carbonation. Nice and creamy.

Drinkability: High drinkability. You could knock back a bomber or two without much trouble on a cool evening.

Overall: Excellent stout overall. I would highly recommend this one.
Nice smooth taste. Pours a dark black with a brown head. Taste is chocolatey and of a roasted cereal.

Pours very dark opaque brown, almost black, with a light brown fine-bubbled lasting head.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, earth, and dates.  Lightly sweet, lightly tart; unsweetened chocolate and toasted grain malt background with notes of apple and citrus and a lightly bitter coffee finish; much lighter than I expected and very clean.  Medium body with a very light creamy texture and soft carbonation.  Overall, a light drinking and elegant stout.  I could probably do with a touch more residual sweetness/roasted malt character but still nice.
Pours almost black with a creamy tan head. Dark chocolate, malty, oat aroma. Starts sweet and ends with bitter chocolate. Heavy bodied. Incredibly delicious!

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, rich chocolate, & some coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, hops, and some coffee; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, well done - great stout.

22 oz bottle. Pours black with a creamy dark tan head. Nose is a milky chocolate. Full, creamy body. Nice balance of sweet malts and hops- more hops than you would expect, I think, but Im always okay with that. Finish is creamy and very chocolatey leaving a sticky dark chocolate aftertaste. It manages to be heavy on the chocolate without it feeling overdone. Really like this one.

(750ml bottle).  Pours almost black with tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma of intense chocolate-liquid tootsie roll.  Taste is sweet with a little sour and some bitterness.  Body is light to medium with thin and creamy texture. Finish is smooth.  Very easy to drink beer.  Me likey!
22 oz bomber. Pours a thick dark brown. The taste is of dark chocolate. Definitely on the bitter side but pretty good overall.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Bomber shared with Jeff. Dark pour with light brown head that stays. Good milk chocolate smell in the nose. Taste is surprisingly mild - definite chocolate, but not overwhelming. Smooth. A beer to drink with cookie dough.
Nice and smooth all the way down. The body is full and creamy, and the aroma matches the taste. This to me is a near perfect chocolate stout suitable for finishing off a meal or any other beers.

Dusty dark chocolate and talc aroma. Jet black, crema head. Rich broody, bitter chocolate - hints of sweetcaramel but then an almost tobacco bitterness kicks in. Decadent and delicate but delightful enough to have a pint-of appeal. Yummmm
Bière stout au chocolat, saveur de chocolat doux sucré style jersey milk, très mousseuse, de couleur noir foncé, bien houblonné...très bonne!!!

Bottle:
Big brown (hint of rose) foamy head.
Thick black color.
Smell is CHOCOLATE, chocolate milk and hints of coffee and wood.
Taste just a tiny little bit waterish. Low body at first which changes directly into a stronger tasting chocolate milk with hints of coffee and bitter. Also hints of wood and malts. Dominating (milk) chocolate.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: 22 oz. bottle- Pours black as black with a nice frothy tan head, aroma is strong chocolate and espresso, very appealing. The flavor is bitter followed by a strong chocolate flavor followed by more bitterness, man I love it when a beer actually tastes like chocolate like the description says. There is also a oat flavor to it, Maybe not like an oatmeal stout, but they are definitely there. If they mellowed out the hops a bit I think it would be even better. Man I could drink this all night, or pour some on some ice cream, that would be good.

220z. bottle: Pours a dark chocolate with a dark brown head. Aroma is of strong chocolate and chocolate malts. Taste is heavy chocolate with a great balance that lends to a smooth drinking beer. As with many Rogue flavors, the chocolate does not feel natural but rather forced. Easy drinking and great chocolate flavor make this interesting.

Bomber from the Natomas BevMo. Pours quite black with a 3 finger foamy beige head. Aroma is quite chocolate with undertones of coffee and nuts. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Flavor remains very chocolate, but its quite bitter. Either really burnt malt or a fair amount of hop. Actually has a creamy smell/taste. Also a treacle note. Finishes pretty dry for a sweet stout. Drinks quite easily.

Pours a deep opaque black with a small creamy beige head that leaves some streaks of lacing on the sides.

The aroma is the best part of this beer for me.  Its like a slightly bittersweet hot chocolate in the nose.  Theres some roasted malts but its all about the chocolate.

The taste has a hefty dose of chocolate as well but it definitely has more bitterness than the aroma indicates.  The black malts are more prevalent and the finish leaves a bitter chocolate aftertaste.

The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with soft carbonation.  Bitter, cocoa powdery finish.

This is a very good stout with an aroma that is exceptional, as long as youre a fan of chocolate.  As a 6% ABV stout, this is a great, flavorful beer.

Nice.  Pours black with a bit of head.  Aromas: dark chocolate, roasty malts, hints of coffee.  Lingering bitter finish.  The bitter roastiness is nicely balanced by the sweet/exotic chocolate and the smoothness of the oats.  Mouthfeel a touch watery, but very smooth.  Goes down very easily.  Yum!
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2011 Great aroma of chocolate. Great hop backbone in the taste, nothing up front, just like a good stout should. Good shit.

Poured an espresso brown with a dark rich head.  Aromas were strong - especially the bitter chocolate.  Flavors were rich dark malts, more bitter chocolate and subtle wood flavors.  Full bodied flavors with a finish that lasts - this was a great one.  Terrific dessert beer!

draught at capital ale house.  pours a big black color with a thin tan head.  aroma is straight up chocolate with a lil roasted malts.  t:  big ole cocoa, hershey kiss, and a lil roasted flavor, veery sweet.

22 oz Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown, with a mild tan head. You can smell the chocolate truffles immediately; flavors are the same, yet bitter, with some coffee beans and maltiness. I was surprised at how watery this brew was on the finish.

The head formed in a traditional stout way with the bubbles rising very slowly from the sides of the glass. The head was a dark yellow cream and from a distance the bitter chocolate aroma became apparent. If I wasnt looking I would say that this beer reminds me of Pilon espresso with a bar of dark chocolate mixed in. Full body lively creamy smooth drinkable and it will leave the front of your palate with a cold bittersweet cocoa residue. I give it 12 Basterds.

Black pour with a quickly fading brown head. Strong chocolate aroma with some roasted malt and coffee presence. Medium body. A bitter chocolate and malty flavor with some lingering bitterness. The bottle states that chocolate flavoring has been added to this beer which may aid ans contribute to the heavier chocolate flavor without the additional roastedness.

Cask at GBBF 2010. Black coloured pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Tastes of real quality chocolate, malt, slight bitterness. Very mellow and really easy to drink. A quality chocolate stout.
Cask @ GBBF. Aroma of turkish delight premdominantly, also dark and milk chocolate and perfume. Bittersweet finish.

wasnt that happy with this beer. the chocolate flavor was to syrupy rather then pure chocolate. much like the choklat from southern tier. i much prefer a rich pure  chocolate like stone 12th anniversary.

From Bottle. Dark, thick rootbeer appearance. Smells of fresh coffee in a chocolate store. Taste lives up entirely to the scent. Enough bitterness to feel like high quality chocolate, rather than run-of-the-mill candy bars.  A great -chocolate- stout, especially at its price and availability.

Very nice dark brown pour with gorgeous layer of tan head that lingers slightly but leaves very little lacing behind.

Smell is dark baking chocolate. Flavor is similar but tastes a bit more like chocolate milk/cocoa powder. Also just enough hoppy bitterness in the finish to balances out the sweetness.

Could be just a tad more thick & creamy, but other than that the mouthfeel is very nice.  I would probably drink this again.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ jet black with a tan head.Aroma of chocolate ,roasted malt and coffee.Flavour is chocolate,roasted malt ,coffee and caramel.Medium body,medium carbonation.Nice beer.

On tap at Barleys Taproom in downtown Knoxville last week while I was visiting there.  Black-sih with some brown highlights but no head.  This was my second beer that afternoon and both had zero head -- whats wrong?  Big vanilla in the nose with other notes of roasted malts and cocoa powder.  Flavor has quite bitter (i.e. not sweet) chocolate, more vanilla, and lightly bitter and burnt roasted malts.  The aroma is sweet but the flavor surprisingly not so -- I would actually like this to be more sweet.  Creamy palate with bitter chocolate in the finish.  Joetheyounger traded me a bottle of the Rogue imperial chocolate stout (available only in Japan?), so I will have to open it soon and compare with the normal version.  (1687, 337)

22 oz. bomber from The Party Source.  Pours a dark, cloudy brown with a minimal beige head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, oats, and toasted brown sugar.  The flavor leans more toward the coffee and roasted malts than chocolate.  Chocolate becomes more apparent as it warms, especially in the nose.  Medium-bodied with moderate carbonation and a mouthfeel that feels like cola with cocoa powder in it.  Nice sweet stout that favors the roasty over the sweet.

Bottle. Pours jet black with thin tan coloured head. I get a huge aroma of cloves with some raosted malt and plenty of dark choclate. Unfortunately cloves arent my favourite so this take away someone from this beer, but other than that nice aromas. Flavours are much the same. Some initial sweetness offset by the bitterness from the roasted malt. Not too bad other than the cloves.
Bottle pours dark black with thin tan head. Rather mild roast and chocolate flavors. Thin to medium body with somewhat smooth feel. Not very bitter. A little too mellow for my tastes.

Served on cask at Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA, 6/7/10. Pours a nearly black color with a large tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of dark roasted malts, chocolate, caramel and bitter hops. The taste is bitter hops, chocolate, caramel and lightly roasted malts. Medium bodied and creamy.

I had this as part of a sampler at the House of Rogue in Newport, OR.  This was hands down the best beer I chose in the sampler.  Aroma is of pure chocolate and cocoa.  Appearance is black and very creamy.  Taste is pretty much like hot chocolate and cocoa, its a quintessential dessert beer, very good.

Pours black with 2 finger black brown head. Smell is extremely chocolaty, with a lil bit of nutty roast/coffee, with some sort of fruit showing through. Taste is similar with more coffee coming through. Medium bodied and quite smooth, with light carbonation and a medium-dry finsh.
One the best beers out there! Rogue knows what theyre doing. Rogues chocolate stout is pure taste bud pleasure!

[bottle]
Lots of vanilla and oak in the aroma, which a hint of chocolate. Opaque, almost oily black, with a light brown patch and ring. Dry dark malt bitterness together with bittersweet chocolate that fades back to a dark malt bitterness. A touch of dried fruit. Light to medium body, moderate to medium carbonation, lasting bitter chocolate finish.

22 US fl.oz. bomber bottle poured into a tulip pint glass...

The appearance is oustanding! Dark brown body, with small bubbles rising. An extremely rich fluffy brown head. Great head retention and lacing!

Very chocolatey on the nose. Sweet milk chocolate notes, some floral hop notes, and a solid roastiness. This is indeed one of the most chocolatey-smelling beers out there!

As much as the smell reminded me of sweet milk chocolate, the taste couldnt be further away from it. At first, bitter chocolate notes dominated, followed by a solid roastiness, with a touch of coffee. Some earthy hops were also present The finish was dry and fairly bitter, with just a hint of chocolate lingering on. After some time, I began noticing a little more sweetness appearing, which really boosted the drinkability for me.

Medium body to it; fairly crisply carbonated. Quite smooth; nicely coats your palate. No trace of alcohol.

Overall, this is a very drinkable stout. Definitely smoother and more drinker-friendly than a typical dry stout. The chocolate really makes a difference. If you are a fan of stout, youll probably enjoy this a lot. This could even make a session stout.
From a 22oz bottle,black in color,brown head,delicious chocolate flavor,roasty malt,This may be one of my favorite Chocolate beers.

A wonderful all around beer.  Maybe a bit too toasty chocolatey for some,but exactly what I expect.  Beautiful dark color followed up with a toasty cocoa nose and great mouthfeel.  Then just a nice chocolate stout profile...I shouldnt be any more complicated.
Wonderful aroma of dark chocolate, slightly roasted coffee. Taste is the same, with some ending bitterness.
The chocolate stout. Most say chocolate, this one actually tastes of chocolate. Bitter chocolate, milk chocolate, sweet chocolate, and chocolate malts all dominate!

A nice stout.  Pours like a stout with a nice brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malts and some coffee(?).  Well carbonated and drinks smooth.  Some chocolate and roasted flavors are going on here, subtle bitterness, not much sweetness.  Maybe a bit too carbonated but really nice.

On tap at the Copper Mine Pub in North Arlington New Jersey.

Appearance: Pours an earthy brown with red corners and an off whilte 1 finger crown that shows a touch of retention and lace.

Smell: Impressive amount of chocolate coupled with a bready toasty malt.

Taste: You know most chocolate beers have a dark chocolate flavor with a mild amount of bitterness. Those same beers are very similar to coffee stouts that have that same dark roast bitter quality. This brew tastes more like milk chocolate with absolutely no bitterness. Just chocolate and malt here folks. Delicious.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied....seems a touch thin to me.

Drinkability: Goes down like liquid candy.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-18-2009

Bottle from the Cracked Kettle in Amsterdam. Almost black with a lacing, tanned head. Aroma is totally dominated by an interplay of sweet milk chocolate and darker chocolate. Low sweetness and a nice balancing bitterness.

Poured off the cask at Rogue Public House, San Francisco. Opaque. Unbelievable creamy, with an aroma that was the darkest, sweetest chocolate and a flavor to match. A touch bitterness derived wholly from the dark chocolate, and an otherwise rich malty flavor blow this stout leaps beyond any chocolate stout Ive had the pleasure of drinking. It may have been a bit too chocolaty as I felt it had lost some of its identity as a beer, but on the whole a fantastic chocolate stout.
Dark brown opaque pour with dark coffee head.  Vanilla, CHOCOLATE duh and some roasty/toasty stuff in the background.  Makes great beer pancakes!!!

Draught at Blind Tiger. Black with almost no head. Aroma is sweet chocolate and vanilla with roasty background. Taste is not as sweet as expected, still chocolate but goes bitter in finish. Long roasty finish.

Served into a tulip glass from a 22 ounce bottle that I found in my cellar. No date on the bottle, but Im guessing its older than a year, but less than 3 years. Dark opaque black, with a huge foamy light brown head that produces small amounts of lacing on the glass.Subtle chocolate aroma. Chocolate cocoa and burnt malt flavors and a bit of charcoal. Originally, I picked up a bit of unpleasant bitterness that seems to have disappeared as the beer warms to room temperature. Medium bodied, not as full bodied as I would have expected for a rich stout. Lots of carbonation and a dry finish.Nice sipping beer to have sitting on the patio on a cool spring evening. Would also pair well with a chocolate desert.

I can imagine the wily, unhinged Wonka factory feverishly brewing this beer if the manic candy-maker had ever gone into the business of alcohol. How did Rogue create this monster? Did they take a chisel to the side of a chocolate mountain? Im not sure, but this thing is on cocoa-overdrive. A great beer to go with a bevvy of ice cream, or simply on its own. Syrupy but crisp, this milky stout is tailer-made for post-dinner escapades. Oily in color and rich in flavor, Rogue should be proud.
Deep, dark, rich and chocolatey, this is a real serious beer with a heavy body and a round palate. A little bitternesd
My only real gripe is the body, too thin and a bit watery for what Im looking for in a chocolate and tasut. Smells of milk chocolate and taste sweet and chocolatey delicous.

I had bought a few of these when the LCBO had them for a limited time, (back in September 2004). They were cellared and now they are gone. It pours a really dark black colour with no highlights. The head is big, brown, creamy, stays a long time and leaves great lacing. Some yeast or chocolat sediments go to the bottom of the glass. Sweet nose of chocolat with some light candy. You can feel the powdered chocolat around your tongue. The taste is not too sweet, but has a bitterness found in imported chocolats (written on the front label). Hop is also very present with its own bitterness, and some molasse, roasted malts, maple syrup. This one (as well as Youngs Double Chocolat) are my favorite chocolat stouts. Please LCBO, bring some more in. Thanks.

Bottle from the Liquor Store in Tyngsboro MA. Nice frothy head with good lacing. Strong aroma of chocolate, more chocolate and maybe some cocoa-based confection (chocolate?). Just kidding, its actually not overwhelmingly chocolate-ey, thankfully. Its also got a fair amount of bitterness due to well-roasted malt.
Black. Aroma is full of chocolate! Flavor brings coffee and chocolate. Palate is pleasant round and easy.

The beer pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is milk chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor is roasted malt, chocolate syrup and piney hops. There is some surprising bitterness, either from the roasted malt or from the cascade hops. Medium-thick mouthfeel and a biting, high carbonation. A very nice beer, but I wish the hops were more in the background since I dont think the pine flavor melds real well with the chocolate notes.

Poured dark brown, with a beige, creamy lacing head. I agree with Armando629, close resemblance to a Somló sponge cake dessert. Chocolate, raisins, rum and cocoa aroma. Sweet with a pleasant bitter finish. Medium dense body, with fairly low carbonation. No false advertising on this one, you get whats on the label.

0,65 l bottle, shared with Balazs. Thanks!
Poured deep brown with a delicious creamy tan head. Fantastic aroma, like a Somló Sponge Cake  with cocoa,  rum, mild roasted aroma, chocolate(wath a surprise), vanilla, fine spcies. Smoot mouthfeel with a sweet but roasted character, both dark and milk chocolates, cocoa-powder. Fine, moderated roasted aftertaste with sweetness of  a cookie. Well rounded, fine, pleasant.
Dark with thin tan head. Aroma of bitter coffee. Very unique hoppy, tingly sort of flavor. Quite original and respectable, but just not a favorite style of mine.

Deep Dark and Devastating.  Not quite as intense as a Russian Imperial Stout, but think a little lighter, and with some chocolate hints. That and the coffee taste of the stout led me to save one for breakfast the next day. Good stuff
Solid chocolate stout.  A good amount of hops but smooth with a chocolate aroma.  Not my favorite but Id definitely have it again.
Cask, believe it or not, at Churchkey.  Dark maroon, no head, no lacing.  Aroma of sweet Nestles bar.  Taste is also sweet, light, cafe au lait and Cadburys.  Very nice.

Big Bottle in a tulip glass, Honolulu. Black color with brown head. Hint of smoke, cacao, brown sugar a bit of pine tar. The taste is sweet and bitter. The bitter is on the front of the tongue. A little slick on the tongue with a long finish. This may become my stout of choice

A- wonderful. small creamy dark tan head with deep black body.

S- sweet dark chocolate and coffee. some hops noted too.

T- malty at the beginning with hints of coffee. bitter hop aftertaste. Dark chocolate lingers. The chocolate and hops blend well together.

P- thick heavy body and high carbonation. Goes down pretty easy.

O- This is a very drinkable treat. Its not hard to drink the whole bomber in one sitting and that is enough for the time being too.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-18-2007 19:26:25

650 ml bottle. Pours opaque black with lasting tan head. Nose of big chocolate and vanilla. Taste of more chocolate, viscous molasses body, and balanced by bitter hop finish. Overall a tasty brew, but not something I could drink too much of due to the sweetness.

Nice chocolate aroma with alcohol, pours pitch black.  Creamy, smooth, rich chocolate perfect level of IBUs to balance the sweetness.  Full bodied, but slightly on the lighter side.  Almost sessionable, almost...

Draft. dark brown pour, heavy bodied. Dark chocolate dominates the taste, hints of fruit.  No stout taste at all, I thought i was drinking chocolate syrup.  Not at all liking, lucky got it during happy hour.
Black brown body.  Immediate aroma of chocolate with some malty notes.  Toasty malt continues in the flavor with some coffee like characteristics.  Body is a little watery but enjoyable.

Bomber. Dark brown pour with thick brown head which fades to leave a heavy, coarse lace. Fruit and chocolate nose, like a chocolate-cherry liqueur. Nicely tart at the beginning with hops, chocolate and fruit. Heavy body, oily mouth feel and lightly carbonated. Bitter resin and chocolate finish, a tasty heavy dessert stout. One of my favorite stouts!

Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--Chocolate Bear Beer--1999	12 oz. Bottle.  5.25% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Stout--Dark black color.  Rich chocolate head leaves big lace.  Sweeter more chocolate less hop version of Shakespeare Stout. Sweet chocolate front. Chalky body carries on flavor. Smooth dry sweetness to end.  Sampled 12/29/1999.

Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--Chocolate Stout--Black 2001B 22 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV--69 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Big chocolate front.  Big sediment.  Dark black opaque color with flecks of sediment.  Rich chocolate head.  Floral hops balance dry roasted rich body and and finish.  Rich hot aftertaste.  Creamy,Dry.  Sampled 5/18/2001.
	
Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--Chocolate Stout--2001 White Graphics 22 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV--69 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Big chocolate front.  Big sediment.  Dark black opaque color with flecks of sediment.  Rich chocolate head.  Floral hops balance dry roasted rich body and and finish.  Rich hot aftertaste.Creamy,Dry.  Sampled 5/18/2001.

Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--Chocolate Stout--Industrial Roguette--Sebbie Buhler 2004 22 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV--69 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Stout--Chocolate.  Rich lacy espresso head. Opaque very dark obsidian black color.  Rich hop roasted cocoa espresso front.  Creamy oat dry sweet sediment mellowed roasted chocolate mild doughy crusty body.  Rich cocoa hop end.  Sampled 11/21/2004.

Pours opaque black with off brown/tan head that retains well.

Nose has a nougat-chocolate character that is very enticing.

On the palate the roasted malts, multi-chocolate flavours dominate, and hops are noticeable in the background to keep things from getting out of hand.

One of the most drinkable chocolate stouts Ive ever had.

The chocolate components are truly some of the best around.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark mahogany, close to black color. Thick, creamy beige head. Decent retention with a good amount of lacing left.

S - Earthy dark chocolate dominates the nose. A bit of a grain and bread smell.

T - Good amount of roasted malts and oats. Dark bread and grain taste taste upfront first. Then loads of dark and milk chocolate that gives a bitter and some sweet taste. A little bit of a cherry flavor. Decent amount of hops giving a slight citrus taste. Starts off somewhat sweet and progresses to finish somewhat bitter.

M - Medium body with good carbonation. Pretty smooth and creamy but it is a little thinner than what I was expecting.

D - Pretty good. Not too sweet or bitter. Lots of chocolate, but it is well balanced as are the malts and hops. Goes down easy but it would have been better if it were slightly thicker.

Notes: Loads of chocolate with lots of flavor. Chocolate provides slightly more bitterness than sweetness (same goes for the overall taste), but that may be just because the finish is bitter and it stays on the tongue for awhile.

On tap at Royal Tavern Philadelphia. One of the best of this style Ive had, very sweet, and Im pretty sure there was some chocolate sediment at the bottom of the glass, Nestle-Quik style. Very rich and filling, creamy, hardly any carbonation or head, and no alcholic twang. Yummy!
Chocolate yogate/diary food aroma. Dark black in colour with big toffee coloured head. Whitakas dark chocolate flavour with mild hop bitterness. Dry finish. Great for chocolate lovers.

Awesome beer. Pour is deep black with dark tan head. two fingers. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee. Taste is uber-chocolate and hint of coffee in the finish. Overall, a solid beer. Rogue never fails.

Nose is straight up chocolate  (hersheys) syrup. Liquid chocolate, well balanced with a syrupy mouthfeel. I found it really one dimensional, was hoping there would be more to it, but for being a chocolate stout, you cant really go wrong can ya?
Black with a tan head. Aroma-roasted malt, chocolate. Taste- very chocolatey, roasty, almost like a smore without the sweetness. Bitter in the end, lingering chocolate. Medium body.

Heartbroken that my Youngs Double Chocolate Stout is so hard to find I went on a quest to find a chocolate stout that could match it. Thanks to smith4498 for the suggestion. 22oz. bottle from the fine folks at Crown Liquors. The smell is a strong dark chocolate one. Poured nice and thick into my stein with a brown milkshake style head. A very dark brew. The taste is more coffee than chocolate, a bitter tasty flavor. Not as good as Youngs, but I will definitely be getting this again.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2010 Aroma is really full of chocolate, and not just the ordinary strong chocolate, that you often find in stouts, but this one really smells like milk chocolate, and it just has a great aroma. Actually only milk chocolate, but Oh boy, is this delcious
A rather dark color. The taste has lots of chocolate, a bit of coffee and has a some hops.
A nice beer. After having a few of these that were past last sales date, I found out that it holds really well with some years on it. Every time I drink this, its just really great, even though its past its last sales date, even by 2,5 years. A bloody sweet session.

Tap. Pour is almost black (but its dark in this bar) with a thin brown head.  Aroma is large on chocolate, hints of roasted malt, and light vanilla.  The aroma is really dominated by chocolate, like a milkshake.  A bit thin on the palate, but not too bad.  Flavor is also dominated by chocolate milkshake with hints of roasted malt in the finish.  Not terribly complex, but delivers on what it promises.
22 ounce bottle.a pitch black pour 3 finger head taste of chocolate, coffee, roasty, A bitter chocolate toasty finish.A real  good stout

Black body, small off-white head, heavy lacing. Strong aroma of milk chocolate. No sweetness on the tip of the tongue, very strong, bitter chocolate taste coats the mouth. Medium body, lingering chocolatey bitterness.

A: Very, very dark brown with a thin tan head.

S: Tons of chocolate, a nice nuttiness, chocolate, some coffee, oh and chocolate.

T: As you would hope and expect, chocolate, chocolate, and more chocolate. A nice blend of bitter and sweeter chocolate tastes.

M: Great body, very smooth.

D: Incredible for a stout, such incredible chocolate flavor. Truly one of the best stouts Ive had.

On tap Feb 12, 2010.  Pours black with medium tan head.  Dark chocolate and other roasted malts on the nose.  Very appealing aroma!  More chocolate and coffee notes hit the palate with some bitterness in the finish.  Not a huge fan of the style, but this is an awesome beer!  One sweet stout!  Cheers!

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2016 Poured from bottle. An incredible nose; I could smell chocolate and coffee from almost three feet away. Pours a rich, dark brown with a moussy head that lasts and lasts. Flavor is deep and complex; chocolate predominates but theres also toast, caramel, and what I can only describe as a port-like note. Mouthfeel is textured and oily. OK, I get the fuss about chocolate stouts now; Im now going to go ahead and drink this damned fine beer.

Powerful aroma of chocolate that reminds me of chocolate milk powder.  Dark black in color with a nice tan head.  This big bodied stout tastes heavily of chocolate with a hoppy finish.  Not as sweet as one would expect from a beer this chocolaty.

Chocolate shoveling beer for round 2 of this week o storms in the Northeast... Pours a big dark brown nearly black with a nice fading tan head.... Chocolate and possibly vanilla aroma atop some slight hoppiness and a note or two of roastiness... Big flavor of chocolate over a roasty body... Smooth body, not abrasive at all, goes down easy, with a slightly dry finish, but not enough to hold off that next sip... Not nearly as burnt/roasty as you would expect, drinkable chocolate stout, very nice...
UPDATED: JUN 27, 2013 This is my treat: Love it in the bomber or on tap. I fill my growler whenever I can.

Pours pure black. I see no light or color coming through. The head is almost three fingers and looks somewhat soapy. Big bubbles popping and leave a nice lacing on my Guinness tulip pint glass.

Smell is pure hersheys syrup. Good grief this smells delicious. Dive in deeper and i get some major hops hidden initially by the chocolate. Some floral notes.

This beer is pretty much chocolate hops. Lots of chocolate sweetness as one would expect but the finish is nice a bitter and hoppy. The hops balance it out nicely or the chocolate might be too out of control.

Smooth and silky. Nice mouthfeel just a bit of carbonation present. I would call this medium to heavy bodied.
