Drinkability is good. Slightly heavy so i could only drink one bomber. But it is delicious and great for dessert.

Overall this is a really good beer and a really good chocolate. I really dont have any other chocolate stouts to compare it to. I would recommend this one definitely.

Pours very dark with thick creamy head.  Aroma has hints of a smoky cigar that is prevelant in the palate.  Taste holds obvious caramel and earthy flavors.  Chocolate is primary character in the palate.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 Bomber. Pours syrupy and black as night with an inch of light brown creamy head. Aroma is bitter chocolate and roasted malt. The taste begins with rich, creamy dark chocolate followed by vanilla, coffee and roasted malts. It finishes dry and slightly smoky with a bittersweet chocolate aftertaste. This Stout has a wonderful balance of sweetness and bitterness and bold chocolate flavors that assert themselves from beginning to end.

Yum. Bury your nose in your glass and smell the delicious notes of roasted chocolate malts...and thats just getting started! A nice foamy head and rich, dark color are very pleasing. The taste of Rogue Chocolate Stout starts very smooth with flavors of rich chocolate, toasty malts, and rolled oats-- very reminiscent of a chocolate breakfast cereal. The finish includes hops which leave a bittersweet taste in your mouth; diagnosis, another sip of this tasty beer...you know, just so you can clear your palate :)

Pours thick black with tan head, aroma is full of chocolate.  Taste up front is a bit of sweet moving into thick chocolate with some bitterness at the end.  Excellent showing, like choklat toned down!

I have not been the biggest fan of some chocolate- and coffee-flavored beers, but this one really nails the balance of flavors, never tastes artificial and still has a sweet, dessert-like flavor. The beer smells like expensive cocoa powder mixed with cacao nibs and a dash of roasted coffee beans. The flavor is wonderful. The chocolate is perfectly used. The beer isnt too sweet or too chocolatey. There are good mineral and earthy hop notes. The malt backbone is big and strong. Its an enormous flavor for a stout that clocks in at a mere 6% abv, a trifling amount compared to some of the Imperial versions. The lush, creamy feel is the finishing touch.

Deep dark brown pour, creamy coffee head.
Strong dark chocolate aroma, some hops and spices.
Thin but strong chocolate flavour with some hops and something earthy.
Pours a dark espresso brown with a tan-tinged head. Aroma is very chocolatey with earthy pine notes. Flavor is very hoppy with chocolate bite. Body is fairly light with high carbonation.

Pours a black-brown color with a foamy, tan had.  aroma is of bakers chocolate, dark choclote, bread, and some coffee.  flavor is of coco, roasted and smokey malt, dark chocolate, some roasted cofee, and a little hops.  has a medium full body with a creamy and slightly oily mouthfeel.  overall, a very good stout.
@ Beertemple. Black colored brew. Intense chocolate aroma. Very intense flavor too of chocolate, truffle and malts.

Bomber pours black with plenty retaining brown head into a pint glass; great looking brew.  Slightly roasted malty aroma with semisweet and bakers chocolate, vaguely detectable hop presence, bit bready.  Toasted/roasted malt backbone, very bitter cocoa though there is a bit of residual sweetness with a vague hop bite in the finish.  Bready and a bit thin.  Frothy on the palate with medium body and low-medium carbonation level.  Very drinkable and sessionable.  Tasty stuff, have a pint or two!

Bottle. It smells sweet of chocolate, very malty, also some dark coffee. The brown creamy head is medium large with a long duration. The body is lively and black. The Stout tasted smoky-roasted, a bitter middle part with a long strong finish. The body is very creamy, medium strong with a lively carbonation.

in my glass it pours opaque with a nice thick tan head. aroma is of oats and chocolate.taste has a medium sweetness and is lightly bitter. full body, thick feel, soft carbonation. overall a good beer, although i think my girlfriend likes it more.

Black with a creamy chocolate colored head that disappears into nothingness rather quickly. The smell of dark chocolate is overwhelming on the nose but I can sense some roasted malts and hints of licorice in the background. For once this stout actually holds the same taste as with the smell: instant dark chocolate that fades into a nice bitter alcohol sting with a hint of roasted coffee taste. This defiantly tastes more like an imperial than a sweet stout.

Enjoyed via draft in a pub glass.  The beer pours an opaque black color with a small to moderate tan head.  Carbonation is good, for the style.  The aroma brings characters of chocolate milk, followed by subtle roasted malt.  The palate again begins with a nice natural-tasting chocolate character, followed by some middle to high crystal roasted malt flavor.   The latter, combined with what seems to be a fairly restrained hand with hops, gives the beer a balancing bitterness near the end of the palate.  The finish is characteristically clean, like nearly all of Rogues offerings.  Overall, a really well-done flavored stout.

Bomber 
Appearance :  Deep black with a huge creamy and fluffy head. Nice lacings. Long head retention.

Aroma : Chocolate and hops with hints of vanilla. Quite mellow. Very appealing nose. Top notch aroma.

Taste :  Chocolate, vanilla, very mellow. Some hops and roasted malt. Felt a bit watery I would say. 

Finish : Hoppy with hints of chocolate and vanilla.

Palate : A bit flat but that makes it quite drinkable and mellow.

Overall : Swesome aroma. Good taste but a bit watery. Nice beer.
opaque black,  thick terracotta colored diminishing head with congruent lacing. very dark body. roasty, coffee, chocolate aroma. medium body, slick feel, soft carbonation, rather bitter finish.

Bottle at The Beertemple, Amsterdam. Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and nothing but chocolate. Slightly watery taste, slightly bitter, and mostly.. chocolate. Bittersweet finish. If you like dark chocolate, you will like this beer.
Black in colour with a large airy dark tan head. Sweet aroma of roasted malt. Expected it to be a bit thicker. Get a pleasant chocolate aftertaste.

Bottle, pours a dark black with tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate and roast, smells great.  Taste a lot of chocolate with some malt and coffee notes and a slightly bitter finish.  Good carbonation and mouthfeel.  Not as complex as other stouts, but this is just plain tasty.

Bottle at Avenue Pub. Dark beer with tan head. Immediate strong chocalatey aroma. Tastes of bitter chocolate with a roastiness to it. This is the first chocolate stout Ive had, but overall a decent beer.

Bottle.  Opaque almost-black pour with a coffee-colored head.  Smell was strong chocolate with roastiness.  The taste was chocolate as well, but it was bitter.  Not much sweetness in the taste, definitely a bitter dark chocolate.  Very tasty, creamy mouthfeel too.   Well-done.
Bottle. Had this after the seahorse ale. Pours a pitch black body - the aroma smells strong of chocolate. The taste is chocolate and roastiness. Nice choc stout. enjoyable to the last drop.

This beer was dark black as stouts usually are. The head was a light coffee color. The smell was just a hint of dark chocolate. The taste was also dark chocolate but not very strong. i was actually expecting a stronger flavor since flavoring was added. This beer was decent and probably one of the better Rogue beers I have had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-09-2007 15:24:05

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2010 Pours a beautiful black colour with a medium mocca head. The aroma is a very nice malty chocolate smell. The taste is of course filled with chocolate, as well as malty roasts and hops which create a slightly bitter finish that is quite nice. It is full bodied and somewhat creamy. A very good beer overall.

Solid dark color. Filmy mocha head. Head doesnt last long. I can only pick out chocolate in the aroma. Some roasted malts as well. Flavors are mainly of dark chocolate. Just like the aroma, there are also plenty of roasted malts. Starts out sweet and chocolaty, then finishes with some roasted bitterness. Maybe a little too bitter to finish. Leaves a acidic taste in my mouth. Body is thin, with proper carbonation. Maybe i was expecting too much..

2009-07-14, västkusten, Sweden,
Etikett bedömning blev även en smoke idag...
Flaska 10 grader.
Kolsvart med ljust kolaärgat skum
Doft: himmelsk tryffel choklad
S: lite sämre choklad, kaffe, bitterhet
ES: lång fin

Pours Black thin head. Aroma is very roasty with strong notes of chocolate. The flavour is also very strong with noites of chocolate and a strong flavour of roasted malt.Kind of bitter and dry. All in all not great. Pretty unispired for a Rogue product.

Smells very strongly of chocolate malts and roasted barley.  Ive been experimenting with beer temperature and I think I had this one a little too warm.  The flavors were a little overpowering and a tad bitter.  It mellowed slightly when I chilled it but I think that some age would do wonders for this beer.  I may have to pick one up and leave it in the basement till next Christmas.

(br-btl, wt-painted-lbl)
(tap at Eli Cannons in Middletown CT)

bk-opq, med milk chclt head, med co2, med body.

aroma:  baking-chclt.

flavor:  chclt oats T1, bitter hops T2, bitter-chclt chrcl T3, same thru.

rich flavor and texture with a nice medium complexity.

22 oz Bottle -- Pours black with a big tan head.  Aromas of sweet roasted malt, chocolate milk, and coffee.  Not as sweet as it smells, bitter dark chocolate and coffee dominate the flavors.  Thick on the palate with a dry, bitter finish.

Black pour dark very dark creamy tan head aroma of chocolate vanilla and roasted malts ..... tons of chocolate in flavor like a liquid chocolate bar roasted malts vanilla and oats lacing little bitter finish in the finish a chocolate lovers beer for sure

Poured pitch black with a foamy tan head. Large chocolate aroma with hints of vanilla and roasted malt. The taste is big on chocolate (obviously) with hints of vanilla and hops. The palatte is thick and oily...a delicious liquid dinner.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2010 pours pitch black with large, foamy tan head.  Huge chocolate aroma and other roasty notes. Taste of burnt chocolate, roasted malts, a bit of coffee. Finishes fairly bitter. Creamy mouthfeel. Good, but maybe a bit overrated.

Had on tap on two occasions recently in Portland at two different Rogue bars.  A nice foamy head.  Overpowering chocolate and vanilla that "punches" your nose.  Too overpowering for the less powerful body and taste that is nice and creamy.  Even as a chocolate lover, this was too powerful to enjoy the whole pint.

Denne amerikanske herligheten har en knall svart farge, du kan kanskje ane en dyp dyp bruntone om du holder glasset opp mot lyset. Kraftig smak, det er nesten som å drikke ren sjokolade med en liten aning tørr bitter ettersmak.
Yummy chocolate beer! Is that a bit of hazelnut? Probably not. Lovely chocolate flavor that lingers, delicious aroma, pleasant palate.
Pours black with a very thick brown head.  Nice lacing on the head.  Aroma is very sweet and chocolaty.  Tast is the same chocolate and toasted malt.  Excellent beer.

A: Deep black brew with a nice espresso type head. 

S: Chocolate, Chocolate, and more Chocolate did I order a Swiss Miss, pass the Marshmellow please. 

T: Boy does the Chocolate stand front and center here, at this point I am begging for the marshmellows. So much chocolate with a great background of malt and a hint of hop. 

M: average body for a stout. 

D: It goes down as good as it tastes. Due to the overpowering chocolate one pint or bomber is enough for me.

From the tap. Deep brown, almost black in appearance. Slight, tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Taste had some initial hop bite, while coffee and chocolate dominated the palate. Go for this one if you like a chocolate stout with hop bite.

Bomber. Deep dark brown with a quickly dissipating off white head . Smells chocolaty & with some roasted notes as well. Mouth feel is medium and goes down smooth. Taste is extremely chocolatly. of the bittersweet variety. Decent hop kick in the aftertaste which melds beautifully with the malty backbone. Even better as it started to attain room temp. No signs of cloying, but I still think one 22ozr is enough for a night. Delicious.

Pours a deep, dark brown.  Aroma of chocolate.  Taste is of chocolate.  Would like to taste the beer without the natural chocolate flavor added.  Tastes a bit like hersheys chocolate syrup.  It is a sweet stout, so that was taken into account upon rating.

Well now, here is a special beer.  In my opinion one of the best, if not the best, chocolate stouts.  Velvety, smooth and sweet.  I wish it was a little bit thicker/creamier but its very good nonetheless.
Creamy, smooth chocolate and nutty taste. Deep chocolate aroma and pitch black appearance. Overall, one of the best sweet stouts Ive ever encountered. Just what one expects from Rogue.

A very nice chocolate stout. Pours dark with lots of thick head. Taste is mild with dark chocolate notes. Hopped to perfection, not overpowering at all but enough to cut through the malt. Lingering chocolate aftertaste makes you want more.

Big chocolate flavors come out in the aroma -- smell sweeter than they actually taste. Pours deep, dark brown -- almost black -- with a brown head. Clings to the side of the glass for a while. Bittersweet chocolate flavors, quite sweet but nicely balanced with citrus hops. Not too big, goes down easy. Could maybe be a tad sweeter, but it has charm the way it is.

for some reason, i always imagined this beer to be some thick, creamy, sweet thing. really, it was bitter, medium body. reminds me of the youngs DC, but maybe a little hoppier. definitely let this one warm up before drinking.. it was ok, but now that ive had it i wont be seeking it out again.

22oz Bomber / Ive enjoyed this beer many times before and will enjoy many times in the future.   The bittersweet balance of malts, hops, and chocolate are about as good as it gets.  Really, this treat never gets old.

On tap at Pizzeria Paradiso. Pours a deep brown with ruby highlights. A massive rocky, dark tan head leaves big lacing. Aroma is intense artesian dark chocolate with milk chocolate ganache. Taste is bitter chocolate with a big hop presence balancing. Bitter, quick finish. Very good.

Bottle. Poured black with a thick brown head. Aroma had notes of chocolate as well as an underlying coffee aroma. Flavor was dominated by chocolate notes with a bit of a bitter but towards the finish.

Pours black. Actually, it appears to be such a deep dark brown that light will not penetrate it. Three-finger head of dense light brown colored foam. Excellent retention and massive lacing. Probably some of the best lacing that Ive ever seen, at this point.

The chocolate really stands out, in this one. It brings a big toasted maltiness with it. Nice roasted coffee notes. Hints of vanilla and caramel. A little bit of smoke. 

The chocolate is still big hare, like in the nose. The coffee stands up next to it, though, to give it some balance. Big roasted malts. Not much hop presence, at all. Just a touch of vanilla cream.

Good medium body, here. Not quite full. Just a touch too waterey, for me. Would like it to be a touch creamier.

Very tasty brew, all-in-all. Nice stout with some good chocolate flavor. Very drinkable. Would be good for a cool night.
With the economical pricing of Rogue beers, this would be a great one to have on hand, most of the time.

Pitch black with a surprisingly big, brown head that settles into great looking lacings.

The aromas is basically just of sweet chocolate mixed with distinct yet not overly powerful roasted malts. Some chocolate syrup, chocolate powder and a faint milky note. Not bad, but certainly not very complex.

Very distinct flavor of sweet chocolate from start to finish. The chocolate flavors arent that luxurious though, they taste more like cheep dark chocolate, milk chocolate and chocolate syrup. Some dark toffee. Just a hint of dark fruits (plums?). Plenty of roasted malts, not very powerful though and they certainly are overshadowed by the chocolate. In the finish coffee flavors make a fairly good attempt at balancing the sweet chocolate flavors and gives the beer somewhat of a mochaccino edge to it. Some very gentle chocolate bitterness and mild grassy hops in the finish as well, and of course more chocolate. Unfortunately, the finish came out a bit short and boring to me, nothing really takes the lead and the taste just fades away too quickly.

Medium body, actually thinner than I had expected. Quite a lot of carbonation. However, it seems like some time in the snifter serves this one well since it gets a little rounder and and the mouthfeel gets somewhat smoother after a while.

A good beer, but I dont think it managed to live up to my expectations. Indeed, there is a lot of sweet chocolate flavors going on here and thats the way it should be, but it would have been nice with a little more complexity and a bigger body. Still recommended, though.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
Similar to the Rogue Shakespeare stout only with more pronounced chocolate flavors.  This was very enjoyable.
Pours deep brown/black. Nose is loads of chocolate, sweet malts and roasted malt. Flavor is big roast, light smoke, cocoa powder and sweet molasses.

See, I was planning on doing a proper rating for this beer, but I poured it and drank it all before I had a chance to give it justice.  Anyways, its very very good, this is a beer that you should never turn down.

The appearance is a black colour with a creamy dark tan head.Has an aroma of chocolate and roasted coffee.flavor is of dark chocolate and notes of roasted coffee with a hop bite.Got the finish of a chocolate kickback and a bitter aftertaste that goes away in a few seconds.A fine stout overall.
On tap at the Alibi Room. Pours black - extremely thick body of coffee, chocolate and malt, slight bitterness. Fantastic stout.

22 oz bottle. Pours black, black, black with a thick, thick, thick dark tan rocky head. Nice lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee, chocolate, malt.  Bitterness lingers on the back of the tongue. Chocolate isnt as prominent as I was hoping. Tastes pretty bitter for a sweet stout. What a quality beer though.

22oz bottle from some ridiculously priced  store on 9th avenue and 46th!... Pours
close to black with a medium tan head... Aroma of powdered cocoa and milk chocolate... Flavors begin with smooth milk chocolate which were pretty nice but some odd mettalic came forth which really took away from its enjoyability.  Creamy medium mouthfeel

Heavy dark chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Poured a pitch black with a sizable tan head. Good flavors of chocolate, roasted malt, and some coffee. Slight bitterness with a creamy finish. Makes for a good dessert beer.

On tap at Rogue Issaquah and in Portland @ Flanders.

Heavy dark chocolate/cocoa aroma with a sweet almost sinewy and lingering finish.  This is a pretty straightforward beer, its all about the chocolate extract, malty sweetness, paired with a little roasted barley bite.  And more importantly they were able to keep the abv down to just above 6%, some of the other imperial choc stouts are a bit high in abv to really enjoy thoroughly.

The brewpub often serves it a tad on the cold side, I like to let it warm up quite a bit and it becomes more complex conjuring up clouds of anise and licorice.

A fine stout to pair with dessert or your favorite ice cream.  Who wouldnt love a Chocolate Stout shake?  Just dont let the kids in on it.

66cl Bottle at Beer Temple. Dark brown to black colour, beige head. Aroma of chocolate and cocoa. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, light hoppy bitterness besides the chocolate bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied. Maybe one dimensional, but very good and tasty.

Wow, have only had this once before and decided to rate.  Pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is strong chocolate, with a little hint of coffee.  Taste is liquid chocolate, very similar to a tootsie roll or cupcake.  Super sweet beer, but oh so good!

(bottle). Black color. Large tan head. Strong cocoa aroma. Dark chocolate flavor with light bitterness. Long duration. Smooth finish with lasting chocolate flavor. Thin texture. Soft to moderate carbonation. Good lacing.

Bottle. Pours to beige tannish head. Beer is a dark chocolaty color. Hints of coffee as well as a smooth chocolaty flavor. Absolutely palatable while a smooth flavor that is almost like a chocolate mesquite. Great beer. Cannot wait to drink again.
Pours black with a thick dark brown head. Nice aroma of chocolate, sweet coffee.  Flavor is roasted coffee beans, silky oats and a nice cocoa bitter finish. Long aftertaste of dark chocolate.

Fantastic. Had some on tap at Rattle n Hum. Pours a pitch black with beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is intense, various coffee notes such as expresso and mocha, and a nice bitter chocolate backbone. Creamy and filling with a smooth finish. I highly recommend.

Sampled at RnH.  Pour is black with mocha color head atop.  Flavor is heavily dark chocolate/cocoa.. with some espresso roastiness, and a bit lactic.  Rich and bold.  While it does not really compete with Southern Tier Chokolat, it is nicely done.  However, im worried I might get sick of this after a while   3.75
Very black stout with a small head. The chocolate aroma is quite bitter, the finish is greate. Not sweet at all, mostly roasted and malty taste.

Pours a serious black. Completely opaque. Aroma is wonderful. Mellow roasted chocolate, smooth and rich, smells sweet with some oats.  Flavor is very rich, roasted malts and mellow smooth chocolate. Finishes bittersweet with some hops and coffee flavor. Mouthfeel begins creamy, but thins out and becomes watery at the end. Overall though, a very rich and enjoyable beer.

Bottle. Black with a quite large brownish head. A lot of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla in aroma. 

Licorice, coffee and dark chocolate. Fairly sweet and balanced. Fluid seemed rather dry and the body was medium to full. Long and nice aftertaste.

22oz bomber. Pours medium thick black with tan head that dissipates, and a lasting lace. Aroma of chocolate milk. If you did a double blind test with this beer and Nestles chocolate milk, youd probably have some mixed up results. Flavor doesnt show through until the beer has passed down your throat. At that point, it turns into a chocolate bounty, then an aftertaste of dark chocolate and coffee. From Nestles chocolate milk to dark chocolate and espresso, this beer is nice and complex. Goes down super smooth, as it should. Great Rogue beer.

On tap. Large creamy frothy light drown head with excellent lacing that lasted a long time. Aroma is mostly coca and doughy yeast and roasted malt. Initial flavor is coca with weak hops, followed by sweet chocolate finished with coco bitter.

Pours an ebony with a cocoa powder colored head that fades to a spiderweb shaped design in the middle of the glass. Smells like store brand hot cocoa, you know, the kind that just isnt sweet enough...kind of like chocolate water. Also has the smell of oats, berries, and nursing home chocolate pudding. Tastes like cocoa powder and water, oats, barley, and fresh hops. Leaves a bitter filmy after-taste. This is tasty in a "I want to feel poor" kind of way.

This is a very fine example of Chocolate Stout. If I were to give someone their first Chocolate stout, This would be it!
It pours a very nice deep brown color. Very nice tan head. The aroma alone makes you want to jump into this brew for a swim. Let the beer rest for a minute after the pour. et the head reach about one inch of thickness untill you take your first sip. 
Just like the aroma, the first sip leaves you very happy. A clean and well balanced chocolate and coffee undertone, complements the oats and malts so well, it leaves you stareing at the glass and bottle while enjoying it. This is the beer you hope for whenever you try a new chocolate stout. Hope no more and go out to buy this brew!!!

Bottle. Pours pretty much jet black with a decent sized tan head that leaves a lot of lacing. Obviously chocolate is upfront in the aroma with some roasted malt and a little caramel, but surprisingly enough there is a fairly strong presence of floral hops. The flavour also has chocolate upfront but it seems more like bitter dark chocolate than the aroma where it seems sweeter. There is also the roasted malt and a little nuttiness. Overall, with its exceptionally smooth, creamy mouthfeel and a little bitterness, this is a great chocolate stout where everything is balanced just right.
chocolate stout with roasted barley and rolled oats brewed in oregon. good chocolate taste and a bit of a harsh aftertaste but good overall.
Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Dark brown body with tall, malty head. Nice nose of dark chocolate and slight floral notes. Soft start that warms up into a chocfest. Sweet and full-bodied finish.
Bottle from Dr. Jekylls Beer Lab in Pantego.  Baking cocoa aroma.  Dark chocolate and malt flavors.  Big brown head.  Bitter cocoa aftertaste.

Black pour with light brown, rocky head mostly diminishing. Fair lacing. Chocolate and milk aroma, tasting also reveals cocoa beans. Moderate to heavy acidity gives way to sour and long finish. Lively carbonation. Satisfying.

22-oz bottle (Marcellos, Lafayette, LA) - Aroma: chocolate and coffee (malts) Appearance: black color, tan to brown head; Flavor: chocolate, and roasted, and oats (malts), sweet, bitter; Mouthfeel: full bodied, mod carbonation; Overall: awesome chocolate stout which is a very dark, full bodied, roasted, chocolate, malty, bitter beer.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 ~ Purchased this 22 oz bomber from Franks Beverage in Glen Cove, NY. Pours black with a big creamy light brown head. Wow! If you like chocolate (and who doesnt?), this is the beer. The smell is nothing short of amazing. Hints of Rich Belgian chocolate appear almost immediately. This doesnt taste like a beer, this taste like something out of a Hersheys syrup bottle. A slight bitter aftertaste makes its appearance at the end, but who really cares about the hops - my mind is still set on the chocolatey goodness. For the style, and everything this Rogue presentation has to offer, Im glad to see all the positive praise from other members. This beer definitely deserves it. Two words: Simply delicious. ~
22 oz bottle, 2.50$ garage sale at rogue. really dark but not to heavy, pretty good chocolate taste not to burnt tasting a good stout.
Bomber. Dark as night in color with a creamy, rich head. Light chocolate note in aroma. Sharp bitter on the palate at first. Gives way to a light chocolate after flavor.

( 22oz bomber) pours dark choc brown and great lasting bubbles. Nose of chocolate cake, alc, sweet biscuit, absolutely delicious. Taste us very unsweetened chocolate and caramel. Light bitter hop presence, and lingers the same way. If this beer tasted like it smelled it would be phenomenal.

Good but not great. Lots of dark chocolate on the nose and in the mouth. A slight bitterness on the tail. Thin bodied for 6.3%. Could use a bit of fattening up. Othewise good solid drinking. On tap at the Wheatsheaf in Adelaide.
Bottle. Pours murky, deep brown with a tan, thick head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and hints of spice. Rich, full body with a smooth, creamy finish. Great stout.
650ml bottle. Dark roasted chocolate malt beer. Plenty chocolate aroma. Good aftertaste.

A roasted nose of pommac and green olives. The taste is of ashes, chocolate, metal, and fernet. Finish is bitter, smokey and dusty. This one hasnt benefited from the months in Gunnars cabinet, Id wager. Maybe i should rerate it, if I get around to do it.

Bottle. Pours deep mahogney, with a generous creamy tan head. Smells like fresh chocolate,dark and slightly sweet.
Taste of dark chocolate, roasted malts and light hops, long aftertaste.
Flavor of chocolate and hints of dust. Apperance is dark black with small brune head. Flavor of chocolate with hints of dust and bitter taste. Overall not as good as I expected.
This beer tastes like a dark hershey bar was melted down and put in the brewing process looks like a guiness in color

650 ml -> pint glass.  Excellent beer.  Pours a deep mahogany; dark like the name implies.  The head is a khaki drab, creamy, and looks like a mocha mousse from the top.  A beauty, indeed.  Smells of powdered Swiss chocolate, caramel, and roasted marshmallows.  Tastes of grain, semi-sweet and bakers chocolates, and hops, which give is a cereal-y, chocolate-y goodness taste thru to the finish, which is a bitter chocolate finish.  Just dry enough to earn the designation as a "stout."  Simply a wonderful beer.

Bottle poured into a trappist glass produced a thick, creamy brown head with a rich, dark-brown body.  To me, the bitterness was balanced well with the sweetness of the chocolate.  Very smooth and creamy.  Not quite as good as Youngs Double Chocolate, but close.

Fantastic rich coffee color with thick tan head, excellent lacing. Sweet chocolate dominates in the aroma, roasted malts, wood and earthy qualities as undertones. The flavor starts with rich dark chocolate, then roasted, earthy qualities, finishing with bitterness that lingers. Mouthfeel is milky smooth ad pleasantly effervescent. An astonishing sweet stout that commands its flavors, enticing the enthusiast to drink on.

22 oz bottle served in a clear pint glass. Pour was opaque with about 2 fingers of dark foamy head.  Slow head dissipation and fantastic lacing are present on this one.  Nose is a delicious, creamy milk chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste is roasted malts and dark chocolate with a lingering bitter sweet for the finish.  I thought this one would be better.  The aroma was my favorite part.

poured dark with a thick foamy head.  strong bitter chocolate aroma with hints of malts and sugar.  thick on the palate with a bitter chocolate aftertaste that lingered on and finished smooth.  it was heavy on the stomach and would of paired nicely with chocoalte ice cream believe it or not.  not a bad brew at all.

Big old bomber courtesy of Cavie which I deftly poured into a big tulip glass.  This chocolate lover is black, but not so black that it doesnt shimmer and sparkle when held up to the light.  This blackness sits underneath some of the best head Ive ever gotten - big, thick, and brown.  The aroma of this puppy has chocolate love written all over it - sweet milk chocolate oozing all over a thick back-end of roasted malt.  The flavor erupts in my mouth with a sour and chocolate explosion of flavor that finishes hard and dry, leaving me panting and asking for more.  The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy but rough and demanding, making me go back for more and more.  Oooh baby, this is some good stuff.

Bottle. Pours black, with a thin dark tan head, no real lacing to speak of. Nose is intense chocolate, mild undercurrents of hops, some roast, but the sweet milk chocolate runs the nose on this beer. Palate is surprisingly bitter, considering the nose, hops come through well, and with time I imagine they would drop out, nice mouthfeel, very chocolaty, some coffee and smoke, very smooth, but never feels thin or light. Nice stout. I cant wait to get some botle age on this one, could be amazing with dessert!

Nice chocolatey cocoa on the nose, with a bitter and chocolate taste.  Well rounded, the chocolate doesnt overpower the stout, although it is very noticeable.  Slightly over-carbonated in my opinion.

Dark pour with a tan head. Aroma is roasted with elements of dark chocolate, smoke, ad coffee. Flavor is of semi-sweet extra dark chocolate with a touch of coffee toffee. In the middle, there is a brief moment of a mouth dry feeling due to the dark chocolate -- like tasting a Lindt bar --, a good palate accomplishment. Finish is completely of dark chocolate.  Smooth with a good balance of chocolate bitterness and sweetness.
Very excited to try this beer and it didnt disappoint. Black thick pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate, smoke, coffee. Chocolate flavor with some coffee and it is very smooth

࿡cl bottle) Coal-black coloured hue with a thick and firm beige foamy head. Sweet and distinctively chocolatey aroma with notes of cacao powder and lighter roast-malty accents in the background. Sweet flavour, medium to full bodied with a smooth carbonation Roast-malty chocolate-like taste; sweet and slightly burnt bitter, quite flavourful and lasting finish with chocolate in the aftertaste. A bit one-dimensional brew but in a superb way ྐྵ.VIII.09).

Bottle: Literally black, big creamy - very stable - yellowish-brownish head; solid aromas of chocolate and/or cacao, accompanied by caramel, toasted malt and a delicate tinge of hops; relatively dry bitter-sweet flavour, medium bodied, quite soft; chocolatey finish with (only) traces of toasted malt and some hops. A very good beer, thats understood, but a bit too chocolatey nevertheless......

awesome sweet chocolate aroma, very nice. taste is of lots of chocolate but very bitter. pours a dark dense brown with a dark khaki head that hangs around the ring for a while. this is one of the first beers that really got me into crafts brews, and probably my fist sought after beer when not available. some batches are better than others, but overall still a very solid offering from rogue. on tap this stuff is amazing and would easily receive a higher score from me.

22 oz bottle. Deep dark brown almost black with a tan thick head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee and roasted grains. The flavor is bitter sweet chocolate with some real dark roast grain and coffee to round it out. Pretty much a full bodied beer with a very mild carbonation and a soft almost thin mouth feel. The chocolate really comes out in this one, both in the flavor and aroma.

Pours black with thick dark brown highlights and a really tall, chunky, cappucino head that has great retention. Aroma is bittersweet chocolate chips, a little roast, caramel and a hint of nutty coffee. Flavor is chocolate syrup (though not syrupy sweet), right away, roast, coffee, toasty grain, nutty toffee, a little hazelnut, milky caramel and some bitter and herbal hops. Finish is milk and dark chocolate truffle, a little roast and a roasty, toffee, bitter hop fade. Palate is medium bodied and suprisingly dry throughout. Really nice brew.

Pours a black with one finger thick mocha head. Turns into a crown with light lacing.

Smell is like Hershey chocolate syrup. Unfortunately thats all there is there.

Taste is very nicely balanced, not overly chocolate like the smell could lead you to believe. Starts off sweet chocolate milk, takes a brief bitter turn, and ends with dark bitter chocolate.

Medium bodied and medium carbonated, nice mouth coating feeling.

Easy and good to drink, would buy again in a second. Very nice.

Bomber bottle served to a Czech-pils glass at Lunar Brewing, Villa Park, IL. Thick and black/brown, with a light brown, frothy head and clingy, foamy ribbons of  lacing. The aroma was strong roasted malt, caramel, and rich, Ghirardelli type semi-sweet chocolate. The flavor was roasty, mocha, pleasantly bitter and dry with not much sweetness,... and I liked it that way.

Had this in the bottle at the French Laundry in Fenton, MI. Well, Ive only had a few offerings from Rogue, and I would say this is the best so far. Huge sweet chocolate nose, with the classic coffee and even some vanilla. The flavor is right up there, with lots of chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Honestly one of the most perfect stouts Ive had in a while. Cheers!!

Bottled 650ml from crackedkettle.com. Appearance: Pitch black, decent-sized bubbly deep beige head which leaves a nice lacework. Aroma: Rather inviting, chocolate accentuated (milk chocolate, Hersheys), faintly hoppy, sweet, powerful with figs, vanilla, walnuts, coconuts, wet wood, maple syrup, marshmallows and oats appearing. Smooth. Subdued roasted malt profile. Flavor and palate: Decent bitterness. Chocolatey. Some nuts sneaking in. Medium bodied. Vanilla, coconut, figs and wet wood showing up. The roasted malt component being most present on the sallow, leaving a dry finish which is reminiscent of Hersheys, coconut and heather. Overall impression: Interesting. Not extremely pleasant though. Inferior to the Youngs Double Chocolate Stout in my opinion which I find similar in structure but a lot more pleasant.

Deep dark chocolate brown. Dark tan head. Brown spiderweb of lace. Head sticks around for a few minutes. Quite good.

A very chocolatey sweetness in the nose, balanced by a lightly toasted malt. Almost like chocolate milk with a heavy malted base. Very sweet and appealing.

Sweet malt flavors, very heavy chocolate in the malt. Roasted but not burnt or bitter. A taste more like liquid chocolate than like a stout. Warmth gives a hint of roasted bitterness.

Creamy and rich feel on the tongue. Milky, with a tiny bite at the swallow. Otherwise, as smooth as it gets. In this beer, chocolate is the name of the game. Sweet (but not saccharine) and very smooth. Quite quite good.

Aroma of dark and cooking choclates with a hint of spice and orange. Big coffee and cream head. More chocolate and dry cocoa flavour, with roast, citrus and caramel, jaffas, and a touch of grassy hop bittereness. A big, tasty dessert beer.

Great beer, much better than their Mocha Porter. Strong chocolate flavor that doesnt get tiresome and a full body. Sessionable stout. Great balance between the bitterness associated with dark chocolate and stouts and sweetness of lighter chocolates. Soft brown head that dissipates quickly so you can get straight to the delicious stout that awaits.

Pours dark dark brown with a pillowy soft, thick and creamy head. A picture in a glass. Lovely rich chocolate aroma, some hints of roasted note - quite inviting. Chocolate and some brunt toast flavourwise, with a velvet smoothness over the palate. Would be awesome teamed up with a rich chocolate dessert.

Poured into a pint glass from a 1pt. 6oz. bottle.

The color is a complete dark black, with a light brown foamy head which sticks to the glass.

The smell is of sweet chocolate. Smells like a chocolate bar of a Hersey kiss.

The taste is very chocolate. Tastes like a Mr. Goodbar, some nutty flavor mixed in with the creamy chocolate.

This is one of the very best stouts I have had. It may be the best stout. It is really easy drinking and very tasty. It also has just enough bitter hops taste to remind you it is a stout. This would make for a very good after dinner beer.
Chocolate nose hits you first.  Nice balance of sweetness and bitterness.  Reminds me of what a weaker cousin to Dark Lord might be.

Nearly opaque with a bit of reddish brown. Big tan head response. Big chocolate smell on the nose. Lots of sweet chocolate upfront, with a lingering dark chocolate bitterness. Roasted coffee grounds appear deep into the finish. Decent but the bitterness lasts a bit too long.

On tap at Coasters.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of smoke and, very faintly, dark chocolate.  Tastes of light citrus hops, dark chocolate, and just a hint of coffee.  Some combination of this becomes less pleasant the more I drink; the hops become noticably more present almost to the point of being a bit sour.  Having had this both in the bottle and on tap I prefer it in the bottle.  A very solid stout all the same especially based on the first few sips.

6/21/2008:  Rogue Chocolate Stout is ebony-colored with a tan head that creates sheet-like lacing on the glass.  The beer smells like dark chocolate and Dutch cocoa.  This beer is quite dry and has some cocoa/unsweetened chocolate and dark chocolate flavor, but it is VERY bitter.  I think there is just too much bittering hops or unsweetened chocolcate.  It has a medium body and is easy to drink, but the bitterness definitely starts to be overwhelming for a chocolate beer.

22 fl. oz. bottle (15° Plato, 69 IBU, 77 AA, 135.45° L) enjoyed during the Grand Banquet at the 2009 American Homebrewers Association Conference in Cincinnati, Ohio.  Rating #1504 for this beer.

On tap at the brewery on 6/28/09. Pours solid black with mocha head, great lacing.  Aroma is certainly dominated by chocolate, but gives way to smoke and coffee.  This is a straight up sweet, smooth, balanced stout with a great chocolate finish, and for the style, its incredible.  Will be looking for this on the east coast.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2009 Bottle. Pours a black color with a light-brown head leaving some lacing. Aroma is rather nice with lots of chocolate/cacao (almost like smelling some newly baked chocolate-cake). Flavour is quite sweet with both dark chocolate, milk chocolate and some fudge/toffee. Palate is a bit thin - light to medium bodied with a bit too much carbonation. Quite good beer, but I hoped for more.

Bomber. Pours dark brown with a big fluffed up tan head. Aroma is strong of cocoa and some oats. Flavors is pretty similar. Pretty malty with a good cocoa flavor, and some roasted malt and oats. As it warms the flavor doesnt really improve, like many stouts. Not to say its bad, though.Alcohol is noticeable, but not distracting. The palate seems almost a bit watered down and not exactly thick like I hoped for, but Its better than a lot of stouts out there.
Pours very dark with a strong chocolate scent. Taste was not however sweet but a tad bitter. Very good blend, an engaging beer!
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2011 Pours black with a small dark mocha head. Nose is chocolate, brown sugar, cocoa & some coffee. Bitter profile and medium bodied.

Opaque pour with a creamy tan head, excellent retention, decent looking lace.  Aroma of dark chocolate, chocolate milk shake, a little espresso. Flavor is sweet chocolate at the beginning and dark chocolate and espresso on the finish.  Creamy, medium-full body with low carbonation, no alcohol burn.  Beer brewed to style but nothing extraordinary.

Bottle.

Pours black with a tan head. 

Smells of drinking chocolate and soy.
Taste of a bit rosted malts and chcolate.

Surprisingly low alcohol and small body but still balanced and a good desert beer.
Bottle. One of the most choclaty beers Ive ever tried. The aroma is incredible choclaty and inviting. The taste is a bit of a dissapointment, nice chhocolate but strange balanced.

Draught at The Local Taphouse, Sydney. Pours very dark brown with a creamy light brown head. Theres no running away from the chocolate that dominates this beer. Its similar to true Belgium chocolate rather than cocoa powder...very nice. Im also getting roasted malt and light coffee. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel and good bitterness. The balance is superb. Delicious, this is my kind of stout.

On tap.  Coffee and choco aroma. Big and black with a thin creamy head. Choco and coffee flavors abound. Bitter, but not as bitter as a an impy stout tho it does appraoch the impact. Not a whole lotta carbonation on the palate. Rather rude overall for a sweet stout. Long bitter coffee and dark choco finish.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: bottle- i have tried many choc. beers this is one of the best very creamy and good choc. notes

A black colored beer, with a thick foamy beige head. The aroma of chocolate with bitter hops. The taste of pure chocolate with dark fruits. And bitterness in the back. The aftertaste is bitter with sweets and still a lot of chocolate.

650ml bottle. Ebony in colour with a creamy tan head that consists of large and small bubbles. Wonderful aroma of chocolate and coffee with a similary wonderful flavour of chocoltae and burnt toffee that swirls around the mouth and leaves a very pleasant aftertaste.

Bottle, 65cl - Dark brown beer with a large disappearing brown head. Aroma is sweet with notes of chocolate, vanilla and roasted malt. Flavor is dominated by bitter chocolate and heavy cream vanilla ice cream. Very enjoyable!

on tap, local taphouse us spectap. nose dominated by exaggerated chocolate essence. pleasant toasty flavours buried under some pretty unsophisticated chocolate essence and spikey high alpha bitterness. fairly light bodied an drinkable though, if you can ignore the chocolate.

Bottle. Pours black with a nice tan head. Chocolate kind of overwhelms aroma, of course. Medium body. Not a lot of depth to the flavor, but lots of the namesake. Overall another good stout from Rogue.
Bottle at Rake. Black with a good tan head. Massive chocolate aroma and flavour, more so than any beer Ive ever tried. Late hops linger on the tonge. Superb!
Bottle. Best chocolate stout(not Imperial stout) I have had yet. But not the best from rogue.

It poured a dark black liquid with a small foam. It smelled sweet with allot of chocolate. The flavor was similar with chocolate and some sweetness. But it was also a bit watery and short, which draws the points down a bit.

Bottle @ home. Almost black and opague. Milk chocolate and cacao in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with blackberries and lots of chocolate. Tasty, but an easy drinker with a roastbitter aftertaste. Nice one!

Big bottle shared with Elisabeth at Henrik Øl og Vinstove. Light brownish head over a dark brown body. Prominent smell of cocoa. Taste of citrus fruits covered by vanilla chocolate. Noticeable hop bitterness to the ending. Easy to drink and likeable (Bergen, 18.06.2009).

Sweet Japanese version? This ezo stuff confuses me... Dissipating fizzy tan head, dark brown body. Nose of vanilla, oreo, and hints of dark rum. Light chocolate, sweet oats and vinous hops are the dominant tastes. Palate is a bit light and plkayful for the style. Quite good.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Oslo. Big tan head. Dark brown to near black body. Powdery cocoa, milk-chocolate and roasted dark malts on the nose. Taste is bitter-sweet and entirely dominated by chocolate. Some roastedness and faint vanilla tones is noticeable. Smooth in the mouth. Medium body strenght. Light bitter choco finish.

Nice dark brown, close to black look with a big creamy brown head, looks way more inviting than the awfull bottle. Aroma is sweet and slightly roasted of chocolate, milk chocolate and pure cocoa powder. Flavour is very chocolate based, sweet but with a balaced somewhat dry, bitter and roasted finish. Medium full body, fairly smooth exept for some a bit too sticky carbonation. Adds to the drinkability tough wich the beer really needs.

Pours very dark brown with a creamy frothy persistant dark tan head.  Smells of dark chocolate, milk chocolate, and some vanilla.  Tastes rich and creamy with chocolate.  Some hints of vanilla, slightly roasted coffee, and a tiny hop spice.  Excellent brew.

Bomber. Dark brown color, medium tan head with good staying power. Chocolate and latte nose. The flavor has some coffee notes but is mostly bitter chocolate. Not silky smooth, and a little long in the finish, but a really nice chocolate stout all the same. Id consider getting it again, but there are better options of similar styles for this price.

deep brown, small cappuccino head, leaves a bit of lacing.  Aroma is nearly all chocolate.  Nice mouthfeel.  Tastes of dark chocolate and a hint of spice, and is balanced with a bitter finish.  My only complaint is that the bitterness lingers a bit too long

On tap at Ice House Pub in Punta Gorda. Pours out in a very dark black creamy liquid. Aroma of full on chocolates, coffee, pure malts with a silght hint of hop. Flavor is of pure chocolates, malts and some hops. Some great beer, find it and drink it!

Bottle. Poured dark brown with a thick chocolate colored head. Aroma was somewhat hoppy-salty, chocolate milk, cream, and very sweet overall. Flavor was similarly over-sweet chocolate milk, cocoa powder, cream, hint of vanilla, but then excessively hopped which produced a strange salt water taffy flavor. Palate was actually somewhat light but produced a good amount of lacing. Not great on its own but pretty good with a cigar.

1 pt. 6 fl. oz. bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Black colour, huge brown head. Sweetish aroma with strong notes of chocolate / cocoa, also notes of vanilla. Silky mouthfeel. The flavour is moderately sweet, again with dominant notes of chocolate / cocoa and vanilla, but also a distinct hoppy bitterness in the finish and aftertaste. Not bad at all.

This stuff pours black very black with some dark brown showing around the edges of my mug, there was a good inch of dark brown big bubble head that did last almost to the end of my glass. The smell of this stuff is almost pure bakers chocolate, with maybe some bitter coffee, and I think I can smell some hops witch is giving this brew a soapy aroma. On my first sip the first thing that came to mind was "mmmmmm........Easter Bunny" very chocolatey flavor that leaves a very bitter after taste, but then I can also taste hops, I hate hops in a stout it ruins the taste for me dont get me wrong I like beers with a ton of hops in them just not in stouts and porters. This was a O.K. beer but in my opinion it dosnt live up to its legend, maybe take out the hops and then this would be a beer I would love
Bottle at McRaneys.  Aroma is...you guessed it..  chocolate.  Very bitter dark chocolate is really nice.  Nice dark malts as well.

The aroma of this beer makes me salivate. Strong warm chocolate rules in beer! This has enough of that. Fresh smelling too. The only negative is that it has a slight powdery smell and could be more complex. Other slights: alcohol, malt and the hops. Something in there makes me think of port. Youd have to say that this brew is black. Its got a good chocolate milk cap - poured pretty good, but its dropped to a thin line....one that wont go away. Ok lacing, but its spotty. Taste needs to have way more chocolate. Very bitter chocolate flavour (that bakers stuff that youd get all exited about when you were young - until you took that first big bite), maybe a slight coffee touch (maybe) and too many hops. The hops do well in this beer - soft, background, but what exists is still too bitter for me in this type of beer (barely... after another one of these Im sure Ill take that back). I like the chocolate bitter and hop bitter is good, but a soft bitter. Pretty straight forward flavour. Mouthfeel is smooth, tasty (malts and hops leave traces) and has a bitterness that is quiet. Concidering Cascade hops have been used, they have been controlled well. Good beer. Still doesnt defeat the mighty Youngs.

This poured a beautiful dark color, and has a pleasant chocolate smell to it. The chocolate taste wasnt strong in the beer, it fit perfectly. This wasnt bitter, and not too sweet, it was a very drinkable stout.

Bottle  Pours a nice black with a lasting tan head.  The head is creamy and lasting.  Produces decent lacing.  Has a good aroma of chocolate.  Smells like a tootsie roll.  It is cool.  Has a good carbonation.  A wonderful outhfeel.  The flavor is robustly chocolate.  Well balanced and fresh.  Has a thicker body.  A real good finish and a nice aftertaste.  This is a sweet drinking beer.  Maybe not for everyone but very good. I like it a lot.

Poured a really nice black color with just the slightest cola highlights when held up to a strong light.  Nice brown head.  Aroma was chocolate, malt, some coffee notes.  Flavor was very forward on the chocolate, but the other more subtle coffee and malt notes played well together and really made this beer something special.  The oat addition was present in a very silky but full mouthfeel.  Nice beer.
bad stout. doesnt really taste like chocolate at all. Im not happy about having to even finish this bottle up. ugh rogue loses more and more of my respect with every beer i try

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a thick tan head.  Nose is milk chocolate, coconut, vanilla and mild coffee.  Medium body with sharp foamy carb.  Taste is dark roast and bittersweet chocolate layered on a caramel base.  Finishes dry with grapefruit peel.

Compared to Youngs Double Chocolate and Southern Tiers Chocolate Stout, I think Rogue is mediocre at best.  I havent been a fan of number of this Brewerys beer but thought I would give them another chance, but again I was disappointed.  Maybe it is just me; I know they are a well respected brewery.

chocolate color with cappucione head. intenese chocolate aroma, smells like a freshly baked brownie. the flavour looses a bit of the choc but blend nicely with layers of caramel and malt. slight lingering bitterness but I think its far from the 69 IBUs that it claims to be on the bottle. body is kinda thin, but i think it could be cloying if there was much more sweetness. tasty for sure!
650 ML bottle.  Smokey, dark chocolate followed by a bitter finish.  Well crafted, but not my favorite.

Black with a dense tan head. The aroma is super chocolate powered; leaning a little toward the dark side, but still milky and creamy. The flavor takes that and adds in a roasted bitterness that doesnt completely blend, but works out alright. The body is a little thin, but pretty smooth. This is a really nice smelling beer, with a pretty good flavor to back it up, but the chocolate and roasted malt dont seem to gel as well as they could

Draft.  Black with a tan head.  Dark Chocolate and bakers chocolate with light marshmallow the aroma is out of this world.  Still the body is thin and the flavor doesnt retain the aroma its more like a light roast y coffee and light milk chocolate.

Pour was a dark brown with a nice brown head.

Smell, chocolate.... ...never could have seen that coming.

Taste, good god love a duck. Rogue did something very different, I was expecting the standard toasty dark chocolate flavors, but this was different. Very creamy and milk on the beginning, but finished of a very expensive dark chocolate. This beer is just packed with chocolate, but you can really taste the quality of ingredients.

Bottle. Pours black, small brown head. Aroma is sweet milk chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, some powdery or ashy sensation. The same notes return in the flavour along with more roastedness, coffee and ash. Nicely balanced by a hop finish. Wierdly enough, its quite thin. Makes it more drinkable, though.

Dark black pour with a brown head. Chocolate aroma with some sweetness and roasted malt aromas. Chocolate taste hits you first, then cocoa, some dryness, than, of course, a dry, chocolate mouthfeel. Nicely balanced. Nothing overtaking the other. An easy to drink beer-goes down smoothly.

22 oz Bottle. Pours ebony with a fluffy copious brown head. Big aromas of chocolate with hints of hops and vanilla. Upfront flavor of chocolate thats layered into some hops with a hint of barely and a pinch of vanilla. Bitter and a little sweetness detectable. Was hoping for more depth, sweetness, and thickness, but it is still very enjoyable. Good all around.
Ginormous brown head over a black body. Aroma of strong chocolate, light hops, chocolate and more chocolate. Flavor is nicely chocolate, with some hops. Creamy mothfeel. a nice chocolate stout.
Bottle @ BA Järntorget. Perfumy and fruity, somewhat artificial chocolate aroma. Soft and creamy mouthfeel with hints of raspberries. Dry and somewhat astringent finish of bitter chocolate.

Bottle from Bevmo... Pours black with light brown head.. Smell is chocolate and kinda woody.. Taste was pretty bitter with some chocolate and woody notes... There was a huge amount of carbonation and it wasnt sweet at all so Im wondering if I got a "bad" bottle.. Also there was a bunch of gunk under the bottle cap, not sure if thats how this beer usually is.

Pours a dark brown, nice tan head head.

Aroma is of hops and malt

Bitter sweet taste of hops and chocolate.

Bottle. Pours with a huge, dark brown, creamy head and a near black body. Good lace. Aroma is sweet with chocolate, chocolate truffle, cocoa powder, oats, and nearly a berry liquor thing going on. Taste is cocoa, roast, smokey, leather, soil and chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, light carbonation.

Very dark with an off white head. Aroma is roasty with dark chocolate and a touch of coffee and cream. Taste is similar and pretty good. Overall it is nice and drinkable with simple sweet chocolate flavors and a touch of roasty malts.
bottle.  very tasty sweet stout.  excellent chocolate malts i very much enjoyed this stout and all rogue beers

22oz bottle. Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma is of caramel, chocolate, grain, syrup, malt, and dark fruit. Taste obviously has lots of chocolate. Lots of dark fruit especially rasins, with caramel, grainy malt, syrup, and some wood. Lingering chocolate and caramel taste. Mouthfeel is very sticky, but drinks easy with the carbonation. Finish is all bitter chocolate. Avery tasty beer, without being a chocolate mess.
Bottle shared with Steve.  Amazing choc stout.  Dark almost black pour.  Sweet choc coffee nose.  Flavors of choc syrup and hints of espresso.  Finish of a little bit of malt.

pours black with medium tan head. aroma is bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and rich malt. drinks bitter chocolate and coffee up front, and finishes with sweet malts and chocolate. long lingering chocolate/coffee after taste.

22oz bottle. Pours black with a large brown head. Aroma is sweet milk chocolate. The flavor is not as sweet; more like bittersweet chocolate, with notes of roasted malts, vanilla, oats, and coffee. A little thin and watery on the palate, but very easy to drink. A good one to share for dessert.

Chocolate is immediately apparent in the aroma.  Pours jet black with a strong black head that lingers and leaves a beautiful lacing up the glass.  Flavor is a nice mixture of malt, chocolate and hops with dark chocolate lingering in the finish.
This needs to be in 6s. Poured black with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate. Sweet chocolate flavor.

Pours a serious black. Completely opaque. Aroma is wonderful. Mellow roasted chocolate, smooth and rich, smells sweet with some oats. I got lost in just smelling the beer...amazing. Flavor is very rich, roasted malts and mellow smooth chocolate. Finishes bittersweet with some hops and coffee flavor. Mouthfeel begins creamy, but thins out and becomes watery at the end, which is the only complaint. Overall though, a very rich and enjoyable beer.

by far the best chocolate stout out there.. pours thick black creamy huge head.. smell is so awasome chocolate candy bar.. taste is so malty, chocolate cake. overall just a great beer to drink after supper for dessert
Draft pour is black with an oily brown head that forms peaks. Aroma is milk chocolate and some bitter. Excellent chocolate creamy taste then the dark chocolate bitterness.
poured dark with cream colored head.  smells of chocolate tastes of choc. coffee very good beer

bottle 22oz: Pours black with a thin dark brown head.  Smells of bitter cocoa and roasted malts.  Tastes of bitter chocolate and roasted malt with a bitter chocolate coffee lingering ending.  A little thin as far as mouth feel and alcohol could be up a percent or two and this would be perfect.
sweet. choclately.  bottle at the hopleaf.   good beer.  would get again.

Wow. 

There isnt much in the world I enjoy more than a Rogue Chocolate Stout after a hearty meal on a cold Oregon night. One of my favorites - the best way to describe it is a beer and chocolate milkshake.

For best results, let it warm up a bit before drinking to really bring out the chocolate.

im a fan of the darker beers. and of the choc. stouts. and WOW is all i gotta say about this one. if u like stouts. try this. smelled very roasty and dark like most stouts. looked very dark with a dark brown head that stayed almost the whole time. tasted of chocolate chocolate CHOCOLATE. but well balenced with the after bitterness. also tasted roasted malts and a bit of espresso. overall nice beer goes well with a burger or steak or by itself as a dessert. my first rouge beer cant wait to dip into some more. HATS OFF!

Bottle.  Poured black with a thin brown head.  Aroma is of malt and chocolate.  Body is medium, lots of carbonation.  The flavor is some roasted malt, hints of coffee, and overpowering bitter chocolate.  The chocolate is a bit too heavy for my taste.

Wow, this was great from 1st to last drop.  Poured a deep dark coffee color with a thick tan head and nice lacing. Aroma of chocolate, malt and coffee. Flavor is heavy on chocolate, with roasted malt notes. Full bodied, bitter sweet finish.

Bottled. Poured black with a tanish head that stayed thin. aromas of bitter chocolate, milk or cream, some hops, and roasted malt. I didnt get too much chocolate coming through on the palate which threw me off. It seemed to need some time for the real flavors to come through. Was more bitter with some hop flavors, than chocolatie and smooth. Still good, and hoping the one i have been aging will be better.

This beer is great.  Aroma is of roasted malt and chocolate.  Pours black with a creamy beige head.  Tastes of chocolate (what a surprise) and nice maltiness.  Creamy smooth mouthfeel with a great natural chocolate flavor.
Pour dark, very strong chocolate flavor present that has a nice bitter finish.  Really nice after dinner brew.  Excellent choice well worth trying

Pours dark brown to almost black color.  Smells like chocolate and the overwhelming taste is chocolate.  Finish is thick, almost chewy.  Beer goes from sweet chocolate to very bitter finish.  Makes you feel like you are drinking dark/bittersweet chocolate.
It had a good chocolate smell, with a strong smokey aftertaste.  The strong carbonation complimented the strong hops.

Bottle. Poured black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malts and hops. Sweet chocolate is the first thing you taste, then the hops bite at the finish. Has a creamy mouth feel with biting carbonation. Overall a good beer.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours an inky brownish black with a fine mocha colored head.  The head leaves behind nice lacing.  True to its name, chocolate is the first thing that hits the nose.  It reminds me of Hersheys syrup.  A little coffee in the background, but it is virtually impossible to get past the chocolate.  Is this a beer or a chocolate milkshake?  Very fine carbonation and a rich mouthfeel like, well, chocolate milk!  Aggressive bitterness helps offset the high level of sweetness.  Sweet malt and chocolate notes.  A little bit of dryness, a little bit chewy.  Mild bitterness and chocolate notes linger in the mouth.  Definitely something different in the world of stouts, but a little one dimensional in my mind.

Pour was stout black with a nice thick, creamy, light brown head that lasted and lasted.  Aroma was chocolatey surely enough, but I somehow found a lot of hops in there which was a turn off for me.  As it warms up from being out of the fridge it obviously gets better and better as the chocolate starts dominating.  Flavor was mostly chocolate and oats with those nice Cascade hops at the end along with a bitterness maybe from the hops or the roasted malts.  A light watery feel in the mouth with a little sting from the carbonation.  Overall  it was different from, though not as good as Youngs Double Chocolate Stout in my opinion.
Pours pitch black with a tan head. At first, the stout overwlems the chocalate, then the chocolate comes back a little. I do taste some coffee notes, and some malt.

Black with a thick, creamy tan/brown head. Lovely aroma of chocolate, chocolate and more chocolate. Easily one of the best smelling beers Ive ever had. Carbonation is a little too lively and fizzy. With that said, this-is-awesome! Roasted chocolate malt flavor bounces around the mouth with a creamy feel. Finishes strong with a lingering dark chocolate bite. All around great stout. Phenomenal beer overall.

On tap at the Golden Rail.  Pours a viscous jet black with a medium tan head.  The chocolate up front is almost overpowering.  Smells like a warm Hershey bar.  But behind it, there is a hint of roasted malt. Body could be a touch thicker, but its pretty solid and overall reminds me of a chocolate milkshake made with stout instead. Finishes with a gentle bitterness reminiscent of bakers chocolate and roasted malt.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2009 Bottle. Tre Små Rum. Gothenburg. Black colour with a pale brown head. Aroma of mostly chocolate, but also some roastiness. The taste is also very chocolately, lighter notes of roastiness, malt, black berries, milk and sourishness.

Moderate chocolate and malt aroma. Black color with a medium thick brown head. Mildly sweet in the beginning with the finish getting increasingly bitter but not getting strong. Palate a little like for what I would like.

These guys know how to brew beer..Of all the chocolate stouts I have had, its hard to find a beer with more chocolate presence. the body is typical dark like most stouts, but maybe a hint more thicker. with a creamy thick dark brown head. the aroma is such a delight, i swear if i closed my eyes, I would think i am in a chocolate factory. at first sip, you hit with the chocolate, but not your typical chocolate flavor, it taste like the powdered chocolate you would add to milk. is almost as if they add a scoop of nestle quick powder right to the beer. after you get through tasting the chocolate you get  a nice rich coffee, and nutty finish to round out this nice blended taste to an excellant beer, and goes down smooth to finish it off.

Bomber. Pours a very dark brown with a small tan head that diminishes rather quickly. The aroma is dark cocolate, sweet malt and oak. Decent spotty lacing on the glass. The taste is a sharp hop with roasted chocolate and coffee with a dry finish. Easy to drink, a very good sweet stout from Rogue.

Poured very dark with a very thick brown head. Immediate pleasant aroma of coffee. A few seconds after the first drink you pick up the chocolate on the back of your palate. There is a small hint of bitterness that is complimented by the sweetness of the chocolate flavor.

Bomber from Evanston, Wyoming. Pours a very dark color with a thick brown head. The aroma is milky chocolates, lots of toasted coffee and light hops. The taste is very nice; initial hops and fresh milky flavors, some roasted chocolate, dry and rich coffee also, especially in the finish. A nice full mouthfeel. Very drinkable and good.

This thick stout poors pitch black with a beige head. In aroma and taste this beer is overtly dominated by dark chocolate. No other flavors vie for attention here. The carbonation is mild and theres not much bitterness. With the reasonable alcohol content you could have a couple pints of this without slurring about how much you love chocoloate. If you are a chocolate fan like I am, youll be hard pressed not to thoroughly enjoy this rich and delicious treat.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma:  chocolate malt Flavor: chocolate with some hoppiness, thin-medium body

Smells of some milk chocolate, some milk and malty sweet. Pours a a dark coco color with a nice off white head. Less than full body with some high carbonation. Goes down dry and somewhat smooth. Flavor was a lot of chocolate and very bitter for me. It was roasty and bitter and I really just did not get into it that much...
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 BOTTLE: pours a very dark brown with thick head, aroma is dark bitter chocolate, taste is roasty, dark chcolocate, bittersweet, slightly carbonated and some dry hop.

Poured from a 650ml bottle into pint glass.
Aroma - Roasty malt, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, bit of perfumy hops.
Appearance - Opaque brown in color. Huge creamy tan head that refuses to budge. Thick lacing on glass.
Flavor - I dont know where to start. Roasty malt with notes of very high end chocolate, and espresso followed by a nicely balanced, slightly floralperfumy hops. Extremely pleasant aftertaste of Belgian chocolate.
Palate - Full, thick and velvety. Lightly carbonated.
Overall -  Everything about this is spot on. Perfect balance of malt, hops and chocolate flavor. What makes it even better is that its very affordable. I paid less that $5.00 for the bottle. Try it!

A- Pours a brown black hue, head is a brown pillowy layer that is mostly sustaining and bouncy, thick lacing on the glass
S- Nose is big roasted chocolate and coffee malts, strong backbone of subtle hops and alcohol, there is a something a little off at the end but I cant place it
T- Initial taste is moderate roasted coffee malts, which quickly transitions to sweet milk chocolate which pervades the flavor, touch of smoke and roast in the bittersweet finish
M- Full-bodied, thick and chewy texture, ample carbonation
D- Well-balanced and smoothly sweet stout, i would have preferred a little less coffee so that the chocolate could have come through a bit more, easy-drinking at 6%

Bomber.  Smoky, jet black with a brown head. Aroma is lots of chocolate with some roasted malt.  Major chocolate taste, good but probably could have been mixed in better with the malt. Some mild hoppiness.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Enjoyable as hell.

Draught: Appears to be a dark brownish black color with a thin tan head. Smells of pure chocolate with hint of malts. Tastes of malts and dark chocolates, but leaves the palate like e creamy milk chocolate. In fact, some would think this may not be beer, but a preview of a Valentines Day treat.
I love sweet stouts and this is a good one.  Dark color with creamy head.  Taste of chocolate malt, oats, and nuts.  More hop taste than many sweet stouts.  Very drinkable and highly recommended.

Pours a dark, opaque, chocolaty brown with a thick tan head. Rich aroma is chocolaty and has just a hint of smoke or roast coffee. Flavor is mainly of unsweetened chocolate and has coffee, hoppy and nutty hints; and is slightly bitter. Silky smooth texture leaves a nice aftertaste of unsweet chocolate.

Pours deep black with a couple of fingers of tan head. Aroma is heavenly, like a melted down Hershey bar with some oatmeal, this is how a chocolate stout should smell. Flavor is also excellent, chocolate is the dominant flavor but it is complimented by oats, some hops and burnt coffee on the finish. Nice creamy body, I really enjoyed this, the perfect beer to end the night.

Bottle 65 cl. Pours a pitch black with a small tan head and and a heavy and deeply sweet chocolate-aroma. The taste is at first very sweet chocolate but then a rich, hoppy bitterness comes kicking in and stays for a long time. This is a very enjoyable beer, highly recommended!

outstanding slightly sweet milk chocolate aroma.  pors very black with a creamy light mocha head.  flavor is suprisingly hoppy given the aroma and has a great lingering roasted chocolate thats not overly sweet or complex.  mouthfeel id more medium than the heavy sweet-syrupy chocolate i expected.  very enjoyable.
Excellent creamy and best of the bottled chocolate stouts. Tastes of cocoa and chocolate with a burnt edge on the finish.

Black with a small brown head and good amount of lacings. Smell is chocolate fudge cake. Taste is rich bitter chocolate with hints of coffee and a full bitter medium dry finish. There is a trace of the Rogue Pacman yeast flavor. Mouthfeel is just the right amount of carbonation. Not normally a big stout drinker but this was was like a dessert. I am thinking this would be a fine companion to a chocolate cheese cake.

22oz bottle. Pours a black body with a finger-width, creamy, dark chocolate brown head that dissipates slowly and remains moderately lacy with a nice swirl on the surface. Aroma of dense, dark, chocolate truffle. Very rich chocolate cocoa. A light burnt roast as well as a light bitter backing. Taste is initially a quick sweet, smooth, rich chocolate that quickly moves to a light to moderate bitterness that lasts through the ending. Finishes slightly burnt with a light creamy chocolate touch and a carbonated feel. Palate is medium bodied and a mix between smooth and choppy. Pretty dry in the finish. Overall, the touch of burnt roast is more evident than a hop bitterness and to me is just a tad off. Could use a little more of that initial creamy rich chocolate throughout. However, I still enjoyed this and appreciated the full flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2009 22oz bottle. dark black pour with a big creamy head. big milk chocolate aroma. creamy taste with just enough carbonation, taste of cocoa and chocolate with a burnt edge on the finish. excellent.
wow... real chocoatey smell..pours nice brown ..creamy head.  tastes chocolate, but a lil bitter.  overall one of the best beers Ive  had so far.

On tap at Stone.  YUM.  Smells like dry chocolate milk powder or bakers chocolate. Black brew with tan foam.  Solid ring destroys the glass.  It seriously smells like someone loaded a stout full of Nestles chocolate milk mix.  The overall taste is bitter, after the burst of cocoa recedes.  But the entire flavor of it is mixed with this sweet malty thing going on as well.  As it warms it loses the brightness of the chocolate and the maltiness, and turns more coffee bitter.  Really good if you like this kind of thing.
UPDATED: MAY 2, 2009 Dark brown pour, off-white head, outstanding chocolate, jampacked with coffee and cocoa, hides nothing, finishes a bit dry, encouraging the next drink.
Not a bad chocolate stout, but not among the best such as Youngs. Huge chocolate aroma, but taste gives way to coffee being the most pronounced. Some bitterness, overall a good stout.

Very dark brown with a brown head. Forceful dessert chocolate and cocoa powder aroma. Taste is... well, chocolate. Unfortunately its not the beguiling soft, creamy European chocolate taste, but the cruder, rougher American version. Some dryness at the end. My hands smell of chocolate an hour later, I really do like chocolate, but not as much as this.
Bottle 22oz.: Opaque black stout from Oregon with an bitter start and hints of chocolate.

Pours an opaque black with some red on the edges. Had a large frothy tan/mocha coloured head. Aromas of dark and bitter-sweet chocolate, spice and a little sweetness in there as well. Tastes malty, pretty bitter, a little too bitter for me. Tastes like itter-sweet chocolate, burnt coffee, roasted malt, and coco powder. Trust me, if you want chocolate beer, try Youngs double chocolate.

22oz bottle. Dark black pour with a nice tan head. Very nice chocolate aroma, slight burnt smell in there as well. Creamy, chocolaty mouthfeel, slight bitterness, but very drinkable. Always a favorite.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Poured from the bomber bottle into a standard glass to drink.  The beer poured out a dark, black color with a big foamy-creamy, dark tan head with long-lasting retention and moderate cling.  It had a big chocolate and coffee aroma with a fainter earthy hops tone underneath.  The body was creamy and wet with lower amounts of fizz and carbonation.  A very full, rich mouthfeel with some dryness at the end.  A very good beer, I had not expected such quality when I bought it.

Bomber.  Pours black with a thick well maintained brown head.  Aroma is roasted malts, but there is a sweetness that is very noticeable.  Flavor of course is dominated by chocolate and coffee, but not in a obnoxinous way.  Some roastiness and hints of oast, I was expecting some more based on the aroma.  Mouthfeel is medium, with a slight bitter finish.  Great stout.

Pours thick, dark scarlet-brown, almost completely black and opaque, only a little bit of red around the very bottom edge of the glass, with a thick, one-finger tan head, good lacing.  Smells of coco and espresso.  Medium-thick body, with a crisp edge.  Bitter dark-chocolate flavor, with a tiny bit of coffee, apple, oat, and pine.  Lingering, but mild bitter aftertaste.  Well balanced.

Mmm...tasty. A great after dinner dessert beer. Everything is dark, from the look, smell, and of course the dark chocolate taste. It isn’t too sweet, which is nice. But it isn’t so dry either, that you choke on it. Very rich, slightly smoky. Will buy again.

Black pour with a thin tan head.  Tons of baking chocolate in the aroma.  Thin on the roasted malt.  Tastes are better, lots of bitter chocolate, bitter roasted malt, and a nice finish.  Only seems a bit too thin for a stout with this much flavor.

Very crisp for a stout, the chocolate smell is much stronger than the taste, so you don’t need to worry about a beer molestation. It is fantastic though, smoothly tickling your tongue with roasted dark chocolate flavors. Leaves a slight Java feel in the mouth afterward. Very Nice.

22oz bottle: Pours a black/very dark brown color, Big thick head-tan, good sized bubbles, slowly diminishing, like a good stout should be. Strong aroma of hops, chocolate, nuts, very interesting aroma. Strong chocolate malt taste, semi-bitter taste, overall pretty smooth flavor.

bottle poured a deep brown color with a nice looking thick one finger tan head. aroma has coco powder, chocolate malt, sweet and milky. mouth feel is fairly light for a big beer. flavor has chocolate bitterness, dark baking chocolate, light roast, and bitterness.

22oz bottle from Village Wine and Spirits (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown to black color with a thick and pillowy tan head that settles quickly but provides lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasted sweet malt, milk chocolate, dark ripe fruit, dark chocolate, some ripe dark fruit. Flavor is sweet and creamy with notes of roasted malt, some coffee, toffee, caramel, some ripe dark fruit. Generally medium body with a slightly sweet toffee finish.
Pours dark black with a huge head. Big nose of chocolate and maybe some malt. Flavor is basically chocolate syrup. Very Very sweet. A bit bitter. Its alright, probably couldnt drink it again.
Bottle. Aroma of sweet, tootsie roll chocolate, very mild roasted notes. Flavor quite sweet with the chocolate. Body is mildly but not offensively syrupy. Decent brew.

bomber. dense black color. good looking frothy tan head forms with a tight fine bead.  nose is lush. lots of cocoa powder, a little smoke and and some coffee.  pretty full bodied for a sweet stout. not too sweet though. starts soft with a velvety mouth feel,  plenty of hops provide  more bitterness than expected. chocolate reveals itself briefly on the end of the finish before disappearing. pretty solid overall. one of the better rogue beers.

Good dark body on a well lasting light tan head. Strong aroma of chocolate though not overpowering. Chocolate in the taste, fairly rich, almost full body and long finish. Tried after my homebrew choc stout which was easier to drink but not nearly as enjoyable.
