Bottle.  Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, it reminds me of chocolate-flavored jello.  Flavor is sweet and chocolatey but sort of artificially chocolately.  A pretty good chocolate stout although on the slightly too sweet side.  One dimensional too.  Still, enjoyable.

I like just about everything rogue has to offer but this must be one of their leading sellers.  Pours a rich dark brown boarding on black.  Certainly there is a chocolate tone to the nose but it is matched by some musky earthy notes as well. The taste is well balanced because while people buy this for the chocolate it does not lose any of the other good stout qualities in its maltiness.  Bitter finish that might be from hops or from chocolate, hard to tell. great palate with crisp carbonation.

Dark chocolate and roasted malts with a little tar/smoke aroma.  Large froth light brown head with good lacing.  Mostly lasting head.  Dark black body.  Light sweet initial flavor with a moderately bitter finish.  Medium bodied with a somewhat creamy texture.  Lively carbonation with a lighly alcoholic feel.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2008 very dark brown, nice aroma that does include a nice hint of chocolate.
at first it is very clean actually all the flavor is in the mouthful, and finish.  The chocolate flavor is of the dark variety and fairly subtle.  Mouthful is a nice full flavored stout with a nice sharp coffee flavor that is also somewhat creamy.  The sharp coffee flavor remains well afterwards.

A nice thick black pour with a rich one finger tan head that has good retention.  Thick creamy lacing.   The nose is sweet chocolate with roasted nuts. It stays consistant throughout the 650 mls and 2 full pours.   Flavor is sweet and complex.  It is full of chocolate with coffee.   There is actually quite a lot of hop presence that adds bitterness and tartness.  They blend well with all of the chocolate and roasted notes.  Like the aroma, the flavor stays strong and steady.   Like everything else about this beer the feel is rich and thick, creamy even.  A delightful beer that is deserving of its high percentage rating.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 Draft at Stone (resampled in bottle). Pours a chocolate brown/black. A good amount of bubbles. Loads of chocolate nose. Great chocolate malt flavors. Nice hop hints. Caramel, vanilla hints too. A bit dusty mouth that becomes very creamy. Also effervescent mouth.  Good beer.

Large biege head,very frothy,dark stout,good carbonation.Aroma chocolate,maltiness,cocoa,vanilla.Flavour like rich chocolate you buy,Hop bitters is fair,caramel and vanilla tastes,finish bitter malty,not their best.

Pours pitch black with a creamy tan head.

Smell: holy chocolate! Smells like a chocolatier’s shop with a hint of coffee.

The first taste to hit is a bit of roasted malt, but is immediately followed the the rich and creamy chocolate flavor mixed with a touch of mocha. The mix of these two principle flavors is what makes this truly spectacular. Very well-balanced.

This brew goes down very smooth and creamy. It reminds me of nice creamy Swiss/Italian chocolate. I would say it is a medium-full body...not too full, but still has a lot to it.

I could drink this one until I am stuffed. An excellent brew. This is the best stout that I have had to date without a doubt.

Reviewed on: 03-24-2007

smells of powdered chocolate and cocoa powder - slightly bitter aroma.  black with little light brown head.  no evidence of roasted or coffee in the nose.  smells sweeter as it warms.  Soft velvet-like mouthfeel that starts sweet and finishes bitter like a special dark chocolate.  Would benefit from nitro or more sweetness to balance bitterness from cocoa powder.

Bottle from Jubilation in the 505.  Quite rich flavor.  Not a BA texture or anything, but very competent.  Has that Rogue aroma of tap water and oyster shells, but is generically dark without being ’chocolatey’ or ’coffee-flavored’.  Certainly not explicitly a sweet stout either.  Dry-ish and satisfying.
UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 On tap @ Monster Bs. Want the grownup taste of the cafeteria chocolate milk you loved as a kid? Try Rouge Chocolate Stout.

Draught @ Kahootz - Pours a dk brown with a medium brown head...aroma is toast and malt, bitter coffee and cocoa... flavour follows, certainly not a dry stout, sweet malty stout with bold but not unpleasant chocolate flavour throughout, pleasant bitterness on the back end...not that you’d need to change this for any reason, but I’d love to see it with a bit more alcohol...great for the holidays...
Black beer with brown head. The aroma is sweet of dark chocolate. Flavor chocolate and note of coffee.

This is a gorgeous beer out of the bomber.  Very, very dark brown, not quite black but close.  Pretty brown but relatively quickly disappating head.  The taste of this stout is actually interesting.  I catch major coffee notes barely offset by a detectable hop presence, and very little chocolate.  This beer is also rather thin, particularly for a stout.  Not horrendous, but somewhat disappointing..

This is just like having a little taste of heaven in your mouth. Very sweet but not nauseatingly so, with a nice alcohol background to ground it in reality. I want to drink this thing like it’s chocolate milk!

Pours thick, black, with a brown foam.  This is a beer so dark, light cannot escape its surface.  The aroma is strongly of chocolate milk, with a slight hoppyness.  The flavor is big, like you took a sip of chocolate milk at first, then a light malt, coffee, and hops on the finish.  This is an outstanding beer.

Bouteille de 22 obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Forte odeur de poudre de cacao. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence d’un moyen col beige mousseux et d’une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de chocolat mi-amer avec une pointe de café. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de chocolat amer en arrière goût. (Rating #1985)

deep coffee color, thin tan head, nice lacing.  aroma of chocolate, malt, coffee.  flavor is heavy chocolate, with roasted malt notes.  full bodied, bitter sweet finish.  a miss in my book because of hte sweetness.  as it warms, it tastes like a tootsie roll.

black with a great lasting fluffy dark tan head. great lacing. Rich cream and chocolate heavy mocha aroma. really just a beautiful round mouthwatering aroma. bitter chocolate coffee flavor with a hint of sweet cream. not quite as round or balanced as the aroma but still good. bitter lasting coffee chocolate finish big roasted malt flavor...almost burnt flavor but not quite. full body creamy mouth feel.  very nice. some things like the finish seem a bit off but overall a very nice stout.
Rich in chocoalte very thick.  Great taste coffee, chocolate, light hops, heavy.  Very nice,
POURS NICE AND DARK WITH A CREAMY THICK HEAD. THE CHOCOLATE HOPS AND FLAVOR JUST JUMP OUT AT YOU. VERY VERY GOOD.

For such a dark and impressive looking beer, the one word that leaps to mind, both aroma and taste, is thin.  Very chocolate nose, a light mocha flavor.  I taste a bit of malt, with a definite bitter kick, but I just expect more.  Actually, now that I am drinking in bigger gulps, it is drinkable, just does not match the mood I am in when I open one of these up.

Extreme chocolate!  Definitely not an every day drinker...but I do think it was fairly interesting.  That being said I’ve had several better stouts.  The kind of beer I’ll have every couple of years.  Peace!

hmmm, this score perplexes me.  I was not overly impressed.  Pours dark brown/black, with thick head and nice lacing.  Head is sustained.  Aroma of chocolate malts... didn’t get much more than that.  Flavor is about the same... chocolate, some ash tray.  Kind of thin on the palate.

Great Scotts! Initial reaction to the very present chocolate nose. Delivers on the chocolate with a oaty earthy undertone, which is followed quickly by an amazing dark chocolate bitterness. Great chocolate stout however I felt it was a little heavy on the carnination.
Thanks to Pollo.  Wow, incredible Sweet Stout.Pours pitch black with creamy tan head.  Syrupy, nice bitter chocolate, not too sweet.  Finishes with some nice smokiness.  Very well balanced.

Bottle.  Pours with a large, dense head brown in color.  Body is dark brown with excellent lacing.  Hints of chocolate, roasted toffee, molasses, vanilla, and plum.  Creamy palate with a short duration.  Decent beer but not long lasting.  Serves as a good desert but needs more flavor.

There are certain pleasurable experiences that separately are divine. Put them together and you open yourself to a mind-blowing sensual experience. A delectable stout and chocolate is one of them. A good stout on its own will have varying levels of chocolate notes, so when you add real chocolate to the mix, it gets dangerously close to beervana.

Coming to me today on draft is the Rogue Chocolate Stout. So far, my only other chocolate stout experience has been the Young’s Double Chocolate Stout which is sinfully delicious. My Rogue came to me a dark murky black with hints of burnt earth peeking through along the sides and bottom of my glass. The nose is an immediate immersion in a warm vat of milk chocolate with a hint of cherries in the mix. Chocolate covered cherries, anyone? A dark beer does not necessarily denote a heavy or thick beer, and the Rogue Chocolate Stout is neither too thick nor too heavy. A pleasing medium body and a lightly drying palate leaves no cloying presence, but instead a refreshing and sweet experience. Rich succulent milk and dark chocolate notes mingle together in harmony as a bitter bite nibbles on the top and sides of my tongue after each quaff. Smooth and creamy sweet, she starts and finishes in an enveloping aroma and body of milk chocolate temptation with a hint of espresso.

I really enjoyed the Rogue Milk Chocolate stout more than I thought I would. I didn’t think there were any chocolate stouts out there which could top Young’s but Rogue may be the best contender at the moment.
Thanks to rsamayoa. Bottle:  @ informal ratebeerians gathering, Liked it. sweet but still a beer. smokey malty and earthy; great dessert drink.
Gracias pollo en la casa del gordo esta cerveza esta deliciosa me la tomo cualquier dia con estos buenos amigos. Que rica me gusta es buena

Pours BLACK from the bottle with a thin creamy tan head.  As soon as I opened the bottle I could smell the bitter chocolate, very nice.  I can taste malt, coffee, and of course chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium, creates a weird tingling sensation.  Very bitter finish.  Will try again, very good.

Bomber.  Black pour with a little brown bubbly head. Aroma was bitter dark chocolate.  Mouthfeel was smooth and full bodied.  Flavore was malty, bitter chocolate and roasted oats.  As with most stouts of this nature, the longer it sat, the better it got.  I drank this one too fast.  I will have to buy another and try to nurse it a little longer next time.  Two thums up!

(Bottle).  Sweet milk chocolate aroma.  Black color with nice thick brown head.  Flavor begins exactly as a fine chocolate milkshake, then notes of bitterness shine through, followed by a lengthy bittersweet finish.   Delicious, and fortunately doesn’t overdo it on the sweetness.
Bottle at Nnudds tasting. Black beer with a medium brown head. Lots of chocolate in nose with a pleasant roastyness. Softly carbonated. Flavour is sweet chocolate, some coffee and roasted malts.

Bottle. Very good choc. stout. Resemblance of dark, DARK chocolate, and very chocolately throughout. Roasted and dry; quite bitter. Smells like the tastiest chocolate truffle you could imagine. Well done.
Smoky, nutty, and of course chocolaty.  Thick, malty, and delicious, drinkable. Beautiful dark pour, nice lacing.  I loved this beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a brown head and unidimensional aromas of chocolate.  Flavor is heavy on the West Coast hops (didn’t see that coming).  There is a piney bite o the initial flavors that then transitions to chocolate, but the pine almost comes off as mint... making this taste like a mint/chocolate candy that might get left on your pillow at the hotel.  Seems a bit thin at times.  Finish is pretty creamy and is nice enough... but I’m not really in the mood for this tonight.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Good flavor. Pretty mild and very smooth and drinkable. Not as full bodied as expected, but still full flavored. Nice burnt bitterness to the malt that prevented this beer from becoming too sweet. Nutty roasted aroma. Very light on the chocolate taste.

Amazing stout.

Pours pitch brown with a smallish brown head. Aroma is of dark chocolate and the flavor follows suit.

Agreed, as far as mouthfeel not as creamy as youngs, but amazing profile, amazing chocolate flaver.
A wonderful chocolate stout.  Not quite as creamy as Young’s but has a better bitter profile that balances the sweet chocolate well.
Very sweet stout, smooth and mild. The chocolate malt could be stronger for a better ale.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 Been wanting to try this one for awhile...luckily, Gabe (GMCC2181) sent one my way! Pours a nice black, with a tan and frothy head. Aroma and flavor both have lots of powered, bakers chocolate. Slightly boozy in spots. Also some raw oat and hints of barley. Not as thick as I was expecting, nor as sweet. In fact, this one has a nice bitter quality to it that is rare amongst sweet stouts. I wish there was a little more chocolate to this one, but still a nice change of pace.

22 oz bottle.  Dull aroma of powdered sugar, chocolate cake, not really feeling it.  The pour was fairly attractive though, thick pillowy cocoa cream head, slightly clear/ not thick looking dark dark brown color.  Flavor to me was of a bittersweet chocolate variety and stale malted milk balls with a malt finish of a slightly off-putting sweetness.  The feel of the beer was good though, quite smooth and easy.  I can say most people would not agree with my rating but for what its worth i can see the quality in this beer, it’s just not for me.

pours black with light brown dark creme brulee colored head. smells of rich chocolate, sweet milk, and oats. wow chocolate, but not too sweet at first taste. the finish is sweet however the initial tase would be chocolate and raw oats. high carbonation, way more than I expected.

Dark dark brown, opaque, with a wonderful  thick creamy medium brown head and significant lacing. Strong bittersweet chocolate aromas dominate the nose, but you can find some espresso there as well. Taste is also all chocolate, but not sweet - more like the bitterness of a dark chocolate Wilbur Bud. Roasted malts are also evident, and just a touch of hops to round out the great overall taste. Full body, medium carbonation, and a clean dry aftertaste. I would understand if this is not someone’s ideal specialty beer, but it’s right down my alley, and I love it.

Let’s keep drinkin tonight, Jakebra.  Its like staring into the eye of a duck billed platypus.  Meaning, its dark, might have a beak, and tastes like some beautiful milk of heaven with chocolates, plus beer.

Aroma of semi-sweet milk chocolate (like chocolate milk) with subtle malt. Pours light opaque brown, no head. Flavor begins bitter and watery, finishes with slight sweet chocolate.  Never again, was really disappointed in this one.

Pours dark dark brown with substanital dark tan coloured head. Aromas of dry coco and vanilla dominate. Palate is rich and viscous with hazelnut, chocolate and some dry coffee roast. Caramel/honeycombe malt supports well to make way for a roasty finish.

Quite the tasty chocolate stout! I absolutely loved the aroma and the appearance, and actually admired it while I did work throughout the early afternoon.  Rich chocolate flavor without overdoing it.  Another fine brew.  Rogue we salute you!
Nice chocolate kick off the nose; dense and powerful. Transfers well to taste with stocks of chocolate coming through. Simple and very effective.

22 oz Bomber from Sam’s Wine (South Loop, Chicago, IL). Pours a deep brown, almost black, with very little light coming through with a big bubbly brown coca-cola-esque head that is definitely staying around. Aromas are sweet creamy chocolate with almost a hot chocolate lure. Initial is smooth, a medium bodied brew that slowly slides into chocolate creamy heaven. Finish sneaks in a touch of hoppy bitterness, stout dryness, and roasted malts. Very inviting brew that leaves a very enjoyable aftertaste and could be a wonderful gateway brew to lure people in (While still being a special, remarkable brew on its own). Great stout!
Bottle dark Amber with deep tan head.  You can’t miss the chocolate, but the high level of carbonation kicks in too soonfor a stout. Dissappointing after a good start. Very little Malt
On tap at Henry’s 12th St. in Portland, Oregon.  Fantastic finish, a hearty "dessert" beer that was great on a cool September evening.

I’ve got to admit that as a beer fan, I need to learn to appreciate stouts.  I like them, I just don’t love them like I probably should...until now.  This is a fantastic beer.  The finish literally tastes like chocolate truffles.  Pours an ebony color with a dark caramel head.  Aroma of oak and smoke as is typical with good stouts.  Smooth as can be on the palate and full of flavor with no reprehensible characteristics.  Rogue, welcome to my mouth.

A great beer in concept, but not in reality. The chocolate flavor is definitely there, and then nothing else but malt. Really tastes like a Guinness with some Carnation powdered cocoa mixed in. The body is watery. Still, despite those negative aspects, it is not unpleasant and somewhat enjoyable. In other words decent, but couldve been so much more. Overrated.
Pour is deep brown with light brown frothy head. Aromas of chocolate, malt, and nice coffee. Flavor is upfront with chocolate, coffee, and a nice smooth finish.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Dark brown pour aroma of bittersweet chocolate.  Flavor is toasty, coffee and chocolate.  Simple yet spectacular

This was a big surprise! On tap at Bistro Roca in Blowing Rock, NC (a great little gem of a bar in the mountains). Went great with the chocolate torte and vanilla ice cream I had for dessert. Very dry chocolate, stout and coffee flavors. So clean!

wow....huge roasty chocolate taste. extremly creamy, a dark appearance with a nice one finger thick head.the finish wasn’t long, but not short either just right.i also tasted a hint of coffee. i enjoyed this on the deck with the view of the ocean in ocean city nj, with a bowl of pasta and shrimp in olive oil very nice

22 oz bomber.  Split with some friends into a tulip glass.  Poured a dark black with a huge brown head.  Aroma and flavor are both heavy with chocolate.  Some coffee in the flavor as well.  Great beer.

on Tap @ Tremont Tap House. pours a nice chocolatey black with brown head, taste is as you’d imagine chocolate and velvety smooth.. not as in your face chocolate as Choklat but still a nice dessert beer.
655ml Bottle (The Rake,London) - Black in colour. Chocolatey aroma with roasted malt and some sweetness. Sweet chocolate taste.  A bit artificial perhaps but very tasty.

22 oz bottle.  Ummmm....chocolate!  Pours black with a thick brown head.  Lots of lacing and sheeting on the glass.  Lovely sweet chocolate aroma.  Taste progresses from sweet malt and chocolate to more bitter chocolate, with a nice balance of flavors the whole way.

Never rated but definately had this one. Bottled. Aroma has chocolate and a lot of chocolate Roast and some coffee. Not really complex but high quality. Black coloured beer. Taste is sweet and has chocolate bitterness. Some roast and coffee. Really enjoyable.

bomber from premier gourmet. this bottle was picked out by my wife from the enitire seletion in the store. pours blackish dark brown with a mid sized and lasting tan head. perfect stout appearance. aromas of sweet chocolate that are playful and intriging. the aroma doesnt show a lot of depth but what is there is enjoyable. flavour-wise this stout delivers. big chocolate with sneaky bitterness from the hops. very smooth although a bit to thin. i have to admit that sweet stouts arent really my thing but this one is enjoyable and something id be likely to buy in the future. id love to try it on tap.

Dark brown beer with a brown head. The aroma is dominated by sweet chocolate with some subtle notes of grain. Flavor is at first sweet chocolate then its backed up by some nice american hobs which bitterness is tasted on the tongue but not in the moutharoma. Great beer.

Had this as part of a 4 beer sampler at the Rogue Public House in San Francisco while on vacation.  Opaque brownish black color with a brown head.  Wonderful aromas of dark chocolate and roasted coffee.  Great contrast of flavors that begin sweet and finish quite bitter.

Pours a dark chocolate black with a tan head. Aroma is of caramel, tootsie rolls (for you fellow Yanks) and maple syrup. Wonderful. Heavy body, almost syrupy. Taste is of course, dark chocolate, with coffee, and a surprising smoky thickness.  Dry lingering bitterness from the perfect complement of cascade hops. Excellent stuff. What an American stout should be.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2009 At first, the combination of sweet chocolate and citrusy Cascade hops didnt work for me.  But after a few sips, this one really grew on me.  Excellent bitter-sweet combination. More flavorful and assertively bitter than Youngs Double Chocolate Stout but still very enjoyable.  

Re-rate 8/29/08 = Black with a creamy, lasting tan head; picture perfect.  Sweet chocolate flavor plus a bitter finish of hops, coffee, and roasted malt.  Love  the aroma; sweet milk chocolate and sticky molasses.  Awesome.

What can we say?  We love this stuff.  How can you beat a superb combination of great stout with a dose of dark chocolate?  Rich, dark appearance, seductive nose that exudes chocolate, lush, intense but not heavy....just delicious.
rating is a day after - though I’ve had this a few times before.  bomber.  black w/ large tan head.  aroma is coffee, nutty and toffee.  palate is a bit acidic.  taste is chocolate and burnt malt.

[1259-20080405] 1pt6floz bottle. Sweet super chocolatey syrup roasted malt aroma with hints of alcohol. Dark dark brown black body with a medium-lasting foamy brown head. Roasted mocha flavour has a sweet chocolate syrup finish. Full body is bitter. Wow, so much chocolate and coffee, lovely.
(c/o GG)
My favorite beer from Ellensburg’s Winterhop Brewfest. Poured very dark with a strong scent of chocolate. The beer felt rather thick but the finish was smooth.

Our batch must have been pretty bad. Poured deep brown with a very dark head. Quite dry, this doesn’t seem to be a sweet stout. I didn’t get the chocolate and I didn’t find it smooth. Finished bad. Hmm....

One of my favorite stouts.  The chocolate flavor is very prominent, perhaps a little too much so.  The bitter smokiness is delightful and it goes down mild.  The coffee flavor is well represented.  It is almost like a porter, but not quite.  It’s a beautiful beer with a thin, tan head.  It’s particularities are very prominent, so it is a very particular sort of stout.  I liked it a lot.
bottle, black color, crema head, with light lacing, coffee malted nose, flavor is overwhelmingly chocolate, finishes with bitter cocoa

Bomber.  Pours a motor oil black with 2 finger bubbly tan head and incredible lacing.  Nose is coffee, cocoa and bakers chocolate.  Taste is coffee, burnt malt and bitter dark chocolate with some hop bite finish.  Way more hops and not as chocolaty as I expected, which isnt a bad thing.  Light to medium mouth feel.  Good brew.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Pour was dark with a frothy tan head. Aroma was very sweet chocolate and burnt malt. Flavors was a bit more bitter than sweet with cocoa and notes of caramel and slight hop bitterness towards the finish. Small notes of banana. Good brew. Smooth. Would buy again.

bottle:  thanks for Lord B for this one.  He hit  review on the head! Felt much more like a porter to me with the strong coffee tasting dark flavours.  I got into this one a little too early in the day thinking a chocolate stout would be OK but the strong coffee flavours were almost harsh.  Flavours rounded out & more mellow as it warmed but do prefer Youngs Double Chocolate Stout for sure.  Oregon seems like a beer mecca with Rogue’s quality products - even noticed Williamette malts showing up in Hooky’s Gold.
Black color with a thick creamy tan head. Aromas of rich chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. Flavor is of chocolate, cocoa, a little coffee, and oats. Dry with a semisweet chocolate finish.

650 ml bottle: I was greatly anticipating this one because I love the Rogue Hazlenut Brown Nectar soooo much. At first sip, I found that there was too much coffee flavour in this beer. In fact, at the beginning I thought this should be more appropriately labelled a porter. However, as this beer warmed I begain to appreciate the complexity and rich flavours. I definately noticed the cocoa and chocolate overatures. A solid stout with bold flavours. However, I would still take a Young’s Double Chocolate Stout ahead of this one.

22oz bottle.  Had this any number of times before (one of my first craft beers), yet never got around to rating it.  Pours a dark, chocolate-brown color; medium tan head with good retention and fine-bubbled lacing.  Lots of cocoa, dark chocolate, and lightly toasted malts in the aroma; very dry, intricate chocolatiness with a touch of oatmeal; basic mineral bitterness.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: dark chocolate, dry cocoa, softly roasted and toasted malts; very pleasant, dry presence in the mouth; some vanilla and oatmeal; light mineral bitterness on the perimeter, keeping things balanced; very drinkable, very tasty stuff overall.  Generous without succumbing to heft.  Lengthy finish: very dry overall: bitter dark chocolate, cocoa throughout, toasted malts, oats, and light roastiness.  Excellent.
Black, creamy, smooth, milk chocolate, alcohol, coffee, nutty, dry, slight bitter finish.
Pours a dark ebony with a fluffy tan head. Nose of chocolate and some toasted malt. Taste was bitter, similar to 90% dark chocolate.
Bottle was a little out od date, but it still was rocking enough to make mr try a newer one. I’ll re rate this soon
Good stout but a little dry and thin.  Aroma of chocolate and more chocolate.  Taste is dry bitter dark chocolate.

pours very dark with lasting tan head.  scent is of strong chocolate and roast with some nuttiness as well.  taste is of chocolate burntness and nutty character.  Not too heavy for a stout, but quite tasty.  I would probably purchase this again.

Pour was dark with a frothy tan head.  Aroma was very sweet chocolate and burnt malt.  Flavors was a bit more bitter than sweet with cocoa and notes of caramel and slight hop bitterness towards the finish.  Small notes of banana.  Good brew.  Smooth. Would buy again.

650ml bottle. beatifully simple nose of pure molten milk chocolate. pitch black colour, thick creamy brown head. i can imagine having this one with a dollop of vanilla ice cream :-), amazingly creamy and sweet with a sturdy bitter backbone. this is harmonious bliss. yummy.

22oz bomber. Pours almost black with a nice big thick chocolate head.  Aroma is cocoa.  Chocolate roasted malt flavor with just enough sweetness and bitterness to enhance without detracting.  Very nice brew.  Will buy again.

Bottle at The Rake, 17th May 2008 and a bottle at home the following month. Very dark brown with a line of tan head. Lovely, milky chocolate aroma, then a chocolate sweetness on the tongue, followed the malt flavours and a nice balancing dryness. It avoids being too sweet or too heavy. The alcohol is hidden well and this is a good choccy stout. Yummy.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 1pt. 6fl.oz or 650ml. bottle into a tulip glass. Its very dark brown, almost black in color. The body is quite opaque with a few streams of tiny bubbles that are only visible near the sides of the glass. The head is thick and pillowy with excellent retention. It has a dark tan color and it leaves behind cool tan lace that slowly slides down the sides of the glass. The aroma has a pleasant blend of dark and milk chocolate with doughy sweetbread malt. The flavor has a wonderful balance with a mild, subtle malt base with semi sweet chocolate and some roasted flavors that turns more bitter sweet and dark chocolaty as the hops add a mild bitterness. The palate is smooth and mellow with a medium body that gets thinner and drier in the finish. Carbonation is active yet still smooth. Over all this has an easy drinking character with nicely balanced flavors that work well and complement each other wonderfully.

22oz bomber from Ron’s in Farmington.  Pours an opaque black body with an inch of tan head.  Smells roasty with strong cocoa notes.  Tastes very roasty with some grassy hops and strong cocoa notes, especially toward the finish.   Medium-bodied with moderate carbonation.  A superb stout in every way.  Super tasty with just the right balance of flavors.  A new favorite!

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 (Bottle at a beer tasting in Göteborg on July 4, 2008)Labeled 6% ABVDark brown to black color, brown head. Sweet, cocoa and chocolate scent. Some cardemom as well. Cocoa, cardemom and sweet taste. Dry mouthfeel, low bitterness.8/4/7/3/15=3.7Rerate650 ml (bomber) bottle thanks to deft!Sampled on August 17, 2009Black color, big brown head. Sweet milk chocolate and cocoa scent, faint roasted malt as well, also sugary sweet. A bit thin malty, chocolate, roasted malt taste. Roasted malt, dry, coffee, dark chocolate aftertaste. Moussy mouthfeel, medium dry bitterness.7/4/7/3/13=3.4

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 Looked beautiful pouring into the glass. Nice head on it.Nice chocolate and hop aroma. I couldnt really taste any chocolatey sweetness but what do I know? More of a bitter/dark chocolate taste which I prefer. More of a dry stout rather than a sweet stout to me.The chocolate flavor seems to linger on the tongue. A well made beer in my opinion.
Bottle. Very good chocolate stout with a lingering chocolate flavor. Good balance of hops and chocolate malts.

Sweet, fresh aroma with mild chocolate tones. Deep, dark brown color with medium tan head and good head retention. (Not sure if bottle conditioned.) Full-bodied flavor with very strong, sweet chocolate. However, a very mild off-taste at the very end. Palate lingers and develops. Chocolate comes out more on your palate with time. Overall impression is quite good Not sure how this stands in its BJCP category, but it fits my bill

Bottle, courtesy of yalnikim, my first taste of this famous brewery. Poured a dark brown, but with little head. The nose is like pure melted milk chocolate, though Fritha also detects a touch of jelly. Plenty of milk chocolate in the flavour as well, with just a touch of roast on the palate, making it quite dry. Gets points for being unusual, but I wouldnt choose to drink it again - unlike yalnikims superb Mild from the same night.

Tasted 28/06/2009. 22-ounce bottle from my cellar shared with TheGrandMaster. No notes. Whoa -chocolate Aroma is reminiscent of sweet hot chocolate. A very nice, fairly bitter, sweet stout lurks underneath but the chocolate aroma overwhelms a little and is out of balance. A nice beer with a gimmicky limp, I suppose.

bottle thanks to metzlers in denton, tx. poured a solid black with decent brown head.  aroma was a bittersweet symphany of malt, hops, and chocolate.  flavor was much the same with a hint of coffee.  carbonation seemed to be light.  this was a good one, but not my favorite by them.

What a treat this was! It pours a deep black colour with a large brown head. Aroma is very chocolatey and sweet. Mouthfeel is very full, lightly carbonated and creamy. Taste is very creamy as well- chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and black cherry flavors. I am very happy i finally bought this one, cant wait to have it again:)

The beer pours a deep black with a thick light brown head. The nose is rich a deep smelling of chocolate and light hops. The flavor is great its like drinking hoppy liquid chocolate. The finish is sweet and biter is a nice chocolate flavor. The only down side is that the beer is somewhat watery, I wish it was thicker.

Weirdly enough, this tastes much better cold than warm. Perhaps because its a bit thin for a stout so the carbonation is necessary for a little body. Tastes like chocolate, as it should. Fairly tasty, just not the best.

Draught at The Red in Santa Cruz.   Black with a dense tan head.   The aroma is super chocolate powered; leaning a little toward the dark side, but still milky and creamy.   The flavor takes that and adds in a roasted bitterness that doesnt completely blend, but works out alright.   The body is a little thin, but pretty smooth.   This is a really nice smelling beer, with a pretty good flavor to back it up, but the chocolate and roasted malt dont seem to gel as well as they could.

Opaque black with a thick persistent chocolate mousse looking head,  Nose of chocolate and coffee.  Taste of dark roasted malts and chocolate with just a hint of coffee-like bitterness.  Great, creamy mouth feel.  Finish is like a semi-sweet chocolate bar, again with a hint of coffee.

Aroma was most definitely chocolate.  Head was not as robust as I would have liked, but was an attractive tan color.  I enjoyed the smoothness of the mouthfeel (from the oatmeal used), and the flavor is nicely sweet at the beginning... but needs something to give it a "punch" in the aftertaste. More alcohol, or maybe a hint more hops would make this one more rewarding.
Bomber. Pours dark brown wuth tan head. Aroma is chocalate malt and some oat. Flavor is malty with big flavor of chocolate and a touch of oats. Creamy mouthfeel. Could use some more hops.
A very tasty beer. The chocolate may be a tad overwhelming, but other than that, I have no complaints. Definitely a sipping beer.

A nice looking black beer with small tan head. Nose dominated by the chocolate but with slight roast coffee tones, and overall pleasant. The taste is rather odd, very creamy and strongly chocolate but somehow incomplete. Ok beer, but I was hoping for more.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2008 Bottle pours dark brown with thin brown head. Aroma is chocolate. First taste is sweet then the chocolate takes over. Not much hops, with chocolate finish that does not linger. Good chocolate flavor, nice sipping beer.
Like drinking a chocolate bar. Suitable for dessert, after hours, eating ice cream, and giving to your wife. Not that there is anything wrong with that...

decent overall, definite chocolate both in the aroma and flavor.  Some underlying hoppiness.  Missing something however.  Perhaps if it were thicker in terms of mouthfeel?  Complexity didnt seem to be there for me.  Prefer this to youngs double chocolate in that chocolate in noticeable to my palate throughout the bottle.  Left with chocolate on the finish as well.  In that respect it lives up to its billing as a chocolate stout.  Would buy again but not one that I would climb mountains for.

Draft-New Orleans. Served with ver little head. Bar was dark but this sucker looked pretty dark and opaque. Tasted like someone went crazy with the chocolate syrup. A good sipper but not one for a hot New Orleans day.

Pours dark black, small brown head. Chocolatey aroma. That being said, Im also disappointed with the flavor. Its a lot less flavorful than the aroma leads you to believe. It was also more watery than expected. Decent stout, but underwhelming.

Nearly black pour with a decent head.  Smells of chocolate, molasses, and some alcohol.  Flavor was disappointing however.  The aroma would lead one to believe it had more flavor which I didnt find.  The flavors are very subtle and the consistency is a little watery.  I was kind of disappointed, but it is still a nice stout. Just par though.

Bottle: The aroma is of pure chocolate.  Pours a dark black with a brown head.  It tastes of chocolate and malt with a slight hop undertone.  Its extremely enjoyable for a sweet stout, but not as intense by any means when compared to other stronger imperial stouts.

Poured a great black color, with a dark mocha head. It gave a great aroma of dark, bittersweet chocolate, but not overpowering. Overall, it was extremely smooth and drinkable, and it only got more flavorful as it warmed up.  Will definitely pick up another soon.
A good chocolate stout. There was a good roast and chocolate aroma. The taste starts off bitter, but finishes off with a nice chocolate hint.

Dark brown opaque pour with a thin light tan head.  Chocolate dominates the aroma.  The flavor has more bitter roast and the chocolate starts subtly and builds to dominate the finish.  Very good chocolate beer.  Its much lighter and more easy to drink than many other chocolate stouts.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 Draft @ the Magic City Brewfest.  I had the pleasure of volunteering for the first session and was the designated pourer for this beer  Almost globally it was loved.  Personally its the best stout Ive ever had, right in my flavor spectrum  Dark, mellow, very thick frothy head.  Malty and lightly chocolaty

My new favorite stout. Pours out very thick, almost sludge like, with a thin head and a big sweet aroma. Flavor is all malts, with some chocolate notes, but note really so much that it ruins the experience. Definitely recommended.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a dense chocolate brown head. Aroma is dense chocolate with a strange yet nice fruity note - towards berries. I pick up the same distinct berry note in the flavour too. Nicely roasted malt, bitterhops flavour and smooth yet slight dusty chocolate powderish flavour. Solid bitter and roasted finish. Strange with this distinct berry flavour, yet it is very pleasing.
Ive had better chocolate stouts, but this was very good. Tasty and frothy and thick.

Bottled. Unsurprisingly, the flavour of this smooth, deep brown beer is dominated by chocolate, but thats no bad thing. The warming bitterness of the hops adds delightfully to the effect. I thought this was very good indeed.
Bottle. Thick black colour with brown foamy head. Aroma is chocolate, roast malts, smoky, fruity. Taste is cocoa, sweet, coffee, creamy, rich. Finsh is slightly hoppy. A delightful beer.

Rogue Chocolate Stout is a black ale with a foamy, light brown head that exhibits great retention.  It has a strong roasted chocolate malt aroma.  It is sweet, dark and a bit fruity.  It is smooth and full bodied; soft with a snappy finish.  It is a very full flavor: pretty sweet and quite bitter.  Its like dark chocolate with a touch of citrus.  The flavor is well balanced.  This beer is almost like a liqueur.  Damn.  I can find no fault with this beer.  I think its the best beer Ive ever had.

bottle; black pour with one to two finger head that lasts. aroma is of sweet toasty malt with lots of chocolate, very pleasant. medium body, with good complex sweet and toasty malt with notes of coffee that quickly fade to a lingering bitter-sweet chocolate.

1/12/08 notes:  Rogue is fucking amazing. Had this beer a few days after really enjoying their Shakespeare Stout. I have this considerable thought, but I really feel that this beer tops it.  Features an delicious  dark chocolate aroma and a full bodied, rich, creamy toasted chocolate flavor.  Perfect medium carbonation and smooth hop-roast finish. Touch of molasses at the end adds flavor and balance to this brew.

On draft at the GOBF. Pours a blackish red, very thick and creamy head. Aroma is almost chocolate milk, but more roasted grains start coming out as it warms. Taste is dry, chocolaty, with a hoppy bitterness and lots of the roasted grains. Very solid beer.

Man, I remeber this beer better than I what I tasted today.  Still a solid brew and still the best sweet stout out there but I found the chocolate flavor to be not as prominant as in earlier Rogue choco stouts.  The chocolate flavor and aroma just seems to be toned down from previous tastings.  All things considered still a smooth sweet brew and well balanced.   This will require more research ;)

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2010 Pours nice & dark with a full head that lasts.  The smell of sweet chocolate is immediate and dutifully powerful.  Small notes of roasted coffee can be found among the striking flavor of chocolate truffel on the palate.  The hops finish it to help balance the sweet chocolate.  This is a great stout with terrific chocolate flavor.

V - black with tan fizzy two finger head. fluffy with a bit of lacing. Head doesnt last.
A - rich aroma, deep malts and chocolate with some caramel and oats present as well and maybe a touch of lavender-like fruit
T - malty with a milk chocolate taste
P - just a touch of creaminess but overall a bit thin.
Great chocolate flavor with a nice body and good mouthfeel.  Head retention could be better.

I would put this Rogue beer on top of my favourite chocolate beers. Right along with Lost Coast Chocolate Porter.

The joy began right after opening the bottle. It pours a dark body and thick head that settled rather quickly. 
Full body / chocolate smell is heavily present right after opening and in the glass. It has a nice smell that does not overtake the quality of the beer.
A very enjoyable beer, very smooth, full chocolate body, does not leave any bad aftertaste. A near perfect mix of chocolate malt and barley.

Pours a cocoa colored brown with thin white head.  Aroma dominated by chcolate malts roasted coffee and tostie rolls.  Flavor once again dominated by chocolate and chocolate malts.  Nice roasted character and hops provide a tasty bitter dry finish.  Very Good!

Tap @ Blind Tiger.  Pours a deep reddish-brown to almost black with a tan head.  Aroma is chocolate malt, almost to the point of chocolate milk.  Flavor is sweet milk chocolate up front dissolving into dark chocolate bitterness with coffee and roasted malt notes barely detectable.  A total winner.
Poured a nice black color with a tan head. Aroma is alot of chocolate mainly. Flavor is also alot of chocolate, sweet and dark chocolate with a nice amount of coffee bitterness to keep it in balance

22oz bottle. Pours black with a thick creamy chocolate colored head. Nose is intense chocolate and caramel but with a very rich smell of fine chocolate. Very distinct body with clear cut changes in palate. Starts of with a strong caramel malt note, very smooth, followed by a giant chocolate truffle middle and it finishes with a strong roasty malty bitterness of Mocha Java Coffee. Outstanding. And as stouts go this is an excellent one for beginners, its very sweet with pretty light bitterness yet a complex and well defined palate. Very well made by Rogue.

Pours black, with a very thick creamy head. Rich, sweet, caramelly chocolate aroma that lasts.  Flavour is quite malty, but with a beautiful chocolate-toast finish.  Beer is clean on the palate.  Overall very nice.

Pours like black Texas T.  Jet black in color with a rich and sweet chocolaty aroma.  At first taste is a bit disappointing compared to the expectations that the aroma and pour had presented.   Very heavy beer (64 IBUs).   Expecting more but didnt completely disappoint me.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008 Graduation weekend in Bloomington. Rogue Chocolate Stout is a black beer with a great shaped dark brown head. The aroma is strong and full of chocolate. The flavor is pure chocolate. I can best describe this as drinking a liquid semi-sweet cooking chocolate bar.

nice malty yeasty aroma with hints of coffee, dark pour (very dark) with dark tightly packed foam (similar to Guiness), excellently bittered with a melange of chocolatey flavors and a very pleasant, lingering, sweet chocolate after taste.  I did not know that it was possible to brew this good of a beer and actually use chocolate!
Another extremely dark beer, yellowish brown head...looks and smells delicious. sweet chocolaty aroma. Wow...taste amazing, nice amount of hops. This is a great beer!
Fantastic! Smells like Chocolate and Carmel.  Black color with a decent size brown head.  Leaves nice Lacing.  The 10 different ingredients blend very well.  Great beer.

A- Very dark with an oatmeal yellowish brown head that retains well and leaves some nice lacing.

S- Smells very sweet with hints of Chocolate, rasberries and hops.

T- Begins chocolate with a definate bitter tinge at the end. Also tastes of coffee and is quite acidic.

M- Mouthfeel is a little harsh, very carbonated, lines the inside of the mouth and stays there.

D- This beer is excellent but i couldnt see drinking more than a bomber. Good desert beer to sip on.
Aroma is barley rich malt, cocoa, and chocolate syrup. Black pour, medium lacing head. Pretty neat balanced blend of chocolate syrup, grass, and parsley. Charcoal finish. Balanced and drinkable.

Black with large light brown head. Sweet aroma with loads of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee notes. Sweet flavor dominated by dark bitter chocolate with notes of roasted malt, caramel and coffee. Nice!

At Tux place, 240408
Bottled
Nice head and a cream like palate. Flavor and aroma is bitter chocolate but with a lactic touch
Pours black with a thin brown head. Aroma is chocolate fudge with a hint of coffee. Strong sweet chocolate start with a bittersweet chocolate head. One dimensional but still good.

Poured a dark-dark black. Had the aroma of CHOCOLATE! It made me happy when I first poured this brew because it reminded me of enjoying a nice cup of chocolate milk or hot cocoa. It also had other roasted malt scents. The flavor was great. It tasted chocolaty,malty and you could definitely taste the oats too. It was also sweet. Overall I thought this was a very tasty beer and will probably be buying another in the future.

Heavy malty and dark chocolate aroma. Large, frothy, light brown head. Good lacing. Mostly lasting longevity. Black body. Heavy bitter initial flavor with powerfull chocolate notes and a long finish duration. Medium palate.

Maybe the best all-around chocolate stout Ive had, for my taste. Pours a deep, oily black with developing dark brown head. Nose of sweet, dark chocolate and roasty espresso. Flavor is just lightly sweet, going into a very mild, roasty bitterness with more chocolate and espresso lasting into the long aftertaste. Im happy that the hopping is so restrained, to let the chocolate and malty flavors come through. We paired this last night with a cherry tart, and its hard to imagine a better combo. Big thanks to my sister-in-law and future brother-in-law for sending this across the pond to us.

Pours a very dark fudge brown with a small but full brown head. Aroma of sweet chocolate, coffee, and some oats. Has a nice bittersweet chocolate start with a very roasted finish. Body is creamy but a little thin. The oats come through a little sweet, maybe some more could have thickened this up a bit and filled out the body.

Wow. On tap. Opaque black pour with a monstrous tan head. A few ruby highlights near the bottom. Big chocolate aroma full of roasted malt and oats. Flavor is very rich and chocolaty, with a smoothness I tend to ascribe to oatmeal stouts. Big dark chocolate taste fading into semi-sweet at the finish.  Great body. A wonderful sweet stout.
Bottle. Black Colour with medium creamy light brown mostly lasting head. Aroma and taste is chocolate. Lots of chocolate and then some. Very good sweet stout.

Dark brown almost black in color with a thick tan head. Bitter chocolate and coffee aroma. Taste is bitter roasted malt and a little coffee, but balanced with some malt and sweetness; nice hops too. This is a medium bodied and carbonated beer and actually very drinkable despite the strong flavors. Nice beer.
65 cl bottle, at my «Hopheads» tasting. Black color, brown head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee. Flavor is chocolate, some fruit ans some bitterness in the finish. I could drink this again!
Nose of chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee. Pours a thick black coloured beer. Taste is strongly cocoa, medium bodied.  Hoppy, oaky very mature and balanced. A good beer.

Bottle. Pours almost pitch black with a big grey/brown head. Nice lacing. Aroma is a blend of sweet chocolate and licorice. Okay, but slightly cloying. Flavour is mainly chocolate; tastes like cheap German chocolate  not that good. Actually the chocolate in the aroma has a bit of the same problem. Finish is better; roasted notes and a lingering coffee bitterness. Feels dry. Slight apple notes appear as it warms. An okay beer, but would (probably) be better with a different chocolate profile. 13-04-08.

Bottle. Pours almost completely black with a small light brown head. The nose worships chocolate with bittersweet qualities. Bittersweet chocolate, some milkiness and a good bitter finish. Soft on the tongue and rather full-bodied. Craftmanship!Earlier Rating: 4/6/2008 Total Score: 3.3Bottle. Dark brown, almost black, with a small tan head. Chocolate and cocoa powder nose galore. Overpowering chocolate and cocoa taste. Very sweet, though the dryness of the cocoa powder provides some balance. I enjoyed this one-dimensional beer (but then I like chocolate!)
Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty aroma, fantastic chocolate notes. Powerfull chocolate flavor. Really great. Creamy palate. Fantastic beer.
Dark brown to black in color with a good tan head.  Smells of malts, roastiness, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is definelty chocolate but well balanced and easy to drink.
This is my new favorite stout.  Smooth and creamy with a sweet chocolate taste all the way down the gullet.  Doesnt overwhelm as the tastes of roasted malt and hops come through.  I love this beer.

Pours with a dark black color and about a half inch of head that dissipates in a few minutes.  The aroma is strongly chocolate.  The flavor is not overpowering chocolate, but seems well balanced.  The roasted malts and hops come through the chocolate fog.  This beer is medium-heavy bodied and medium carbonation.  This is a good beer and good stout.

(cleaning out my beer bottle collection as pictured in my profile and utilizing ratebeer.com)
As I recall, this was a delicious stout.  Could use more abv, but was just the right balance of bitter and chocolate.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2008 Original rating 3/6/05.  Pours a very black color, moderate tan head that doesn’t last long. Chocolate, malty aroma, although not all that strong. The flavor is pretty nice with dark chocolate right away with subtle malts and bitter hop notes following. This seems more like a dessert. Hell, maybe it can be. I can’t drink too many of these chocolate beers though. A simple 12 ounce would have been fine. 

Re-rate 10/31/08. A nice one for Halloween. Black color with a little amber sneaking through with a thin head, even with an aggressive pour. Wonderful aroma, lots of cocoa. The beer starts off rather tame but quickly turns to a nice mix of milk and dark chocolate flavors. Roasted malts, light hop bitterness and coffee notes prevent this from being too one dimensional. Chocolate lingers long into the aftertaste. Easy drinking stout... no problem finishing a bomber this time. Rogue’s Shakespeare is still better but this is very solid.
Pours black with light brown head. Aromas of burnt malts and chocolate. Flavor is bitter burnt malts and chocolate. Full body with minimal carbonation and creamy mouthfeel. An excellent sweet stout.

Pours a thick, dark black with a minimal tan head. The aroma is almost all sweet chocolate, with a little bit of roasted malt bitterness in there. The flavor hits with tons of chocolate right of the bat, which fades very gracefully into a somewhat roasted malt/hop bitterness. The chocolate flavor lingers throughout however. This beer is balanced remarkably well, with all the flavors existing together quite harmoniously. The mouthfeel is little sharp for the style, but is still very nicely full bodied. I have to say that this may be my favorite Rogue brew so far, highly recommended.

Pours black with huge tan head and phenominal lacing. Nose primarilty of grapefruit hops, roasty malt, and roasted coffee. Palate was quite smooth with flavors of roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, and hops. Nice lingering hop presence.

hoppy for a stout, great chocolate hit to the senses- beautiful brownish head with gorgeous lacing. bitter chocolate with hops and malt, strong flavor overall. palate is solid, with a bitter aftertaste resulting from the chocolate. overall delicious, especially under the sweet stout category- magnificently to maintain beer taste, doesnt get overwhelmed by the chocolate. great stuff.

22 oz. Bomber. Pours a nice dark brown to black with a big, puffy caramel colored head. Has a huge chocolate malt aroma. Chocolate, chocolate and more chocolate in the flavor. Also earthy and musty in the background. A bit thin on the palate, but still pretty good. Descent bitterness and a nice finish.

Pours out black with a nice sized fluffy brown head. Aroma is of cocoa powder, hops and some roasted malt. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Flavors of sweet chocolate, dark chocolate, roasted malts and slight caramel. Solid beer.

Bomber from West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago.  Opaque black with medium creamy brown head.  Aroma is big chocolate and roast with nice spicy backbone.  Flavor is also chocolate and roast with sprucey, pine like hop presence and all around very nice flavor, but I wonder what "natural chocolate flavor" means.  Medium creamy body.  Very nice and pleasing.
Creamy head but after beating that away left a middle of the road chocolate stout.  Go to Brooklyn for Brooklyn Chocolate Stout for a beer that hits the pallete with more bite.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 Black with a low but dense brown head and some nice lacings. The aroma blows me away, but then again I am also a sweet chocolate stout maniac! It has BIG notes of chocolate (!), caramel, orange, cocoa, and a bit of cinnamon. The flavour is somewhat different being bitter to begin with, then moving into some sweeter regions of coffee, chocolate, liquorice and roasted malts. It is light-bodied with lots of tiny carbonation-bubbles. This beer reminds me why I am in love with the American beer tradition.

a very substantial and tasty beer that is worth going back to. Chocolate is there, sure. But, so is some nice cascade bitterness that really works well. Creamy, thicker mouthfeel makes this one of the best in class for chocolate stouts.

Tap. Dark beer. Came out with a large rolling head (love it when beer does that). Large head that lasted a while. Aroma of hops and bittersweet chocolate. Has a definite chocolate taste. Almost like drinking a chocolate bar. A bit of hops on the finish makes sure the sweetness keeps in check. Very good beer. Easy stout to drink.

[Bottle, thanks Philsner] Pours dark brown with a pretty good sized tan head that lingers nicely.  Aroma is really big on citrusy hops when poured cold with subdued milk chocolate also present, but when allowed to warm a little it is like smelling a glass of milk chocolate. Aroma is huge, and although one-dimensional, very nice. Taste is fairly bitter from the citrusy hops up front, but then transitions into a deep roast with a surprisingly small amount of chocolate present. Medium-thin mouthfeel with an average finish that has some chocolate but is largely bitterness from the hops. The aroma was the high point of this beer for me, with the palate somewhat lacking and the taste surprisingly low on chocolate taste. Not bad.
Another good beer from rogue. A good begineers stout. Decent amount of flavor. Quite tasty

Pours black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and hops.  Flavor is hoppy chocolate,  coffee,  smoke,  and nuts.  A little too carbonated,  just a touch.  Finishes lightly bitter with a bit of sweet.
This is quite a hoppy stout.  Has some nice aromas of chocolate, but the flavor is just ta bit more than I prefer in a chocolate stout.  Not horrible, not great

UPDATED: APR 21, 2008 Pours dark with a slightly creamy somewhat off-white head.  The aroma is chocolate and roasted, and tasty, but the lingering effect on the palate is somewhat more acidic (think bitter cooking chocolate with a touch of alcohol), and while not entirely unpleasant, leaves something to be desired.

Bottle at home .... Thanks to Reakt for delivery of this ... Deep black ... sweet slightly artifical chocolate nose ... quite thin ... lots of roast ... slight burnt tones ... bit too much hop in its front for me ... and a little hop bitterness ... decent enough.
Bottle. Deep brown with a foamy lightbrown head. Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee and sugar. Rich and creamy palate. Very drinkable. Flavours of roasted malts and of course chocolate.

Flaske. Kraftig duft af chokolade, på denne meget mørkebrune øl. Lækkert skum. Næsten ved at nå sidste holdbarhedsdato hvilket betød at der ikke var så kraftigt et humlebid til at opveje den meget kraftige chokolademælksmag. Det kunne den ellers have godt af. Men alt i alt udmærket uden at være rigtig god.

Bottle huge thanks to harrisoni. Aroma is burstign with chocolate malts its really really choclaty. Taste is similarly choc out its nut, however thinner than expected but this did make it amazingly drinkable. Hops are there but hidden in compairison to the choc. Great sweet stout, they should make more like it.
Bottle. Dark black with tan head. Sweet aroma. Strong chocolate flavour, but not syrupy. Nice bitter after taste. A fine stout.

Black with a tan head.  Aroma is chocolaty sweet.  The flavor is plenty of sweet chocolates, but not particularly sticky.  It has a rather strong hop presence that allows for a nice, pleasant bitter finish.  Strong, thick-bodied mouthfeel.  Quite enjoyable beer.

650ml bottle. Black with beautiful thick brown head that subsides with little lacing. Massive chocolate aroma WOW! Based on the style I had to give this one a 10 for aroma. Its intense chocolate. Smooth and sweet. If it werent for the slight hoppy finish Id swear I was drinking some kind of a chocolate milk drink. Tasty and very drinkable. A nice session stout.

Bomber poured into a pint glass.  Poured a thick black with a tan beige head that was fluffy and lasting and lead to nice lacing.  Aroma: wow!  For me, this was by far the most appealing aspect of this beer.  It wasn;t extremely complex, it was just unbelievable delicious smelling: rich chocolate, coffee, and sugar.  The chocolate worked much better with the aroma the flavor; the flavor was still good, but it tasted kind of like watered down dark chocolate, and the focus on the chocolate style kind of takes away from the other typical stout aspect that one might normally be able to pick up on.  There were small hints of oak and alcohol.  The palate was nice and rich, smooth and creamy and dark.  It leaves a warm stickiness coating the palate.   This was a great beer in my books.  
 
WARNING: I just noticed (upon getting to the bottom of the bottle) that there is a thick layer of residue/sediment settled on the bottom of my bottle.  This is probably because the bottle was sitting for a long time and i didnt remember to stir it or agitate it in the bottle before pouring it.  Be warned to agitate the bottle so as to abstract all of the beers intended flavors.  Perhaps this accounted for the "watered" down chocolate flavor.
Good hearty stout and Im glad I shelled out the duckets to try one.  Very dark stout with suprisingly little brown head. Lots of roasted malt and chocolate flavoring.

Bomber -  Black, black, black.  Faint head dissipated quickly.  Bitter chocolate aroma, flavors of black and roasted malt and tobacco undertones.  Medium hop bitterness and better than average mouth-feel.  Personally I like less roasted malts so not particularly high on this brew.  And whats with the chick on the label??  Purchased Ramsey Liquor 2008.

oooohhh boy oh boy! licorice and chocolate with a body that is rich and full. oatey body that is just the mark of a really good stout. beautiful head that does not last. smokey in the very finest way. velvety and yet refreshing ths ought to knock the rust off youre tastebuds. very good.

Pours dark chocolate burnt color. Has a nice flavor but not anything exciting with a roasted malt that turns into a finish and aftertaste that are wonderful. The roasted malt needs to have something to play with in the flavor, its currently the only thing you taste during that point.
Using real chocolate is kind of cheating, but I dont even care.  On draught at Circa 3/3/08.  Big creamy oatmeal stout body with super chocolate flavor and burnt malt finish.  Amazing.
I so love this beer.  Gotta get one now.  It is not available in Alabama in bottles due to our shitty laws but I can get it on tap at the J. Clyde and On Tap.

Bomber from the rip and run.  Muted nose of swet dark malts is realy a bit weak.  Pours a magnificent dark brown. Burnt sienna head is alive and dense and thick....it never stops thru the whole bottle.  First taste is a bit charcolish and bitter but soon the chocolate roundess is pronounced and is then taken over by the crisp hop and dark malt bitter finish. Legs are sparse and run freely down the glass. No sticking here, this beer wants to be consumed!   Head is recharged continuously.A fine pint of stout.

I do apologize for the low rating.  I believe you rate a beer on its enjoyment, and I loathed this.  I can appreciate a great beer.  For whatever reason this is just not for me.  I have a similar contention with Guiness.  Its entirely too over the top for me.  I may be missing the complexity, but its astringency and weightyness leave me totally unsatisfied.  Its aroma is wonderful.  Its appearance is gorgeous, its dark color and its fluffy head.  Its flavor isnt bad at all.  Its bitter hop count absolutely ruins this for me.  I expected something, but was utterly disappointed.  I do recognize however that this may not be for me.  Unless you are in love with heavy stouts be careful.  This baby packs a high price, and big bottle.  Be careful.
UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 freakin AMAZING! it could taste a little better, but the aftertaste is amazing! probably top 10 on my list of best beers, top 3 on my list of best stouts.

Bottled (6% ABV). A opaque dark black beer with a big, persistent, creamy brown head. The aroma is powerful more than intense and has strong notes of chocolate (a mix between dark and milk chocolate), Cascade hops with their citric character and roasted malt. The flavour has the expected notes of chocolate, plus a hint od coffee and a large amount of hops. Medium body at best, lively carbonation, quite long chocolately finish with medium bitterness. Certainly not bad, but I would have preferred a stronger body. However if you like chocolate this is your beer.

Near black colored, little brown head. Well, chocolate dominates this overly sweet aroma, slight hops, mild caramel and roastiness also there. Medium bodied. Flavor is also chocolaty, though hops are nicely present here. Aftertaste dries nicely with bitter hops and chocolate still. Flavor is way better than overly sweet aroma.

This one is hard to rate as it is the best tasting beer Ive ever had.  Someone finally got roasted malts quite right.  Not overpowering but with a  very complex set of flavors.  My overall isnt a 20 because it cost about $6 after tax.  Also, this is not an everyday drinker for me.  But, as a brew to end the day on, it hits one out of the proverbial park.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 pours dark brown to almost black with a thick creamy head reminded me of a rootbeer float.flavor of choclate and roasted malts a little dry on the tounge. i really enjoyed it, but at 4.99 abottle i should have cant wait to try the mocha porter

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2008 Pours dark brown with a tan head that disappates quickly.  Strong aroma of chocolate, but with additinal notes of roasted coffee and licorice.  Tatse of chocolate and hops which really shine through at the finish.  Fairly well balanced.  The chocolate malts are the highlight here, but the finish is bitter and lasting. One of Rogues best beers.

Pours a black color with a tan head that dissipates quickly.  Scent of chocolate and toffee.  Taste was of chocolate, and roasted malts.  Surprising hop finish and small bite of the alcohol.  This beer was awesome.  Definitely one of my favorite stouts and overall beers.
pours a very dark brown, nearly black with a two finger tan head. nose is chocolate, espresso, and plum. taste is a lovely dark roasted fusion of sweetened malts and coffee. deep bitter finish.
Pours dark black, smells like mild cocoa. Tastes like mild cocoa. Like a desert beer. Pretty good. ITs got a lot of foam, and has a fair amount of bite.
Tap...Pours a deep brown color w/ a tan head. Nose of chocolate, toasted malts...Taste is chocolatey, malty w/ a little hop bite. Nice and thick, but w/  a semi-dry finish.

22 0z bottle via Roths. Pours a near pitch black with dark brown edges and a large tan head. Nose is chocolate, oats, and dark currants. Taste is sweet chocolate, licorice, soy, roasted grains, and a strong citrus hop finish. Carbonation is medium, body is medium. A good easy drinking Stout that gives you a chocolate fix!
Bottle. Nice big tan head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are milky chocolate, roast malt and maybe some vanilla.
Pours deep dark brown, almost black with a good tan head. The aroma is of chocolate, vanilla and a touch of bourbon. Tastes very chocolaty and bitter with a smoky finish. A damn tasty beer.
65 cl bottle, Fargo. Opaque dark brown colour, thin head. Chocolate aroma (no surprise), lightly carbonated with a very smooth flavor. Very drinkable. No idea it was 6.3% alcohol.
Bottle Black pour with great head. Sweet chocolate aroma and flavor. Very smooth. Good beer overall.

My favorite Rogue offering thus far.  Key black with a nice creamy looking head that oozes out the aroma of Hersheys syrup and a little bit of hops.  Loads of dark chocolate with a surprising hop presence. Only negative is that the mouthfeel is a little thin on this.  It isnt quite as viscous as I would like it to be, however, this is still really good.  A dessert in itself.
Pours a thick black color with a dark brown head.  Has a rich sweet chocalete aroma, with a flavor to match that finishes with a bitter burnt taste.Very Good.

As I poured it out of the bottle, I smelled the sweet chocolate immediately.  A dark beer with very little head.  The first sip was like biting into a dark chocolate bar.  Every sip after gave me the same feeling.  A costly beer here in Virginia but I will buy it again.  As I drank it, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory appeared on the television when I turned it on.....irony!

All i have to say is oh my god. Ive had a few chocolates and none have tasted anything like this one. There is no bitterness, no blech, no burnt. Its just a chocolate bar melted down mixed with some beer. The smell of chocolate was so much that we smelled it when she put the glass on the table. The only reason its not perfection is its almost too much on the palate for any beer after to follow.

Rogue Chocolate Stout
ABV: 6.3%
Volume: 1 PT 6 FL. OZ.
Glass: okocim .5L curved glass
Purchased at: Jacks Wine Sense
Consumed on: 02/08/08

first impression: Absolutely beautiful in sight and smell. A rich cocoa scent with dark undertones. Head is fabulous and three fingers. Three slow pours to fill the half liter glass. Only visible color change is at the thinnest edge, where its a deep purplish red. I could smell it all day long, but on to tasting. Its like a deep dark chocolate cocoa with strong hop overtones. A glorious mix of bitter and sweet. The tastes are hardly sweet, but so very delicious.

Visuals -- Color, depth, belgian lace, legs: The edge of the stout where color peeks through is more orange than red, and it seems angry. The taste isnt exactly happy either - its beating the hell out of my palate, but its wonderful. Head dies down after a few long sips, but still very present. The lace is nice and stays with you.

Olfactory -- Aroma: While the other aspects of this stout are delectable, the aroma is maybe its best feature. It is heavenly.

Taste -- Hoppiness, bite, maltiness, flavor: The hops are surprisingly present. If this beer was smoother or sweeter, it wouldnt be such a powerful presence. The hops are here and obvious, but not overpowering, and not the point. The point is the chocolate flavor.

Tactile -- weight, mouthfeel: Its heavy in the hand, the eye, and the wrist. Its heavy in the air and on the tongue. Its undeniable. Crispy and dry with a smoother finish.

second impression: What a delight. Easily one of the best beers Ive had in this family.

Nice slightly bitter chocolate aroma.  Pours an opaque black, with a big tan head.  Flavor is hints of chocolate, roast, and a touch of a sour taste.  Some bitterness balances it out.  Somewhat light on the mouthfeel.  Not a bad beer, but not the first Ill go for.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 This thing is pitch black. Try shinning a white LED mag light through this thing and FAIL. Nose is heavy chocolate and doesnt even smell of alcohol. It just seems like a regular chocolate beverage by nose. This is incredible. Alcoholic chocolate thats there is to this. Im totally blown away. I think Rogue will and should be recognized as one of the worlds greatest breweries.

Pours a creamy black into the glass with a tan head.  Aroma brings me back to my youth and a nice glass of chocolate milk.  The flavor is, thankfully, more grown up.  Nice bitterness to balance the sweetness and a nice dry finish.  By far the best Rogue I have had

Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with dark brown head. Aroma is of hersheys chocolate syrup with some hints of roasted malt and oat. Flavor is rich and chocolaty with a cocoa powder bitter edge to it leading to a dryer bittersweet finish. Mouthfeel is not thin by any means but thinner than the rich flavor would lead you to expect, making it easy drinking. I was pleased to find it balancing towards bitter more than sweet.

This is what the aroma of a chocolate stout should be and the taste to back it u.  Not to thick on the palate with the initial taste being all chocolate.  This taste passes quickly and leaves a very hoppy aftertaste.  This is pretty thin for a stout and doesnt coat the mouth as much as I would have liked.  Even so, this is a good beer and my favorite from rogue.
dark color, dark brown head. Doesn pair well with chocolate but has its own chocolare taste. Nothing special.

A decent chocolate stout but nothing out of the ordinary.  This beer exhibits a dark leathery body with a tan silky head.  Although this is more drinkable than most because of its less "sticky" consistency, it lacks the complexity of higher ranked stouts.  All of the typical ingredients and "profiles" are there, it just doesnt bump anything up a notch.  Good, not great.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 Bomber. Thick dark pour, instant aroma of milk chocolate, rather than dark bittersweet which is common with choco stouts.  Tan, thick head. Mocha in a glass, very drinkable though.  One of my favorite choco stouts

Opaque, lasting dark brown head. Chocolate immediately hits you in aroma, but also some roasted malts and oats are present. Predominantly bitter flavour, but still obvious complexity, milk, oatmeal, and quite some hops, really nice. Lasting bitter finish. I think this beer displays the most chocolate flavour ive ever encountered in a beer (so far), funny. Nice beer.
22 oz Bottle.  Quite an experience.  I could tell you all about aromas and flavors until youre blue in the face, but ultimately you need to try it yourself.

Bottle.  Pours black with no head and a good amount of lacing.  Aroma is chocolate and bitterness.  Taste is coffee, creamy, roasted malt, and just a bit of chocolate.  This is a very good stout with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a deep brown color with a nice beige head.  Aroma of (gasp) chocolate with a slight roastiness.  Flavor is mainly bitter chocolate, with some oatiness, roastiness, and a hint of coffee coming out in the finish.  Smooth and pretty creamy, but would have enjoyed it more with more body.  Overall, a pretty solid offering from Rogue that I will have again.

The 22 oz bomber poured into a tulip glass produced a black body toped of by a two finger tan head. That settles into a nice thick lace covering most of the glass 

Yes its a chocolate stout and the aromas defiantly back it up lots of sweet chocolate aromas some earthiness to it along with some hint of roasted malts 

Flavors of dark chocolate are dominate not overly sweet with a coffee backbone its got this mocha thing going on

The mouthfeel is medium to thin would have liked it a little thicker

This is really one of the great chocolate stouts especially for under $5 a bomber well worth the experience

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass, this beer is black as night. The inch-tall head rises a dark tan and sticks around for ages. 

Big surprise, this chocolate stout smells like chocolate. A part milk chocolate and a part baking chocolate. 

Phenomenal taste. Milk and dark chocolates, some roasted malt bitterness, and a even a little hop zing for balance. 

Like drinking velvet, in a good way. Smooth, full-bodied, and luxurious.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep, deep brown with good size tan head.  Nose of chocolate and malt.  Tastes of roasted oats, chocolate, and a bit of coffee.  Has a wonderful burnt bitterness that I really like.  Great chocolate flavor, but with enough bitterness to remind you that you are drinking beer, not eating candy.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 22 oz. bottle. Pours black with a beautiful brown head. Bittersweet chocolate nose with notes of roasted malt and a hint of chocolate. Medium/full body. Heavy chocolate flavor with some earthy notes and some roasted malt. I really enjoyed this one.

Smells like bitter black chocolate -- awesome!  Looks like strong coffee with espresso-like light-brown bubbles on top.  It tastes much like the aroma, and theres both the burnt malt bitterness and a more piercing hops bitterness.  Very yummy.  I like how its not too sweet, which is what tends to turn me off of other chocolate stouts and some imperial stouts.

Bottle, 650 ml. Pours black brown ruby with thin tan head. Aroma is chocolate, malt, molasses, anise, coffee, vanilla ice cream. Flavor is very sweet, sort of like chocolate cake with a bit of coffee and roasted nuts. Not bad.
Too sweet for my taste.  Felt like I needed to brush my teeth after this one.  Aroma of Chocolate, almond, carmel, and coffee.  Definately not my kind of stout.

2 ounce sample.  Tasting at 99 BOTTLES.  Chocolate and coffee were the dominant aromas and flavors.  This was one of the best smelling stouts I have encountered.  The flavor fell a little short of the aroma, but was still well done.  If you like chocolate mochas then you will enjoy this ale.
Bottle.  Very dark, smells of chocolate.  Taste is first chocolate, then a bit of hops comes through.  Very good.

22oz.  Pours black with an orange head.  Aroma is mostly roasted malt with some sweetness.  Flavor is pretty sweet, roasted malts, lots of hops and what I am led to believe is chocolate but Im not sold on that flavor standing out like I expected.  Best closer to room temperature, this lends itself towards a creaminess with some good sherry-like nuttiness.  Kind of reminds me of the hazelnut brown on steroids minus the hazelnut.
Bottle: Poured a thick black with a brown creamy head. Aroma is heavy with chocolate with malts. Taste is rich chocolate and coffee bean. Finishes dry and very yummy.
Draft.  Deep ebony with a tan head.  Aroma is definitely chocolate.  Hoppier than I thought it would be with a cocoa finish.  Roasty, but a tad astringent.  A little thin for a stout.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cookie, toasted, nutty, dark chocolate, and strong coffee, light perfume for the hops, light earth for the yeast, and cola and a faint dried fruitiness in the background. Head is frothy, light brown, has fair lacing, and is mostly lasting. Color is opaque black. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic, and the long finish is lightly acidic and heavily bitter like semisweet chocolate. Palate is light to medium, dry yet creamy, has a lively carbonation, and finishes moderately astringent and very dry. This reminds me of an after dinner espresso. A lighter body than I expected, but a very dry texture and finish, and a complex malt character makes this a fine sweet stout.
this beer is vary tasty.  a good beer to have by a camp fire.  lots of sweet chocolate that you tast mostly on the exhale

Bomber. A super-dark beer with a creamy, foamy off-white head. Intense aroma of chocolate, with roasted malt and hops right behind it. Wonderful creamy palate with chocolate flavor dominant but, not over shadowing the roasted dark malts and hops. a relly excellent beer. Another beer I wish I could find where I live.

Black with a dark brown head. Nose lots of chocolate, little bit of roasted malt. Chocolate dominates the flavor, but then in the back, theres just a nice little hoppy finish that makes me want another sip.  And another...

A Mes rate: Bottle thanks to Reakt.As black a beer as I have seen. You could hold a Fresnel to this and there would be no light penetration. Big chunky milky coffee head. Damn good looks. Easily the most hardcore chocolate smelling beer I have sniffed at. If this was a blind tasting I would swear someone had just given me something made by Cadburys. In fact no. I know what it is. It smells exactly like chocolate Ovaltine. Like right on the button. This is a bed time beer, 100%. Full on chocolate in the flavour with some eventual hops that finally confirms this is actually beer. The hops add a really nice, and very welcome, bitterness to it. I really like it, its just not beery enough.

22 oz bottle from South Bay Drugs: Almost pure black with burgandy highlights held up to a flashlight and a generous tan head. Aroma is cocoa powder. Flavor starts very chocolaty like dark godiva cocoa followed by sharp carbonation on the tongue and maybe a hint of burnt coffee with a bittersweet dark chocolate finish. Medium body is smooth and tangy with lively carbonation.

From bottle. The first thing that got me was this beer really did smell of chocolate, chocolate milk in fact, and you know what... I love chocolate milk. Great black appearance with a muddy flood water head.  Chocolate fudge flavour. Its like drinking/eating a whole box of those chocolate liquor selections. Its smooth, bitter sweet, coffee. Not really any sign of the 6.3% alcohol. Its like a meal in itself. Successful chocolate stout in my opinion. Enjoyed it immensely and want another one.
lager journey. A sweet chocolate brew. This beer doesnt hide anything be ready for a session of melty pocket chocolate. Light enough to enjoy multiples

Pours a dark brown, with a nice tan head. Decent lacing. Aromas of chocolate, expresso, and a slight vanilla. Flavors of chocolate, and malts, with a slight smokiness to it. A little bitter on the tounge, but still a great beer.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA
