text: great tasting stout. I had it with another chocolate stout and this was my favorite of the two. its everything you are looking for in a good stout, strong flavor, beautiful mouthfeel and a full, bittersweet finish.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2008 I guess Im man enough to confess that I got pwn3d by this beer.

Not pwn3d the way I got pwn3d by a bottle of the Abyss that I opened after getting home from a hard night Uber. No, this was worse. It started off almost boring; this was the last of the "accessible top 50" for me, even though its in most every grocery store around here, andI figured I may as well tried it. I bought a bottle, and while I didnt really look forward to drinking it, the prospect of panning it in my review here gave me at least something enjoyable to anticipate.

Why? Chalk it up to some combination of character flaws on my part, perhaps best explained with reference to Seattle coffee-geek culture. Along with beer, Im a bit of a coffee geek as well, continually obsessing over the latest pro-series rotary pump espresso machines and conical burr grinders, procuring my espresso beans only from ultra-geek David Schomer (Espresso Vivace), going through a half-dozen shots in the morning to calibrate extraction times, the whole nine yards. So anyway, seeing this beer on the accessible top 50 list was like when some colleague of mine finds out that Im into coffee and wants to take me to try the amazing one she found the other day and we get there and it turns out to be a Starbucks and then she orders me a double decaf soy frappaccino with Irish Cream syrup and if she wasnt such a babe Id either be laughing in her face or dumping the coffee into a potted plant and instead Im setting there across the table from her trying to choke the damn thing down while keeping my eyes at or above the horizontal.  

Yeah, so a seemingly-highly rated Rogue concoction with "natural chocolate flavor." Could there be a more perfect set for the ultimate drainpour slam review? Basically, this one was floating up there soft and gentle, just hovering above the net, the perfect set. And I was Karch Kiraly looming in to spike this baby home and bury it two feet in the sand and leave the two bastards on the either side of the net looking around for their now-stained jockstraps. 

And I crack it open, and pour it into a snifter, and I inhale, its a perfect facsimile of a chocolate milkshake from Johnny Rockets and I burst out laughing because its all too perfect and damn am I going to slam this thing on Ratebeer for being a syrup-added pseudo-stout for the Bartles & James set. So I take a sip, getting ready to pound that last nail into the coffin, and wait....

...what the hell is this....?

I like it....its got a serious hop bite on the finish that actually compensates for all that darn chocolate, maybe even almost complements it...nah....its got to be a first sip sorta thing, all of the flaws are going to come out in the second sip and man Im going to trash this thing on ratebeer, and then I take a second sip, and a third, and all the flaws are there, and the chocolate is syrupy indeed, but damn this is a pretty enjoyable beer anyway, and then Im 18 ounces in, and almost regretting -- no, I am regretting -- that there are only a few sips left and wondering what to drink next and not really feeling quite in the mood for my usual favorites like a saison or belgian ale, they seem too...challenging right at the moment after this wonderful chocolate syrupbeersoda, and I get up, and carry glass across the room, and I look in the mirror, and there I see a beer geek struggling to hang on to the last vestiges of self respect by pouring this one down the drain....but instead the bastard gulps down the last few sips and stands there like an idiot, smiling at how good it tastes.

PWN3D.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Very strong aroma. Looks excellent. Very flavorful as well but a hint of sourness and a little thin. I really enjoyed it but its not exceptional.
Very strong chocolate taste without being as thick as Youngs. A rich aftertaste and even better with ice cream.

Ezo Beer Bitter Bear Chocolate Stout. Pours black and thick with dark brown head.  Very sweet aroma, caramelly, inviting.  First sip: Holy Crap.  Its like biting into a bar of dark chocolate.  Thick, sweet yet bitter, slightly smokey, loads of chocolate, slight maltiness, all gently tapering out in a smooth, clean, non-cloying finish.  Quite a fantastic beer.  I want to eat this as a cake.

Beautiful opaque black pour, with a sudsy tan head that leaves a light cap and soapy lace.  The nose is of complex, multiple chocolates... very, very indicative of the flavors on the palate.  There is an upfront bittersweet choco malt, followed by a nice contiguous bitter mid-palate, followed by an effervescent chocolate finish that waxes and wanes between bitter and bittersweet (possibly leaning toward a slight vanilla compliment).  The mouthfeel is medium-oily, with nicely integrated carbo levels to make it somewhat slick.  Very complex is this offering, and definitely explores the many variants of chocolate.  Prost!

22 oz. bomber split with Naka.  Pours opaque oily black w/ chocolate head about an inch thick.  Sweet nose w/ hint of roast and plum.  Tastes of chocolate w/ sweet, some roasted notes, then a bitter dark chocolate finish that lingers.  Pretty good offering.  Tasty, but odd.

Bottled, consumed 01/03/08.  Almost-black pour creates a lingering dark tan head.  Aromas are red wine like fruit and, you guessed it, chocolate.  Mouthfeel is unremarkable.  The flavor is strong bitter chocolate/cocoa that grows more defined as the beer goes down.  Slight sweetness totally conquered by big bitter flavor.  Oats mellow the flavor somewhat, but only a little.  Not really my bag.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 Great looking dark color with a chocolate brown head.  Aroma is of roasted chocolate.  Much hoppier than I expected... the Cascade hops are very apparent.  A good beer... the one I had the label was colored differently than the photo to the left... she was wearing a bright red shirt.

1 pt. 0.6 oz bottle.
22oz bottle. Pours pitch black in color with brown head. Aroma milk chocolate and hops. Taste milk chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt and hops with a dark chocolate bitter finish.

22oz bomber or New Years Eve. Pours oily black with a full, creamy tan head. Strong aroma of oatmeal, chocolate, and some yeast. Tastes of unsweetned cocoa and oats with a slight hop bitterness on the finish. This is good. Id prefer it to be more creamy and more sweet chocolate. I prefer Youngs Double Chocolate to this.

22oz bomber-pours a dark color with a creamy tan head. Tastes of bittersweet chocolate. Not sweet at all. Very smooth and creamy. Slight carbonation with a chocolate finish. Cannot taste any alcohol. One of my favorite chocolate stouts. Good job Rogue

Pours a deep black color with a tan head.  Powerful aroma of oat, chocolate, and hops.  Nice body.  Taste hops and oats upfront with a back edge of chocolate-unless you let it warm up a bit.  The chocolate takes over when warm.  Not my favorite chocolate stout, but a good one nonetheless.
tastes like a chocolate shake... only not in a good way. like hershys syrup

A disappointment.  Aroma of roasted malts, with no particularly unique qualities, & alcohol.  Pours with a thick head.  Flavor is quite dry & sour, with too much alcohol coming through.  No chocolate flavor whatsoever.  Roasty malts, maybe a pinch of spent espresso grounds.  Mouthfeel is spritzier than I enjoy in a stout. Not enough flavor or alcohol for an imperial stout, but too much booziness for a standard stout.

Pours oil black with a dart tan head like chocolate mousse.  Has an aroma of sweet cocoa.  It has a sweet taste of caramel malt and a melted chocolate milkshake... in a good way.  Finishes with bittersweet chocolate.  It didnt have the thickness that I would have thought from the looks of it.  Highly drinkable if you are into chocolate.

Bottle: I have to admit that I am not a big fan of chocolate, so take this for what it is worth.  Pours dark with a thick head.  Heavy aroma and flavor of chocolate.  A little too much.  Too sweet.  Drinkable, but I will not be back.

Pours very dark black topped with a mocha colored head. The aroma is filled with roasted malt, dark chocolate, and what smells like some lactose sweetness. There is a roasty blast up front but it fades quickly revealing very smooth dark chocolate and some sweetness. Very tasty and very smooth but perhaps a bit too sweet. The chocolate aftertaste last a while. It has a creamy full body and excellent drinkability.
Pours an extremely dark brown with an accompanying light brown head.  Smells chock full of chocolate malts.  The taste is a roasted chocolate.  One of the most chocolate beers out there.

Pours a dark brown that its almost black. A huge chocolate milk head that dies slow with spotty lacing. Nose is a chocolaty as I have ever smelled. Huge on chocolate and cocoa, roastyness comes through with a nice bitter hop finish but a chocolate linger. Silky smooth in the mouth and not thick like an impy. Drinkable but more than one of these treats would be much. Absolutly one of the best chocolate stouts I have had.
Draught @ Taco Mac.  Very good.  Taste of dark chocolate and not too sweet.  Not too heavy mouthfeel and would drink again.
A nice choclate stout.  Just misses the mark for some reason.  Bitter in the wrong spots.
22 0z bottle pours an opaque black with a thick beige head.  Aroma of chocolate and roasty malt.  Slightly bitter chocolate flavor with a nice medium-full mouth feel.
Bottle from the fresh. A very nice thick black pour with moderate head.Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Im not a huge fan of chocolate stouts but this is one i enjoy. Nice hoppy finish.

1pt 6oz bottle at Kerbey Lane (So. Lamar Blvd, Austin, TX)... they have the beer as a special beer currently (12/19/07). Pours slick jet black, raising a nice finger of reddish/brown foam. Foam didnt last long on this one, but had a nice ring lace on top. Aroma: obvious roastiness, chocolate malts and flavoring, mud and cocoa powder. Flavor was fairly sweet, like the end of a cup of hot coca or chocolate milk. Dare I say it sweet chocolateness borders on over-the-top like Herseys being poured into the brew. Not enough to kill the thrill, though. Still very enjoyable. A dry finish and surprising carbonated spark to it.

Pours black with a large dark tan head.  Big sweet chocolate aroma.   Flavor is a little on the sweet side...could use some more balance.   Not a whole lot of bite.    Bittersweet dark chocolate and thats about it.   Palate is watery and adds nothing.  The chocolate flavor could be really excellent if it had something backing it up... the body leaves such a big flavor flat.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2016 Bottle. Appearance: Pitch black with a thick brown head with medium retention. Aroma: Chocolate, vanilla, hops and roasted malt. Flavor: I am very surprised here, the taste is really milk chocolate instead of dark chocolate. It is very chocolaty, there is vanilla, sugar, roasted malt and a somewhat bitter finish. Full to medium body. A very good chocolate stout.
Bomber.  Pitch black with dense brown head.  Sweet cocoa aroma.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate which turns slightly sour and bitter.  Roasted malt and hop finish lingers.

Great beer for tonight - snowing outside with the wind whipping around.  Deep brown color with a huge foamy tan head.  Heavy roasted notes with a balanced milk chocolate aroma.  Taste was predominantly the roasted malt - very little chocolate on the palate.  Flavor skewed much more to a stout than a chocolate stout.  Still enjoyable, though.  Rogue rarely disappoints.

Completely opaque.  I like that in a stout.  Smells like chocolate.  Tastes like chocolate.  Nice mouthfeel of a stout, with a hint of hop flavor in the finish thats just enough to bitter up the chocolate flavor.  I tip my hat to rogue, Ive never had anything quite like that before.

I was not greatly impressed with this beer.  It certainly looked the part of a sweet stout, but the flavor and mouthfeel were very reminiscent of Yoohoo chocolate drink to me...which is to say chocolate-y (in a way) yet a bit thin and watery.

This beer certainly looks the part of a top-notch stout; it was black and opaque, although not particularly viscous.  Head formation was creamy and sturdy.  Aroma was chocolate-y and coffee-ish, but not overpowering.  Flavor was as I said, very reminiscent of Yoohoo.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin.

Id weakly recommend this beer.

I picked up this 22oz bottle from Garys Liquor in Oak Creek, WI.

Somewhat watery and smooth.  This is all about dark malt.  It doesnt overpower with bitterness or a syrupy mouthfeel, its more about subtlties like chocolate, smoke, coffee, cream.  Dark as night with a thin tan head.

Great looking from a 22 oz. bottle. Dark brown almost black with a large tan head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Flavor is chocolate with a hint of licorice. Very nice dry finish. Very smooth and easy to drink.
Delicious Beer! Unable to see through, and has great head. Taste like pure chocolate! If you like stouts, TRY IT!

12/06/07 Big bottle, thanks TikiE.  Mmm tastes of a delicious bitter chocolate.  Could not taste the alcohol, very well hiddden.  Poured a nice head and a great mouthfeel.  Would buy again.  Awesome beer Rogue!

22 oz. Bomber. Chocolate stout perfection! Alcohol % not high enough to serve warm, so slightly chilled is the way to go. Black color, smells of sweet milk chocolate, little bit of coffee flavor but mostly chocolates. Some vanilla, good but not great mouthfeel. Highly recommended

One of my friends brought some over.  Dang, if this doesnt define the perfect balance of roasted malt with just enough sweetness and hops.  Others are right when they say drink cool not cold ....  excellent beer.

Draught at Mellow Mushroom in Brandon. Served way too cold, in a frosted pint glass, so had to let it warm for quite a while. Nose of chocolate - all kinds, powder, milk, bitter, etc. - light coffee, dark malts, sweet cream and a very light hint of the hops. I wouldnt describe it like drinking a chocolate milkshake, as others have, but there is a ton of chocolate here. Its well balanced with the malts and the cream, very well done. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Finish is bitter chocolate, some chalkiness, and super lengthy.

From a bomber provided by Carrie Nation.  Opaque black color, sweet chocolate aroma, brown head, flavor like "alcoholic chocolate cake" to quote Ms. Nation but sweetness is thankfully not overpowering, bitter finish.  Quite respecatable sweet stout.  Thanks, Carrie!

The most surprising thing about this beer was the thin mouthfeel - seemed more like a porter than a stout.  Poured nicely with a good head.  Flavor was unique and tasty but didnt hit a major chord with me.  Disappointing - maybe expectations were too high.

A really nice chocolate stout, definitely drink warmed. NIce chocolate aroma. pitch black pour with with creamy molasses head. very chocolatey and cofffeelike but not overly sweet. moderate hop bitterness balances the flavor. That is an ugly woman on the bottle.

Bomber: Poured black with a tan head. The aroma was all chocolate/cocoa. Taste was similar. Cocoa taste in the beginning followed by a sweet chocolate malt flavor. Toward the finish the hops come through a bit and give the beer a slight bitter, earthy taste. The only complaint I have about this beer is that the mouth feel is almost nonexistent. Other than that it is tremendous.

Bomber bought on sale at Bella Vinos, pours black with a dark tan head, nose is a mixture of bitter and sweet chocolates, 
creamy sweet and vanilla alcohol, I know the alcohol is 6.3% but the nose has a slight vanilla alcohol fragrance like sniffing a bottle of vanilla extract
without the alcohol burn tingling, it is really faint and complements the other aromas I do not know where this comes from, 
there is a good amount of roasted malt fragrances, the nose was pretty nice, lots of smooth roasted malt flavors with chocolate and some sweetness,
faint malt graininess, I did not feel the hop bitterness but it gave a good tongue drying at the finish, finish is pretty dry on the palate with a little bitterness, 
medium mouth feel and carbonation, mouth feel was a touch thin but it was smooth and creamy in the mouth, very easy to drink.
A really flavorful beer with nice velvety smoothness.  The chocolate flavor wasnt too overpowering -- just right.

[bottled] Pours a very dark, opaque body. Head is brown, medium sized. Bitter chocolate immediately evident in the nose and even more so at the first sip, followed by smokey roasted barley and coffe notes. The slightly tangy Cascade hops lead to a rather dry finish which nicely counterbalances the overall sweetness. Body is smooth and rich; bittersweet aftertaste. A robust and delicious chocolate stout.
Lots of cocoa, rather light sweet aroma, not too much of a body. Nice dry chocolate finish. A dessert beer?

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2008 Dark brown pour, tan head.  Not too much chocolate, not too much stout.  A great take on the style, with the hop character being the difference making it a Rogue.  Great finish/aftertaste.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: On tap at the Rogue Ale House. Pours deep brown, almost black, with very thin head. Nose was, of course, chocolate. Flavor was a bit smokey along with the chocolate, and a slight bitter and quite dry finish. Pretty good brew.

Medium dark brown shiny fine-laced head. Opaque black body. Rounded harmonic soft chocolate aroma with milky sugary notes and traces of hops. Dry roasty chocolate taste with hoppy notes. The chocolate doesnt go too well with the hops. Aftertaste is the same, and very long. (0.65l bottle at Knut Alberts.)
A smooth-drinking stout that forms a beautiful creamy head. Has wonderful chocolate notes and a sweet aroma.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2007 Pours a straight black with a small but dense tan head. Aroma is light and sweet. Taste s a good strong malt flavor with strong notes of dark chocolate. Texture is thick, and only lightly carbonated. Nice strong hops taste, but its definitely in balance with the sweetness of the malt and chocolate. I approve.
Pours to a nice tan head, great aroma. Palate is not that good, but the flavour is very good and chocolaty, hoppy and creamy. very good beer.

22 oz. bottle. 
Pours black with a 1 finger brown head. Milk chocolate and blackened malt smell with cinnamin and vanilla. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Very chocolatey taste with toasted malts and vanilla in the background. Finishes bittersweet and smooth. 
An excellent dessert beverage. Jan 2005
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 10-22-07 bottle.  Black with slight lacing. Chocolate creaminess with a background of fruity hops. Hoppy and creamy - a rare but very successful combo.  Very drinkable!

Pours a black color with a brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, molasses, and a hint of citrus hops.  Flavor is pretty strong with chocolate.  Flavor starts off sweet with the chocolate, molasses, and sweet malts.  Finish isnt quite as heavy as I was hoping, but still good.  Finishes with only a slight hint of bitterness from the citrus hops.  Very good stout.
Dark black with a mediam head very light aroma of dark chocolate and hints of coffee. chocolate fudge flavor and a light malt finsih.
Pours out a dark brown color with a huge tan head.  aroma is choco, roasted malts and fairly sweet.  flavor was malty with a nice choco sweet finish.  i liked this beer.  was very tasty.

Bottle.  Poured thick and dark with a nice brown head.  The chocolate is very prominent in the intial aroma with the roasted malt mingling in.  The initial flavor was of chocolate, unfortunately, this initial taste was reminiscint of drinking a stout flavored with chocolate cocoa powder.  As the beer warmed a bit, this subsided.  A nice beer...must try again.

22oz. bomber into pint glass. Pours a deep black color with a thick brown head that laces nicely. Heavy aroma of chocolate, almost too heavy at first smell. Flavors of chocolate, caramel, roasted malts and a hint of barley are present, with a slightly bitter finish that goes well with the sweetness of the chocolate. Has a very smooth thick mouthfeel like most stouts. A chocolate lovers dream.

Fine looking beverage. Pours out inky black, with some ruby hue. Thick mocha head. Smell is primarily powdered chocolate. Taste- more of the same. Has that sweet chocolate milk powder taste, as well some roastiness from the malts, and a touch of lactic sourness. Mouthfeel is good, as is the drinkability. The sweet powdered chocolate gets tiresom after awhile. enjoyable beer.

Pours black with a light brown head. Very very sweet. First sip made me think of Kinder Eggs. Later it gave the impresion of dark Swuiss chocolatebut also coacoabutter. Very full bodied. Medium carboantion. Dry dark choclolaty finish.

Pours rich and dark, aroma of chocolate and thats about it, tastes like a plain stout with an overwhelming chocolate presence, not complex at all. hopping is mild and unintrusive, perfect beer to initiate your Budmiloors friends to a stout.

Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is very light, dusty cocoa.
Flavour is very chocolate forward (again bitter cocoa) with a creamy hot chocolate tones and a medium malt body and a dryish finish.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 Deep black oily pour with a nice medium to small sized brown head.  Smell is sweet milk chocolately.  Pretty smooth tasting, with an obvious big flavor of chocolate up front, followed by a noticeable, but slight hop presence in the finish.  Somewhat crisp carbonation.  Rich and chocolately as expected and quite good, but very simple at the same time.  Might have rated a bit higher had I been more in the mood for something dark and rich.

bottled. black with a steady tan head. pretty no surprises to find a strong chocolate aroma - suggestions of chocolate cake dough and bitter chocolate. standard boring, soft rogue texture, pleasant enough drinking, hints of coffee and cream and a decently bitter finish

Bottle (pint) shared with three dudes at Tre små rum, Göteborg, Sweden. Dark black with a creamy beige head. Intense but not overpowering chocolate aroma, well integrated with the roasted malt profile. Medium to thick in body, smooth mouthfeel, good balance.

Had this side by side with the shakespeare stout.  The pour was rich, dark and creamy.  Had nice head retention and lacing.  The aromas were exactly that of the shakespeare, just with a mild chocolatey sweet smell, without as much roasted notes.  The taste was also very, very similar to that of the shakespeare, but lacked the espresso element, which was replaced by the smooth chocolatey and milky feel at the end.  Nice balance between the roasted malty sweetness, the hop bitterness, and the milk chocolatey creamy mouthfeel.  Slight edge over the Shakespeare...but virtually the same.

Completly black with a medium brown head. Big but not overly assertive aroma of sweet milk chocloate. Quite full bodied. The flavour is dominated by the delicate chocolate character, sweet and malty with some mild coffee bitterness. A very beautiful beer, not very complex, but elegent and soft, and very tastey.

Bomber.  Pours thick and very dark brown with a small coffee colored head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, and milk chocolatey.  Flavor is initially a malty sweetness followed quickly by a bittersweet chocolate/coffee finish; it has almost a smoky quality about it.  A nice balance between sweet and bitter.  Another Rogue success.

bomber.  very creamy - thats the first impression.  I dont get an overwhelming sense of chocolate on this - but it is there.  pours a nice thick black with a gorgeous tan head that lasts throughout.  there are some hops that make themselves known in the end.  a touch of coffee and lots of malts.  A very good offering from Rogue...

Cold 22oz bottle:  Pours a dark brown almost black color with a fluffy milk chocolate head.  Aroma is of chocolate, rich malts, dark fruit, spice and notes of caramel and flowers.  Taste is of rich, roasted malts, coffee, dark fruits and spice.  Heavy bodied, medium carbonation and smooth.  Ending is of a burst of chocolate with notes of caramel and flowers.  Most excellent chocolate stout!!!

Bottle 650 ml. Wow! The aroma is surprisingly and unmistakably sweet chocolate. It reminds me of hot chocolate or delicious cocoa. The body was dark brown and completely opaque.  Produced a nice big creamy caramel head which left heavy lacing on my glass. I really picked up the sweetness and smoothness of the oats and real chocolate. The chocolate malts are bitter but the nose of this stout is decidedly sweet. I picked up some notes of coffee but honestly chocolate is the star here and this stout is a delicious vehicle for it.  Delightfully playing the sweet and bitter without ever losing focus. Medium to full body with a slightly fizzy finish. This stout definitely surpassed my expectations, I am not particularly fond of the other chocolate stouts that I have tried.  It kills me that Rogue beers are so tasty because they are so expensive but I have to grudgingly give it up to them again. Not an everyday beer but I would/will definitely have this one again.

Black coffee/coke color. Smells a little hoppy, chocolatey, with roasted malts. Great texture, not thin, not to thick. Tastes like it smells with a little coffe. Chocolate is a little bitter which is not bad. I love stouts, and this one is no excpetion. Great beer.

This beer pours almost black with a dark head composed of foam and large bubbles.  I dont even see a glint of light comingt through the glass.  The beer smells malty and hoppy at the same time.  There is a chocolate aroma as well, but it isnt too sweet.  The beer tastes of bitter chocolate and coffee.  It is a strong chocolate flavor, but the lack of sweetness makes it very drinkable.  The beer is thick and creamy in the mouth and isnt very carbinated.  Very heavy, but a good beer if that is what you are looking for.

Bottle- poured black, nice head formation.  Aroma of roasted malt with hint of chocolate.  Very full body, smooth chocolate taste and of the malt, slight bitter/hop finish, which compliments the body.  A very nice beer that gets better as it gets warmer.

This beer is very good.  I had one a 49deg F and the flavor was very chocolaty and full of roast malt.  Then I had a second at 40 deg F not bad at this temp but the warmer the one did have much more flavor

The aroma a little hoppy, chocolate, roasted malts. The head is light brown, big and creamy to mostly diminishing. The color is black. The initial flavor is a little bitter, hints of chocolate, kinda of a chestnut flavor. The body is medium and the texture a little watery, the carbonation is soft.

Poured an attractive black color with brown head that lingered.  Aroma is chocolate, but also of Cascade hops.  Flavor is very chocolatey, but the sweetness is balanced well by by the hops.  This was very tasty. Nice lacing on glass.  If you like chocolate, do yourself a favor and try this.  If you dont like chocolate this might convert you.
22 oz. Bomber - Great chocolate aroma.  Pours a deep dark color with a cocoa colored head.  The flavor is of semi-sweet chocolate with a bit of a bit to the finish.  Bittersweet heaven.
Wonderful aroma of dark chocolate and malts with a subtle hop aroma, tastes of subtle bakers chocolate. wonderful beer.

Extra bottle from Pailhead. Black with beige head, appears to be rather thin just looking at it. Aroma dominated by chocolate and buttercream, doesnt seem infected though. Flavor much the same, thins out near the finish. Decent overall.

Strong aroma of creamy chocolate and hops. Wow.  Pitch black with a nice deep tan head.  Beautiful.  Taste is immediately sour and bitter.  Finish is extremely creamy chocolate, with a bitter aftertaste.  Great lacing down the glass.  Mouthfeel is carbonated, not bad.  Great aroma, beautiful beer, a little too bitter.  Nice though.

Pours a perfect opaque black into the English Pint glass.  There was a nice inch of tan head and a thick lacing coating the glass.  The scent was of chocolate cake, malt, light hops and some roasted nuts.  There was a sweet taste up front with a dose of chocolate and malt.  The finish had some bitter notes with some oats, barley and yeast accompanying the chocolate.  Excellent beer.

650ml Bottle: To quote a famous philosopher: "Wowsers!"  Things were promising from the start as the name of the beer are my two favourite food items, so surely it cant be bad, right?  Pours black as your soul, beautiful deep head, looks like cake with whipped cream.  The aroma is just awesome, terrific cocoa sweetness, lots of bitter Cascade hops, I want to cry.  Enough of this, must taste... sweet merciful crap!  Buy this immediately, run over your own children to get it if you have to.  Sweet, roasty, coffee.. wow.  Just wow.
This would be a perfect beer if you need a guaranteed Stout. Creamy finish, roasted, and chocolate flavors. Not my favorite of the style.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Pours black with a nice creamy head that dissipates to a film on the top. Coffee, roasted malts flavor. The chocolate is present but not as strong as I figured. Delicious.

Bottle. Rogue makes some good beers and this is their best and my favorite sweet stout. This beer is so thick on the pour with a great oil black color and a light brown head. Taste is amazing - sweet originally, then you notice the roasted coffee malt with a hersheys syrup and caramal hints. Just amazing
This is the beer that introduced me to the beer world.  A great chocolate stout with flavors of dark chocolat, roasted malt, and tobacco.  Also,  used to make ice cream - You should try.

OK, Im a little biased...I love Rogue, and I love chocolate. But anyway. Bomber pours oily black with a well-retained brown head. Nose is almost completely chocolate, but hints of roasted malt and slight espresso sneak in. Tastes big dark chocolate, a hint of milk chocolate, and a touch of vanilla to round it out. Tastes a bit thinner as it warms, but the flavors come out as well. All in all, another great stout from Rogue.

On draught at the Issaquah brewhouse.  Aroma is sweet chocolate forward with lots of caramel and light dark fruit and no hops.  Appearance is dark brown with a well retained tan head.  Flavor is a sweet, carbonic roast malt blend followed by a slight caramel flavor.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with very low texture of carbonation and roast grains.  Overall, I wasnt overly impressed, but my wife loved it.  It was just too simple.

pours black with a one finger stiff brown head. aroma is chocolate malt, cocoa powder, and a touch of hops. has a medium to full body with good lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger and the taste is like Hershey syrup. has a little bite from the hops, and they hit a bit more at the end and in the aftertaste. not bad i like it i have been looking for a stout that tastes like this. as it warms has a touch of coffee here and there especially in the aftertaste, which lasts awhile on the tongue. also all the flavors and aromas turn a little from syrup to cocoa powder more. and the aroma is a little stronger as well. just a touch thin here and there in the mouth but is made up at the end and aftertaste. my second rogue beer and i am very impressed with this one.

Bottle: Pours very dark brown with a big fluffy light brown head. Wonderful milk and dark chocolate aroma, a little roast in there as well. Slightly malty flavor with lots of chocolatey goodness. Slight roasted coffee notes and hints of oats too. Some hoppy bitterness in the finish. Sweet and dry and bittersweet at the sametime. Wonderfully balanced.

Pours a serious black.  Completely opaque.  Aroma is wonderful.  Mellow roasted chocolate, smooth and rich, smells sweet with some oats.  I think i smelled this beer for 10 minutes.  Mouthfeel is creamy, almost frothy.  Flavor is very rich, roasted malts and mellow smooth chocolate.  Finishes bittersweet with some hops and coffee flavor.  Only complaint is the finish is a tad watery, but overall I think this is an amazing beer, thats truly rich and enjoyable.
Chocolate aroma with coffee,black, aminimal head, tan foam, full body, creamy.Excellent, more chocolate than Youngs. but still not enough for me.

big chocolate flavor that is balanced perfectly. much better than the other two chocolate stouts ive had in the past which tasted like fake chocolate was just thrown in...  great smooth feeling over the tongue. not much in the smell other than chocolate i guess.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2008 On tap at the Rogue Public House. Damn...I wish Id bought more when this was available at the LCBO. Smooth drinking and pleasant mouth feel. Melted chocolate, with hints of smoke and coffee. Extremely drinkable and highly recommended!

I liked this more and more as I drank it. At first sip, I thought the Rogue Chocolate Stout tasted artificial, as if the chocolate was added later as a flavor. Was also disappointed with the aftertaste: seemed too short and not deep enough. I expected a longer, more robust, richer, roasted flavor throughout: a bigger body in other words. Would also have liked more bitterness, but hey, Im not the brewer. After my initial impressions wore off I started to really appreciate this beer. The mouthfeel is excellent, actually, and shows that Rogue definately know what theyre doing. Lacing on the glass is nice too.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 Bottle labled as Bitter Chocolate Bear from Ezo Beer.  Gotta love all the different lables Rogue is offered under in Japan.  Pours like sludge, black with a small brown head.  Aroma is full.  Sweet chocolate, malts, roasted, oats.  Full, chewy, smooth body.  Bittersweet cocoa, roasted malts, some smoke.  Finishes bitter, with a cola like bite.  Would liked to have seen a little more complexity, but a good brew regardless.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2010 
Date: March 11, 2001
Mode: Bottle
Source: Belmont Station, Portland
Appearance: pours thick and slow producing a glass of black oil with a thick tan head
Aroma: strong aroma of a mocca espresso
Body: rich creamy body
Flavor: lots of chocolate flavor, big bitter finish thats out of place

Date: February 16, 2010
Mode: cask
Words: tmac woodstock
Aroma: strong dark chocolate aroma, caramel sweetness brings out the chocolate
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, touch of roasted, a bit dry

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

Poured opaque black with an ample tan head that receeded quickly. the nose was of cocoa, chocolate, ginger and a roasted smokiness. The flavor began with a dark carmel, roasty maltiness then opens up with an stunning coffee/cocoa bitterness. The finish was cocoa dry and cherry-cola like, leaving lingering bitter chocolate notes. A very good example of a chocolate stout.

Draft @ Loon Lake Lodge - Aroma and flavor are pretty much the same, which in this case is not a bad thing.  Tons of roasted chocolate malts, oats, dark chocolate and just a touch of hops.  Pours black with a small brown head and good lacing.  Palate was creamy and smooth.  Very tasty brew that didnt taste artificial like some chocolate stouts.
Poured a dark murky brown color with little to no head. Full bodied with a oily feel. Tasted like chocolate and had a roasted nut after taste. It is not bad, I am not a huge fan of flavored beer.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2008 puored a very dark brown with a small (1/4 inch) caramel colored head.  smelled like fudge and coffee.  very heavy on the palate with a strong aftertaste of dark chocolate.  my 3rd beer from rogue and im quite impressed.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2007 Thick oily pour with cola-ish head that hangs around for quite a while, leaving a wispy lacing. Has a bitter dark chocolate aroma, with cocoa malts entwined with some peaty malts. Tastes richly of unsweetened cocoa. Not at all what I was expecting, but thats not a bad thing at all. Very distinct flavor of chalky sprouts and dark grass, all smoked with birch wood. Lighter palate than expected, but holding its own distinctness. None of this "Swiss-Miss" hogwash; real cocoa beans up in the hizzy, ya dig? Extra points for representing the expected super-sweet chocolate milk stout cliche with a bittersweet masterpiece! Sans coffee!

bottle...bomber...poured black with a big dark brown head...aroma of chocolate and bisquits and coffee...chocolaty, roasty, smoothie....slight sweet bitter in the finish with a touch of alcohol....very rich tasting...I love this beer...I need someone to help me finish it....I hope it goes with the fried egg sandwiches Im dining on tonight

Pours a dark black coffee color.Choco- malt aroma wtih oats. Mild small tan bubbled head. Cappacino at the end of a medium to large bodied mouthfeel. The oats add a nice silkiness. Plenty of chocolate but enough supporting flavors to keep it a beer first. Nice job.

Bottle at 3-små rum Göteborg: Black colour, with a nice creamy head. Aroma of chocolate,lots of hops, flowers and vanilla. Flavor is almost the same,dark choclate,and coffee,medium body,and a dry hopy medium finish. Nice,and easy drinking.

Bottle, poured bubbly with a frothy porridge coloured head, a dark, deep chocolate aroma. PACKS A PUNCH, a serious bite, there is no milk chocolate involved, pure cocoa, on second sup *just like Youngs* it has a wonderful malt and chocolate flavour with a spicey finish. Very enjoyable, for the serious stout lover

Draft
What a night for great beer. Started light with the wimpy beers ended with this deep dark black nectar for the gods.  The aroma was thick with chocolate and coffee.  Loved the flavor of his deep rich malts and chocolate and other slight spices.    This beer finishes sweet and flavorful and makes you want more.  This was a great Stout.  Loved this beer.

Chocolate indeed!
this stout is like drinking a liquid Hersheys bar... way too over the top on the chocolate for my taste

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2008 old rating: 8/4/7/3/15 - 3.7.

pours a black with a large brown head, excellent lacing.

smells of sweet milk chocolate, toasted almonds, and smores???

taste is smooth, milk chocolate, fudge brownie, and milk chocolate, also has a slight coffee to it, some vanilla, touch of nuts, ends a little bitter and a little sweet.

Pours solid black with deep brown head.  Aroma is of dark chocolate and roast.  Flavor is a little dry and not that profound.  A nice evenly paced beer that appears threatening, but doesnt have much of a bite.

On tap at Issaquah brewhouse.  Shakespeare with chocolate!  Very strong bittersweet chocolate on nose, tongue, finish, and memory.  Nary a hop bitter flavor, strictly a dessert beer.  Some gritty texture like theres baking chocolate in the glass.

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a shaker.  This stout poured an opaque black with a huge, rocky, tan head that slowly faded away.  Some creamy lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of this stout was made up of rich chocolate, light spicy hop notes, and some roasted malt.  The flavor was dominated by the chocolate.  Some excellent roastiness also arrived towards the end, then finished with a mild lasting bitterness.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation.  A very nice stout.  Highly recommended for chocolate lovers.

Holy cow...baking chocolate OVERLOAD. This beer is like a rich piece of chocolate cake that you can only take in small doses. Im only half thru my 22 oz and I dont think I will make it. I cant understand how anyone can think the chocolate taste is mild?!?! Yes, the beer is pretty hoppy and balanced and the chocolate taste isnt sweet at all (as I thought it would...ala Youngs Double Chocolate). The mouthfeel is kind of gritty, like hot chocolate with too much mix in it. The appearance, as mentioned before, looks EXACTLY like used motor oil on the pour...as dark as dark can be, with a nice decent head with little lacing. This beer is really too much for me. Kind of like Dick says below...nice looking, nice smelling...but the most important quality (taste) didnt appeal to me. Def. my least favorite Rogue of the handful Ive tried so far.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2007 Black with with big, foamy head / Toasty chocolate nose / Medium body with gentle spritz and lingering chocolate finish / Sharp flavors of bittersweet chocolate (Hersheys syrup), prunes, root beer, roast barley, and cinnamon / A spectucular, unique piece of brewing.
Very, Very, dark thick beer. dark tan head. Lots of chocolate, lots of dark malts. Lots of flavor. Wonderful malty and mellow finish. A really good beer

Oily black/brown with nice tan head leaving nice lacing.  Chocolate roasted malts, smokey chalky aromas with light hoppy-marshmellow scents.  The taste leaves a dusty burnt mocha with lite-hop finish.  NIce body and a light warming sensation.  The hops provide balance to the sugary malts and produce a drying, lingering hoppy finish.

Appearance- nice black color with a beautiful tan head. 

Smell- Can smell dark chocolate and coffee. Roasted malts maybe. 

Taste- Again, CHOCOLATE! Wow this is great. I can also taste a coffee flavor as well. 

Mouthfeel- A very smooth medium body beer. 

Drinkability- This beer is fantastic! It would be awesome to drink in the winter time. I think when my wife is drinking hot cocoa Ill be drinking this!
bottle. it is a black color with a large head. the aroma is clearfully lots of lots of chokolate. taste is lots of chokolate with a slightly hoppy note.
UPDATED: JUN 6, 2010 Bottle. Had this after the seahorse ale. Pours a pitch black body - the aroma smells strong of chocolate.  The taste is chocolate and roastiness.

Pours ddep brown with a light brown head. Lots of chocolate in the aroma, almost smells like chocolate chip cookies. Bittersweet chocolate right upfront with hops hitting you afterwards. A little harsh in the beginning of the bottle. Aftertaste leaves the dark chocolate flavor in your mouth.

Pours a dark black color with a nice dark brown head. Aroma is full of chocolate malts. The aroma is full of sweet milk chocolate, and hints of cookie malts. Hints of hops come in as well. The flavor is chocolate malts through and through, some hop bitterness sneaks into to make the beer not overly sweet. Definitely a nice dessert beer but cannot drink several of these.
Thick beige head with a dark as night color. Chocolate on the nose of the milky variety. Chocolatey with some hop character. Nice on the palate with a good but not complex finish. Good beer .

22 oz Bomber. Poured into a pint glass with a cookie brown head and rich dark brown color. A Medium creamy head brought on a great initial appearance. Aroma of slight hops notes mixing with a roasted chocolate overlay. Initial taste is begins with a quick bitter hop moving strongly forward into a rich creamy chocolate sensation. Oats are apparent but not overwhelming. Medium body. Palate is long lasting with a surrounding grassy hop with mixing of chocolate. Seems the two are battling to take ones place for the finish which makes it very interesting. Lacing of the glass was minimal and the head disapates to just a small tan ring down the to the last sip. The carbonation on my bottle seem rather high, it was very fizzy and at some points was overwelming the elements of the beer.

Dark pour with a creamy tan head that fades away. Chocolate aroma with a hint of hops. Very good mouth and smoth. I got the chocolate taste at the finish of the beer.  The finish was deep smoky chocolate but very suttle. Will drink again and again

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2010 22oz bottle served in a Duvel tulip.  Pours very dark brown/black with a large brown head that leaves globs of lacing and reduces to a rocky island and ring.  Aroma features layers of chocolate, dark chocolate, bakers chocolate, chocolate syrup, chocolate milk.  There is a bit of earthy hops, coffee, roasted malt and bread underneath all that chocolate.  Sometimes there is a bit of a sour milk and smoke characteristic on the nose.  Flavor is quite chocolaty, not as strong as the nose, fair amount of bitterness, some caramel, roasted malt, a bit acidic.  Mouthfeel is a little thin, but soft, low carbonation.  Good for a chocolate fix.

Original Rating July 7, 2007.
22oz bottle poured into a goblet.  Pours a dark brown with a small tan head that doesnt last long.  Chocolate, chocolate, chocolate dominates the aroma and flavor...big surprise.  The most chocolaty beer Ive had to date.  Smooth, creamy mouthfeel with medium carbonation.  Very smooth.  Im a fan of stouts and this one is quite nice...would definitely buy again.
Aroma 8/10, Appearance 3/5, Taste 8/10, Palate 4/5, Overall 17/20.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2007 Bottle.  Dark, coffee pour with a tan head. Aroma is mellow and chocolatey.  Like cold hot chocolate smells, if you added hops and alcohol.  Flavor tastes like watered chocolate milk.  Not complex or interesting, but tasty, in my opinion.  I dont usually enjoy Rogues brews, but this one was decent.

1000th rater.  Been waiting a bit for this honey.  22oz bomber, not terribly fresh, picked it up in a store I figure has had it for more than a year on the self.  As usual I love the silk screen bottles and the community aspect this brewery provides. I pour it into my Chimay Goblet glass, I just think this beer (and most Rogue beers) deserve better than the English pint as suggested by Ratebeer or the mug that is hoisted on the label.  Pours black with a small but present tan head.  It soon fades to a strong lacing that is super sticky to the sides of this goblet.  A very presentable beer from bottle to glass.  Aroma is strong and what hits me first, surprisingly, is actually a stinging hop bite of pine trees.  Then comes the rush of chocolate, which comes as a shock because it was hops that my nose first picked up.  The chocolate overwhelms any sense of hoppiness.  And its not just your regular candy bar chocolate but a very bittersweet, naturally creamy, and a bit harsh kind of chocolate.  Its a type of chocolate that little kids would kind of not enjoy.  Taking a step back to the hoppiness I pick up, I am always amazed how Rogues hop profile stands up to age.  Its as if they threw in a whole lots of hops and said well lets pack as much damn chocolate in here as possible.  Trying to see what they can fill the beer up more with, hops or choclate.  Not that the chocolate is overbearing but again when its not artificial it can only be good.  So overall its a chocolate stout with a forest feel that comes from the piney hops and the real, bitter chocolate.  Now to the taste.  Does not start off with an onslaught of chocolate as one would think. More like creamy chocolate accented thick maltiness (thick shake beer), which then rolls off into a lighter, piney, excited spiky flavor.  Starts off soothing and sweet with a felt presence on the palate and ends up light and wild jumping all over your cheeks, from the hops.  Mouthfeel is nice, a very creamy texture almost like chocolate milk but then halfway down one feels the carbonation and it ends with a medium-light hop bitterness to round it off an bring it all back into the beer realm.  Leaves a long, lightly chocolate milk, and lightly piney expressive aftertaste.  One downside, I get a slight mineral quality at the end of the taste.  Its this battle between chocolate and piney hops that embodies the whole beer and the brewers at Rogue found the best middle ground so they can both shine.  This is also probably where other "chocolate" beers go astray, they forget to offset the chocolate.  No hint of alcohol at all, one could drink this and completely forget that its really above a session beers abv, I think I am starting to feel it now.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Very nice brown head and good dark color.  Sweet delicious chocolate taste.   All in all a good stout and a nice offering from Rogue.  22 oz. bottle.

Pitch Black with a Thick brown head. Sweet chocolate to the nose, but not as perfumy as other chocolat stouts. The flavour is of chocolate but with a nice hoppyness to counteract and support it. Dry finish.

Pitch black pour with a chocolaty-brown head.  Smells of chocolate and malt with some coffee as well.  Chocolate isnt nearly as prevailing as some chocolate beers, which I like.  It mixes nicely with the other flavors.  Very good beer.
Black of color with a nice brown head. An aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. A flavor of coffee, roasted malt, liqurice and chocolate.

Less chocolate and less malt than Youngs Double Chocolate, which I prefer slightly to this.  Aroma and flavor was all chocolate and vanilla for me with a little bitter finish.  Definitely a 4 though.

Deep dark brown ale with a medium brown frothy head.  Aroma of burnt chocolate and vanilla.  Flavor of lots of dark toasted chocolate, oats, caramel, and some vanilla.  As it warmed it became more subtle on the tongue.  Sweet then bitter on the finish.  Not a bad stout but "Ive had better".

First try 6/24/07.  650 ml bottle.  Black pour with a medium sized dark tan to light brown head.  Aroma is an excellent mix of sweet chocolate and rich roasted malts.  Flavor is complex, with both bitter and sweet chocolate up front, followed by a smooth coffee and oatmeal finish. Great balance of sweet and bitter flavors.

Hell of a brown head with a blackish, unfiltered body. Smells mostly like dark chocolate and awesomeness. The taste of a little bitter chocolate is right up at the front, but aside from that there are some hops and a bunch of roasted malts. There is also a little oatmeal stout thrown into the mix. Very good, in fact, very, very good.
Rouge = fantastic. Dark brown black with small tan head. Full aroma of chocolate malts. Taste is medium to full bodies with roasted malts and chocolate. Nice bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2007 This was a great beer; dark black colour, brown head that doesnt last long, and a great taste.  My only problem was that I couldnt taste the chocolate until the end but I was eating a pizza at the beggining so that could have affected the flavor.  I drank this from a shaker

Its been a while since Ive tried a Rogue beer and wow what I was missing. I passed this up many times looking for more obscure and hard to find imports and what a mistake. Aroma is strong and full. Smells like chocolate milk. Dark chocolate milk. Pour was perfect. A deep black with a 2 finger milky tan head.  Taste was milky and thick, but nicely carbonated. Tasted like chocolate and milk with the bubbles burning the top of my mouth. Bitter aftertaste and now much sweetness (which is the only thing I would change). Fantastic!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: This is by far the best chocolate stout I have tried to date. (keep in mind that these reviews are off notes from long ago and my palate is much different now than then) The chocolate flavor is smooth and perfect as far as I am concerned. If there is another one out there that is better, I cant wait to try it. As far as appearance goes it is dark brown with a thick head.
Great beer! Pours a rich inky black color. With a big think bubbly brown head. Smells of chocolate and maple syrup and tastes like espresso and roasted malt. A truly great brew.

22 oz. Bottle. Chocolate smell is first thing to hit me as I open.  Pours dark stout color, and I believe I see threads of chcolate syrup as I pour, too. As dark tan a head.as Ive ever seen, and quite rocky (oatmeal influence?).  Taste is big on chocolate indeed, but also has overabundance of tannins from chocolate roast malts. Perhaps therein lies the difference between this and a Sam Adams Chocolate Bock. Notable hop match to keep the cocoa in check.
Beautiful chocolate aroma.  Rich and roasty with a sweet chocolate backbone.  Carbonation a little too high which detracts from the smoothness.

This beer really looks, smells, and taste like chocolate.  The initial pour has a medium head which looks and smells like a chocolate malt. The taste is that of a dark chocolate, which gets smoother as you progress through the beer. Very tasty.

Appearance: Pours black with brown highlights and a sizeable cappuccino head, which while its initially rather pillowly, doesnt last for very long.

Smell: I havent had one of these in awhile, but friends, I can tell you quite categorically... it smelled exactly as I remembered.

Largely black roasted malts blended with toasted caramel, a rich earthiness, and just the merest amount of hops.

Taste: Sweeping chocolate taste (as in a bakers chocolate, not the overly sweet chocolate youd get at Easter as a kid), with a dash of espresso and a hint of almond. The finish is slightly bitter and plentiful, reminiscent of a fresh espresso or a fine cocoa powder.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin; a bit lighter than I would prefer. Thankfully, its not overly fizzy, keeping it creamier on the tongue.

Drinkability: Phenomenally well-balanced, and very drinkable. A good stout is tough to beat, thats for sure. 

Still though, you put a gun to my head and say "name your #1"? I dunno. Gotta go, like, double stout. Or strong ale. Or a nice lambic. Or a good juicy IPA. 

Or a barleywine! 

Yes, maybe its that. 

Maybe its a barleywine.

Still though, this is a darned good stout!

Pours black with a nice tall dense tan head.  Lots of rich dark chocolate aroma with just a hint of roast.  Flavor is also mostly dark chocolate with some coffee and bitter roastiness.  Medium body with a fair amount of carboantion.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 Bottle. Opaque black with a medium-sized and lasting, dark brown sugar head. Aroma is definitely dark chocolate-cocoa, but has some citrus hop peeking through as well. Wow, flavor is not-too-sweet chocolate and bitter hops. I love chocolate and this is definitely chocolate! I think I was hoping for sweeter, but that probably wouldnt be very drinkable as a beer. As is, this one is definitely drinkable! Great job Rogue.
Strong chocolate aroma with a very dark body and a brown head. Malty and chocolaty flavor, decent stout.

Bottle, 22oz. The aroma has a distinct nose of sweet chocolate. The head is dark brown and very chocolatelike. The flavor is sweet chocolate (is beer is not drunk too cold). The mouthfeel is rich and the chocolateflavor fills the mouth.
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Best served cold. Lovely chocolate arome and taste, nothing too overwhelming. Rogue makes very solid beers, this is no exception. A good introduction to chocolate beers.

Rated 12/9/06:  Rich floral aroma with a dark bitter chocolate scent. Black pour with a 3/4" head that settles down to a solid 1/4", but no lacing ouch. Mouthfeel is much thinner than anticipated, finish is primarily bitter. Flavor is decent, the chocolate doesnt come through as much as in the aroma and the bittering hops seem to have a tight grasp on the taste. Overall this is not one of my top picks, kind of bummed out. The regular Shakespeare is much better. Ill be using whats left in the bomber to make a black and tan, Cheers!
Robe noire surmontée dune mousse beige qui sestompe. Arômes de chocolat sucré. Saveurs de café et de chocolat.
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2007 Good stout overall.  Nothing special.  A little more bland than most chocolate stouts.  Otheerwise, identical to most other stouts in aroma, appearance and mouthfeel.

Big thanks to Matt for this extra! Pours a dark brown almost black with a bubbly brown head that lasted. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste was much of the same. Roasted malt to start with chocolate flavor throughout. Also had hints of hops. Excellent brew.

22 oz. bomber pours a semi-transparent brownish-amber color with a rocky tan head.  Bakers chocolate along with some roasted malt in the aroma.  Dry mid-grade chocolate and espresso taste together with the aforementioned malts.  Not much of a finish to it, just seemed to dissipate too quickly.  Decent.

Bomber in Atlanta, shared with Clinton, served cold in a wine glass. MA05/07.
App.:  BLACK, no light transmission, decent tight mocha head.
  
Aroma:  initial impression is vinous and fruity, sour cherries and tangy; milk chocolate-ish aroma after that; some vanilla and darker chocolate/cocoa as it warms.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft carbonation with some sharpness, light powderiness but smooth overall.
  
Flav.:  lots of chocolate, but not all in a good way; some licorice and molasses, dark roasted malts; finishes with more obvious chocolate, some stone fruits, cocoa and darker chocolate; somewhat powdery with good bitterness.

Drinkable, but a bit simple and underwhelming.  I question using added flavours...
[bottle] Dark brown (almost black) colour. Thick head. Wonderful chocolate bar aroma. Malty, roasted flavour long chocolate bitter finish.

22oz. Bomber
$4.99
Health Mart

Finally getting around to trying this. Its been on my list to pick up many times but I always seem to pass it by, since its always available, in favor of seasonals or special releases. Poured black with a big 3 finger brown, creamy, ruddy head. I cant see a thing through this beer. Leaves spotty lacing throughout the entire drink.

This stuff smells amazing. Big notes of chocolate and cream. Mildly roasted barley and a small hint of coffe beans. Smells like dessert in a bottle. Fantastic.

Flavor has all the qualities of the aroma with a little extra. Starts off with the creamy milk chocolate. Roasted malts and coffee grounds come through mid-palate as the chocolate starts to fall back. On the swallow theres a mild hop spiciness and coffee ground bitterness. 

Medium bodied and somewhat creamy. Lively in the back of the throat. My only complaint, and its a very small one, is the mouthfeel could stand to be a little more creamy. Still very nice though.

This chocolate stout is an easy one to put back. Wonderful flavor and aromas make it a pleasure to drink.

Im surprised at how good this stout really is. I wasnt sure if it could live to the hype or not. I wish I would have picked this up sooner. Another great beer from Rogue.

2/25/07

Deep black with vigorous light brown head. Nice lace. Aroma is coffee and a hint of hops. Predominant flavor is roast coffee. But the chocolate is there. Some bitterness at the finish, like a very dark european chocolate.

Bottle: Opaque black with a rich creamy dark brown head. The aroma is rich and robust, full of roasty malts. Chocolatey, milky, with a hint of cascade hops. Appetizing. Tight carbonated body, with a nice roasty flavor throughout. Dark chocolate malts mesh nicely with a surprisingly hoppy character; especially for a sweet stout. Later flavors show some bitter dark chocolate, burnt peat and a late coffeeish bitterness that lingers. A solid, hoppy/bitter example of the style.

22 oz bomber pours a dark brown with a beige head.  The nose is really nice brown sugar, sweet, toffee, taffe, bakers chocolate, molasses, carmel and candy.  All very distinct and really nice.  The flavors have some of the similar notes but more chocolate overwhelming it, with a dry bakers chocolate finish.  I am surprisingly pleased with this one, definitely one of the best sweet stouts ive ever had.

From bomber to becker at cold temp.  Color is opaque black with light brown head, quite a bit actually. Transmitted color is deep ruby.  Decent amount of lacing.  Sweet chocolate aroma is very pleasing.  Medium to thick mouthfeel leaving a slick, tacky coated palate.  Tons of sediment.  I love Dead Guy Ale, and this is another solid offering.  Good amout of bittering balancing the sweet.  Not really a sipper, but not something youd want to slam either; drinkability is excellent.  A little heavy on the belly, but its a chocolate stout, so thats understandable.  Great quality; nothing fake or cloying here. Definitely would try again!  Not a lot going on with this, but still interesting.  Could be considered a good baseline/benchmark for the style.

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Dark brown color with a average fizzy fair mostly lasting light brown head. Aroma is moderate malty, milk chocolate, sweet, vanilla. Initail flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, finish flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate metallic bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is soft.

Pours a dark black with a small beige head. Aroma has plenty of chocolate with hints of vanilla. Flavour is equally sweet, with lots of nice chocolate - great balance, as it does not become too clingy or too sweet. Nice!

how have i not rated this yet?  one of those thats slipped through the cracks i guess?  Sweet chocolate, with hints of coffee and vanilla.  Pours black, very black with a thin tan head.  Cafe mocha anyone?  Strong chocolate and coffee with a bakers chocolate bitter finish.  One that stands out in the Rogue lineup.  Very good on draft with a scoop of vanilla ice cream!
Bomber. Dark brown pour with a large head. Fair lacing. Aroma is dominated by chocolate. Mostly sweet, with a nicely bitter finish. Creamy texture. One-dimensional, but fairly nice.

650ml bottle, $5.49.  Aroma is chocolate malt and moderately hoppy.  Average sized, light brown, mostly diminishing head that left virtually no lace.  Body is dark brown and black.  Flavor starts moderately sweet and finishes same and moderately bitter.  Finish is average.  Palate is light to medium bodied and watery flat.  Lots of chocolate flavor in this beer and surprisingly also alot of hopps.  Interesting but not one Id buy again.

Pours like melted chocolate--black and thick; very thick and frothy brown head; nice lacing; moderate carbonation; bitter start and very bitter finish; not as malty as expected; above average brew but by far not the best from Rogue

Tap... Poured an opaque black with a light brown head, nice and frothy and nice lacing.  Strong malt, and sugary chocolate on the nose.  Very minimal on carbonation (if any) and flavors of roasted barley malt, chocolate, hazelnut, and a tad of hops to make it a little crisp. Very smooth finish.

22 oz bottle-pours a foamy brown head and black color.  Aroma is rich dark chocolate/cocoa, some cherry.  Nice.  Taste is rich dark chocolate/cocoa, some cherry, secondary bitter/metallic hops, chalky.  Finishes bitter and chalky.  Plenty of effervescence/carbonation.
Good chocolate and alcohol aroma.  welvet smooth palate.  Creamy sweet taste with a slightly bitter and long lingering dry chocolate finish.  A great stout!

Deep black color, short brown head. Aroma of chocolat, chocolat and chocolat. Only some minor other notes survive, like some hop, some roasted malt. Not really sweet taste, more bitter. Milk chocolat present, some roasted notes, bit coffee like. Chocolat is dominant, but not too overwhelming in this beer, perfect balance. I like it very much!
Bottle. aroma of chocolate. This beer is loaded with chocolate taste. I can only have one or two in a night, way to heavy.

Bottle.  Aroma of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt; definitely sweet smelling.  The carbonation is a little too heavy.  The flavor is pretty similar to the smells, but it is dominated by the roasted chocolate malt.  Bittering hops present in the finish.

Great looking pour, oily, opaque black with a thick, lacing, creamy tan head.  Smells like... chocolate... and grain, and malty, but very soft aroma.  Flavor is wonderfully blanced; nutty, malty, grainy, chocolatey sweet.  Finish is velvety soft, subtle but a lasting malt flavor.  A great example of how a specialty beer can be unique while also maintaining balance.

Pours a true black with a frothy, lasting, tan head. Nice lacing. The aroma is as advertised: mostly a heavy roasted, bitter chocolate and molasses. The palate is medium-bodied and oily with a dry metallic finish. The flavor is all about the malts. Dominated by the taste of burnt or bitter chocolate it has a long finish that lingers on the tongue like a good cigar or pipe tobacco. Another great beer from Rogue. Ive already bought another bottle.
Pours black with a small tan head.Lots of carbonation.Chocolate, caramel and smoke aromas.Chocolate and burnt malts on the taste.A small bitter and smoky finish.

heavy carbonation. malted chocolate milkshake. false bittersweet cocoa flavoring with a dry hop finish.  too sweet and disappointing...chocolate flavoring???? 
drink guinness while eating a chocolate bar and you will get a better flavor...  mmm, guinness
This is one amazong stout.  It pours deep black.  It aroma of bitter chocolate and coffee make turn the same flavors plus a hint of oats and hps on the finish....A PERFECT BALANCE!

Bottle. 22 FL. OZ.  Black color with large, brown, rocky head. A good looking beer.  Aroma is very roasted malty and chocolatey.  Medium bodied with a creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a light bitter finish.  Sweetness followed by a lingering bittersweet finish. A dessert in itself. Very good.
22 oz bottle.  Dark brown, smelled of real dark chocolate.  Taste is chocolate some roastiness, balancing hops.  Pretty good.

Nice opaque black pour with a big foamy red hued head.  Very pretty, Head fades too fast.  I know a chocolate malt aroma, but there is real chocolate aroma in here.  Nice and full bodied, the chocolate flavor is present and smooth, the chocolate malts are mellow, not as strong as I like them.  The chocolate in the aroma led me to expect some additional sweetness to be there, but this is not sweet.  Finish is long and lingers.  Very Unique, very good.

22 ounce bottle.  Almost opaque black with a lasting frothy light brown head.  Nice looking.  Pretty light on the aroma side.  The chocolate comes of like obvious extract to me.  Theres some slight coffee, and a good punch of hops in the flavor.  Palate is okay.  easy to drink.  Not something Id want to drink again though.

A little thin. The chocolate is almost a little overbearing in the aroma. I like the bitterness and dark chocolate in the aroma and flavor, but the body is a little thin with high carbonation. A little one dimensional for me, but still a very pleasant desert drink, especially considering its moderate ABV. The 22 oz. bomber is to be shared.

A little overrated IMO.  Looks like a typical stout.  Black with light brown head.  More carbonation than what I expect from a stout.  Chocolate aroma is present as expected.  Mouthfeel is kind of light for a stout.  I think it must be the carbonation.  A pretty good beer overall.

Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a thin tan head.  Has strong smell of chocolate, coffee, and some malts.  The taste of chocolate is good throughout.  It is a thicker bodied beer, but finishes nice and sweet.  Definitely better on tap than in bottle.
Dark rich body and creamy head.  Wonderful coffee and chocolate aroma.  slightly bitter finish.
Deep and dark with a fluffy head.  Smells very sweet, a little piney, with lots of chocolate.  Very sweet to start, chocolate, surprisingly bitter finish.  A tasty brew.

22 oz bottle. Black body with a beige head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malt. Flavor is chocolate, sweet malt and a hint of coffee. Very well balanced and not to extreme on the chocolate even if its a lot of it.
From bottle pours almost black, with a good amount of brown head.  Flavor more of coffee then chocolate.  Good finish.

aroma was of dark chocolate and coffee.  appearence was dark black with a brown head.  flavor was of dark chocolate and with some bitterness from the hops and roasted barly.  I really like this flavor combination.  nice think palate.  great brew

Bottle, 6.0% at Ma Che Siete Venuti a Fà, Rome. Creamy caramel/butterscotch aroma. Black colour, small light brown head. Creamy flavour, bitter chocolate and some barley bitterness. A little aroma hops to flavour, as well.
Smells like Hersheys syrup.  Flavor is like fine dark chocolate.  Oats smooth out the mouthfeel nicely.

22 oz. Bomber. Pours as dark as Ive seen yet. The old cliche of used motor oil comes to mind. A 1/2" tan head with nice thick lacing that coated the glass. Nice mouth feel, not the oilly feeling one sometimes gets with a beer this dark. You can taste the flaver of unsweet chocolate, especially when the glass begins to warm. I have not had the Shakespeare Stout, but I was told that this is the same recipe only with chocolate added. Will buy this again.

bomber...pours black with a frothy tan head that goes about half and inch and laces the glass well...On the palate this is a smooth and creamy drink until the finish then it is kind of bitter and beautifully mouth coating. The hops balance the sweetness an make this quite a tasty stout!

I love big chocolate flavors in stouts, so this one caught my attention. It was a while ago when I had it, but from what I remember it was pretty decent. good malt flavor with a sweeeet dark chocolate finish and good carbonation. dry alcohol on the palate with some hoppy bitterness on the end. Agree with jarspag, better than the Shakespeare

UPDATED: APR 16, 2007 I think this one is better than the Shakespeare - same recipe i believe, with much more flavor and not the dry, hoppy finish, which I def do not like so much in a stout.  One of the better beers Ive had from Rogue!

Pours an opaque dark brown with a thick brown head that sticks around.  Aroma is earthy, like cocoa powder.  Initial taste is muted by the lively carbonation on the tongue, but obviously bittery sweet.  Finish is a bit more savory...the chocolate taste matures a bit and the bitterness really kicks in.  A very great drinking experience.
Pours dark brown w/thick brownish head.  Smells...like chocolate.  Tastes....like chocolate.  Shocker.  Bitterish but pretty good.
UPDATED: APR 13, 2007 Bottle.Large dark tan head.Smells like chocolate,coffee.Light sweetness.Bitterness to balance.A bit thin bodied.Good flavor.Pretty good overall.

Bomber.  Chocolate in the nose with just a bit of roasted malt as well.  Chocolate dominates the flavor and kind of puts everything else on the back burner.  This is a good stout, I just feel like they added too much chocolate to it.  Id rather go for the Shakespeare stout if I want a stout from Rogue.

Bottle.  Small tan head (fully diminishing).  Black body.  Strong Chocolatey aroma.  Also some toasted grainy malts.  Flavors are initially semi bitter and finishes semi sweet with some bitterness.  Long flavor duration.  Light bodied.  Watery textured.  Lively carbonation.  This is a very solid stout...nothing that stands out...other than the chocolate.

Poors very attractive swirling browns throughout a sumptious head.  Head condenses in a creamy froth.  Opacque, almost black.  Very faint smell.  Good carbonation from bottle, but not thick enough body.  Tastes wonderful, like jamocha almond fudge, but grapefruit flavors start to come in as it warms, overpowering the chocolate towards  the end.  Nice balancing bitterness and moderate abv make this an easy guzzler too.
Bottle. Black with brown head which quickly disapears. Lots of chocolate in the aroma. Lots of chocolate and cocoa in the flavour.
Dark brown with a tan head.  Tastes and smells of chocolate malt of course.  Sweet and delicious.  One step down from Youngs.
Bought at Trader Joes Alexandria. VA, $3. Chocolate and espresso mouth feel with dry finish. Beautiful cloudy head. Great dessert beer.

Strong showing from Rogue. Very nice big initial chocolate that washes over your tongue, finishing with a balanced (i.e. not cloyingly syrupy) mouthfeel. I appreciate this even though other have labeled it thin. Tough to tell what else was going on besides chocolate but caramel is a possibility perhaps.

Draught - black with a brown head that quickly dissipates to a slick of small bubbles on the surface.  Aroma is all chocolate with similar initial big chocolate flavor with caramel and vanilla hints then finishes bitter chocolate.  Palate was a bit thin.

Bottle.  Poured a jet black, with medium brown head.  Aroma was one of the best "chocolate" aromas Ive had; aroma of sweet chocolate and vanilla. Hint of caramel.  Initial roasted malt and then a bitter chocolate takes over.  Mouthfeel could have been better; a little stickier or full bodied would have been ideal for me.  Warmed up to it a bit over time, but not an elite beer for me.

Currently my favorite brew.  Probably the best beer we can get comercially in MS unless I dont know of another kicking beer available here.  Aroma is very nice not too strong, but lets ya know whats comming.  Beautiful beer, pours black with nice toasted tan head with staying power!  Flavors of mild nuts and coffee linger as the smooth chocolate takes over.  Chocolate flavor lingers on the toung, in the mouth, and dominates the palate.  The mouthfeel is very good and the hops are almost nondiscernable.  Truely a fine beer for any beer lover.  Heres to the Rouge in all of us!!!

The aroma of this beer is great. I loved to smell the aroma of chocolate when I opened the bottle. Then I actually stuck my nose somewhat in the beer, and the chocolate smell hit me like a ton of bricks. The beer pour a nice black, with a light chocolate head. The flavor was great. The chocolate is definitely noticeable. A fine stout, but there is a problem that I have with this beer, it is not thick enough! I want a thicker, and less carbonated stout!!!

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 Great desert beer with a thick dark brown-black body and inviting head.  Sweet chocolate waterfalls followed by hints of vanilla cream and a slight caramel flavor.  Very enjoyable beer!
Bottle - Pours a nice black with thick tan head.  Strong aroma - sweet malty, chocolate.  Sweet flavors - chocolate, malt, bitter chocolate finish, oats.  Thick mouthfeel.  Very good beer.
Wonderful, one of the best chocolate stouts I have ever had.  Absolutely delicious I highly recommend this beer.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: excellent beer, pours dark, little head, perfect amount of CO2 rich flavor of cocoa. worth every penny. love Rouge beers!
UPDATED: JUL 3, 2007 Pours black with a dark brown head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts and a hint of caramel.  Chocolate dominate the flavor. Starts Sweet and ends bitter. A very nice stout.

Excellent dark chocolate aroma with a hint of caramel.  Poured with a frothy light brown head. Body wa a deep dark brown almost black.  Slighlty sweet taste with a bitter finish.  Overall a great beer.
22oz. Poured a very dark almost blaco with a 1 finger head. Aroma is like a hot chocolate and malt. Taste chocolate and a cole mocha miked together.
Black with thick tan head. Roasted malt and citric floral nose. Mild chocolate and perfume taste with bitter chocolate finish.

Concur that this stout gives a beautiful pour with a very bubbly head.  Nose is obviously sweet chocolate, as is the initial flavor, though the aftertaste is somewhat bitter with hints of chocolate and roasted nuts.  Although I found this to be a good drink, I did not find it to be as amazing as others...

pours black with thick khaki head.  aroma chocolate milk and coffee.  taste is much the same.  it is dominated by milk chocolate followed up by some expresso and milky sweetness.  i pick up maybe some citrus and alcohol notes in aroma and flavor.  the finish is lingering bittersweet chocolate and coffee.  very enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours opaque black. The head is nut brown and very firm, dissipates very slowly leaving a thick coat of lacing. Smells of chocolate and espresso. Taste is iced coffee at first, as it warms the chocolate really picks up. Some hoppy bite at the end. The sweetness of the malt is balanced well by the little bit of bitterness. Mouthfeel is thick, but not as thick as I expected. The chocolate isnt overdone but is just about right and well balanced.

Cant believe Ive never rated this beer. Some people love to rip on Rogue, but this is one of my all time favorites...tons of chocolate and roasted malts. Not overly sweet at all....just damned tasty. I could drink this all day and twice on Sundays(what?).
Gorgeous. Aroma of sweet chocolate. Nice roasted taste with some chocolate as well. An outstanding chocolate stout.
UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 Excellent chocolate stout.  Aroma is great.   Pours thick with a soft brown head.  Very opaque with little carbonation.  Big chocolate flavor with some hops.

Wow.  This is my first Rogue beer.  Ive barely even poured it and already its the best looking beer Ive ever seen.  The thick tan head and extremely dark body is absolutely beautiful.  Also, I smell chocolate!  Very nice taste that finishes with a good taste of the chocolate I smelled before.  This is now my favorite beer.

Cant complain about the appearance of this one.  Dark dark dark, too dark to see highlights by room lights.  Thick tan head, moderate lacing.  Aroma is rich, toasted, cocoa.  I LOVED the palate, very thick, chewy, lush, and I pick up tons of chocolate malt taste, but without the usual blast of cloying sweetness that accompanies it.  Plenty of milk chocolate goodness and the hops quantity is perfect to balance.  Bit more than some.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2007 Pours a dark brown color. Has a slight head, with some lacing. Its a heavy bodied beer with strongs hints of chocolate, coffee, malt and some hops. This beer is to hoppy for me. Pretty good aftertaste.

Recently had it on tap at JAXs here in Orlando. This is the best on tap. Flavors are definitly more distinct, than the bottle.
Poured a thick chocolate brown. The texture was creamy and smooth. Great balance between chocolate malt and hops. Delicious for a dessert, add a scoop of vanilla bean ice cream and enjoy.

Bottle. Pint Glass.  Pours a dark color that makes it impossible for light to pass through.  Dark tan head.  Milk chocolate aroma hits the nose hard.  Taste is more of bittersweet chocolate due to the roasted malts and barley.  I thought the body would be thicker and smooth, and perhaps would leave an oily coating on the palate.  However, the body is of medium thickness and  there is a slight fizz on the tongue at the finish.  I was in the mood for chocolate ice cream so this worked well.  A nice once and a while beer.
Full bodied and well structured, having a very present chocolate flavor without tasting like a candy bar. Bitter malt round out the sweet dark chocolate. Silky smooth mouth feel.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2007 Pured from the bottle - A very full-bodied brew.  An excellent dark chocolate taste, strong coffee flavor with plenty of hops and malt to keep me interested in future purchases. A great dessert beer!
This reminds me of cream soda and chocolate.  Its very smooth, has a nice head though it dissipates quickly.
