A little thin in the finish which is due to the relatively low alcohol content, but otherwise outstanding. The most chocolatety beer Ive had.

22oz bottle: Pours a black/very dark brown color, Big thick head-tan, good sized bubbles, slowly diminishing, like a good stout should be.  Strong aroma of hops, chocolate, nuts, very interesting aroma.  Strong chocolate malt taste, semi-bitter taste, overall pretty smooth flavor.

ebo ny in color with a creamy head.  an earthy flovor of oats and hops that gives way to a rich chocolate truffle finish. taken right off the bottle and thats exactly what it is.  too much sweet chocolate for me now. maybe down the line of trying diff beers.

Pours a dark black color with a medium brown head. Chocolate is dominate in the aroma and rather enticing but it doesnt really give you much of a hint to that taste sensation you are about to receive. Holy shit. What happens when you taste this beer is rather amazing. What starts out as a typical coffee rich stout explodes after about half a second into a wonderful chocolate explosion that lasts and lasts and reminds you of a being a child tasting chocolate for the first time. Dry finish and maybe a little undercarbonated. This is still a fantastic beer that should be cherished. Well done you label changing bastards!
UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 True to its name, there was a distinct chocolate aroma and taste to this stout.  I was a bit disappointed at the chalky feeling it left in the mouth.

Strong showing in the "Chocolate Stout" arena. Im growing a little underwhelmed by the chocolate stouts on the market. This would have to be the best in my opinion though. Its a solid and harsh stout with more of a chocolate/molasses feel than say... Youngs double choco. All an all a valiant attempt to mix the world of chocolate with the beer, and probably the best beer ive had along those lines.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2006 Pours a thick and dark color. Aroma hints strongly of chocolate. Head is tan and creamy, but fades quickly.Weak point of the beer is the palate in my opinion. Lasts too long. Rich beer, very satisfying.

Tap- Make sure you get a good breath of this before you drink.  The chocolate aroma is very strong.  This isnt the bitter or dark chocolate that some beers have, but a semi-sweet taste with a creamy palate.  Like drinking a candy bar!  A real desert beer.
bottle-Pours a very dark brown with a nice frothy head. Obviously strong aromas of chocolate with a little touch of hops and hints of woodiness. A good beer for a style I am not to crazy about

A dark beer, completely opaque, with an aroma that entices.  It smells strongly of its namesake.  It has a smooth, thick, consistent pallette that reflects its warm refreshing taste.  Overall a good friendly beer.

Pretty darn good beer. I suggest not drinking this too cold as it mutes its flavor. Definately one you want to try, as it is one of the best in its class.

Emo
Bottle from their Portland pub. Very dark, opaque. Chocolate in the nose. Small head, some lacing. Semi-sweet chocolate taste. Medium body. Excellent beer.
Deliciously chocolatey. I heard they use real chocolate in it. Nice medium-medium light body and the experience of drinking dessert.
caramel, chocolate, black, cloudy, brown foam, aminimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, oily feel, average carbonation,
22 oz bottle dark brown pour with a small beige head , good lacing . chocolate/coffee nose . good bitter chocolate flavor smooth and well balanced .  nice brew
Pours dark brown into a snifter.  Chocolate and espresso notes.  Thin mocha head clings to the rim.  Sticky, fizzy and thin with roasted chocolate.  Bitter chocolate, lasting finish.
One of the best chocolate beers Ive ever had.  Pours a very deep brown color, with a nice dark tan head.  The palet leaves a hershey bar residue.
Dark coloring and tan head. Smooth drinkablility. Sweet taste that doesnt overstay its welcome. Tasty.
There is an aroma of dark chocolate and roasted coffee.  The color is a rich black with a tan head.  Flavor is a balance between dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and dark fruit.

On Tap. Very dark brown in color with a creamy tan head. It is one of those beers you want to smell for a while before tasting. It has a distinct aroma of Hersheys Chocolate Syrup. It does not taste like it though, as the beer is anything but sickeningly chocolately sweet. A bitter, heavy finish. Cannot taste the alcohol content at all.
Bottle Pours a very dark brown almost black.  With a tan head that last forever. Very nice aroma of dark chocolate good tast. Another GREAT Rogue beer.

Pours a dark dark brownish black with thin dark tan head.   Aroma of very dark chocolate, coffee and roasted semi-sweet malt.  Flavor matches aroma perfectly.  Very good, but overwhelming after a while.

On Tap at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 05/08/2005
Black and rich on the palate with chocolaty aroma and flavour. Some bitterness in a lasting coffee roast finish.

On tap.Pours a thick dark brown-black; forms a thinnish mocha head that slowly dissipates to a persistent thin layer on top. Beautiful aroma that is at once chocolatey, spicy and a bit piney. Flavor is nice tight bakers chocolate, medium roast coffee, sweet yet dry malt. Spicy, somewhat piney hops add an interesting element. If someone were to describe to me a chocolate stout with notable piney notes, Id imagine it tasting kind of gross. But the piney and spicy nature of the hops unexpectedly complements rather than detracts from the base chocolate character. Rogue seems to strike a perfect balance here and my guess is that any attempt by anyone else to replicate it would likely come off tasting awkward. Palate is impossibly smooth as it slides down like a chocolate milkshake. Even though I intended to do a beer-rating marathon during this particular trip to the pub, I ended up ordering round after round of this instead.

This beer offers a good hearty chocolate aroma with hints of vanilla and toffee.  It is a black solution that resides under a good thick brown head and has good lacing.  This moderately thick bodied beer has a well developed chocolate taste.  A mild bitterness does creep in at the finish.
Bottle 650 ml. Appearance: Pours black with a medium brown head. Aroma: milk chocolate, caramel, alcohol, hops. Flavor: sweet milk chocolate,  hop.  Thank to jrob_21.
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2007 Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma of roast, chocolate, alcohol, and hops. Flavor is sweet upfront, chocolatey, some bitter hoppiness, nice thick body, great brew.

Opaque ebony with a thick medium-brown head, that richly laces the glass.
Very nice light chocolate aroma. The chocolate comes through in the flavor, with a bitter chocolate aftertaste.
UPDATED: OCT 3, 2009 Bottle, re-rate on 10/1/09:  Dark brown pour with a thick tan head.  Tastes of malts, chocolate, butterscotch, light nuttiness, and a light hop presence.  Simple, yet satisfying.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2006 Pours a dark, almost black, medium-bodied beer with a  brown head.  Smells of chocolate and alcohol, and tastes the same.  Very strong chocolate presence in this one, which fits its namesake.  After the chocolate explosion, the taste of smoke and nuts prevailed through out the finish of this stout.  If you like this, youd love Breckenridges Oatmeal Stout as well.

This beer is the same recipe as the Shakespeare stout with the addiction of malts and Belgian chocolate, so I am told.  This is basically how I feel about this one.  Not a session beer, but not a big boy that will put you to sleep in the recliner.  I love this beer, the possiblities with food are just endless. The chocolate is rich, balanced, and natural. It isnt some forced chocolate beer. Kudo Rogue.

Aroma of incredibly sweet chocolate.  Really sweet taste as well.  Nice hop bitterness comes close to balancing out the chocolate.    Loses points because it tastes more like chocolate milk than a stout.  Chocolate milk is money tho.

Bottle: Pours black with a creamy frothy light brown head. Aroma is a malty dark chocolate as well as the flavor with hints of oatmeal in the thick creamy finish. An excellent sit down desert beer. Delicious!

I may have to come back and rerate this (I had set the bottle outside to chill on this cold night in the mountains and started to freeze as I poured it) not sure if I did it some damage... But as is, I was very unimpressed, Aroma and flavor of bitter chocolates and tastse of bitter chocolate, dry cocoa and chocolate truffle. A bit overpowering on the chocolate and beyond that, kind of flat and non complex... Ive had a lot of Stouts and can think of many better than this, in fact, Im likely to not even finish it.

A wonderful dark stout with a dark bittersweet flavor. This has got to be one of my favorite sit down and relax stouts. The oatmealy flavor and choclate truffle aftertaste just made me sit there and go mmm....and as thick as it is..one is about all you  can take. Nice creamy head...but it didnt keep it long..but who cares, this one has a lot going for it. In one word..delicious.

Opaque, black or dark brown. Head is gone quickly. Aroma is bitter chocolate but I get an image of maple syrup and pancakes as well!? Maybe its the sweetness. As the beer settles it is more chocolate bars or chocolate toast. The flavour is chocolate and pancakes as well. Maybe it is chocolate oatmeal rather than pancakes. Finish is a short light dusty chocolate.

pours black with a frothy brown head and some lacing.  aroma is definitely chocolate with a bitter sweet chocolate taste.  fairly thick, dont think i could handle to many in one sitting but nicely done.  would have scored even higher with more complexity.

This is an exceptional beer. It has a very chocolate flavor and is a bit on the bitter side as well. This was pretty complex and tasted a bit like a chocolate wafer bar of sorts... Very dark in color, pretty much black. It has a decent size head which disappeared pretty quickly. It had a lot going for it.

I really enjoyed this beer. Defintily had to split the bottle as it is an incredibly thick beer, but i certainly enjoyed my half as i slowly slipped. This beer had a chocolate flavor like no other i have had. It almost tasted like a delicious stout with chocolate syrup mixed right in. Everything worked well for a delicious beer.

Bottle.  Rich chocolate body with a thick brown head.  Aroma smells like a chocolate bar.  Flavor is chocolate with milk chocolate, bittersweet chocolate, and dark chocolate.  Smooth chocolate palate.  Chocolatey.

Bottle.  Dessert beer for sure - rich chocolate, smooth, witih nice hop undertone.  Full, complex aroma and flavor both a good compliment to vanilla ice cream.  deep blacky brown with tan generous head, a lil lacing.  Tons of roasted malt.  you can taste the fishing boats and the perfect water throughout rogue beer...
Wow. Thick mahogany with a thick foamy mocha-colored head. Rich chocolate flavor and aroma. This is good!

Dark chocolate pour matches the dark chocolate aroma and taste of this delightful sweet stout. The thick dark-tan head atop the dark brown body enhances the appearance. Along with the chocolate, the aroma was full of roasted/burnt malts. The flavor started sweet and quickly evoked images of dark chocolate before the Cascade hops kicked in layering the chocolate with a bitter aftertaste. Creamy mouthfeel, somewhat sticky. Moderate finish.

Bottle. Pours thick black with a creamy, thin brown head. Enormous chocolate aroma, - thick, sweet, and creamy. Flavors are there too, but hoppiness is a little detracting, almost nullifying the sweetness rather than blending with it. Still a tasty beer, even if it wins mostly on aroma and a silky mouthfeel.

Poured dark dark brown (not QUITE black) into my english pint glass.  Dont bother trying to see through this one unless you have a spotlight behind the glass.  A rich brown head developed with moderate retention.  Nice lacing.  The initial nosing revealed bittersweet chocolate, and then sweetened a bit into a chocolate smell that reminded me of a powdered hot coco drink.  The aroma was basically all chocolate, but it was multilayered and not one dimensional...and that scored big with me.  I didnt notice any hop flavor until the finish, and even then it was mild.  It seemed that they tried to bitter more with dark roasted malts rather than hops.  The massive chocolate dose was a little overpowering in the flavor.  Its a decent beer-it does exactly what it says it does- but its a little cloying to me.
Pours black with a decent, thick brown head.  Aroma is bittersweet chocolate.  Creamy mouthfeel with taste of chocolate, malts, and oats.  The cascade hops give it a sharp finish.  Very nice.

Valentines Day 2006. 22oz bottle. Pours rich dark and opaque almost-black brown with a lasting head. Pretty. Aroma is chocolate, with fruity aroma like chocolate dipped. Starts sharp and bitter, then quickly mellows to a roasted malty flavor and in between one finds the chocolate. Finishes a bit like a good ipa, the bitter chocolate blends well with the floral hops. Very good; this is MY kind of stout. Looking forward to it again next year.
650 mL bottle.  Poured to a dark brown/black.  Great aroma of chocolate and a hint of coffee.  Slightly bitter chocolate taste.  Get in my belly!
Not a bad stout. Still doesnt beat Sam Smiths Oatmeal stout. Great aroma but the flavor falls short on its promise IMO.

Pours a light blackish brown that shows a little light through around the edges. Head is reddish and thick but fades a little fast. Nose is bitter chocolate with some maltiness, doesnt mix very well. Flavor is semi sweet chocolate with some sweet malt balance. Maybe even a hint of vanilla in the after taste.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2006 giving the aroma a ten simply because the chocolate is so impressive.  appearance is great, though ive come to expect pure opacity in a chocolate stout.  certainly great head, thick as hell.  i dont think it is as good as other chocolate stouts ive had.  i recently had the black sun stout, this isnt as good.  but its pretty good at what it does.  on the downside, the alcohol has a tiny bite more than youd want at 6.3 abv.

Bottle - Poured black with dark brown bubbling through the beer to form a large, foamy deep tan on the top that hung around for a while and left a good amount of lacing.  Aroma, distincly burnt dark chocalate was not impressive to me, but mine was slightly cooler than it should be to start.

Very tastily enjoyed during the Superbowl with dark chocolate being the overriding theme with hop bitterness noticeable throughout.  The aftertaste was surprisingly minimal.  Would drink again, perhaps as a dessert beer.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2006 Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a nice dark tan head that leaves great lacing.  Aroma is unmistakably chocolate, with some roasty malt notes.  Taste is very hoppy, though still with a definite chocolate flavor.  Not as smooth as Id like a sweet stout to be, but still a good beer.

Bomber - Poured a very dark black/brown with a quite thick tan head.  Aroma is light of coffee and roasted malts and fairly distinct of chocolate (!).  Some hop bitterness, but still chocolatey!  Rally good beer... I love the chocolate!!!!

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2007 On tap at Crescent Moon Alehouse in Omaha, 2/4/06: The expected black elixir with a coffee-brown head.  Pure cocoa goodness with a night light bitter finish.  This is awesome.  Delicious with any chocolate desert or good as a desert all on its own.
Bottle. Pours a pitch black with a huge coffee colored head. Very hoppy with some chocolate flavor. Hoppier than other sweet stouts, but interesting. Very little carbonation, nice smooth mouthfeel.

Very dark, totally opaque.  Odd thick head that looked like sponge toffey.  Very chocolaty scent.  Very hppy.  Fine tinging carbonation.  Goes down very easy for a stout but I an still not a fan of stouts.

Smells like quik chocolate with some light hoppiness.  Pours a very dark brown with a brown-tinted head about an inch thick that quickly recedes.  Tastes of bittersweet chocolate with a slight bitter aftertaste.  Enjoyable, not anywhere near as smooth as Youngs double chocolate stout.
Tap. Freaking tasty, no doubt about it. I prefer Youngs Double Choc, though. Had a more balanced chocolate edge to it. This one has a great aroma, though.

Black stout pour offers a nose of roast, light chocolate and a bouncing hop presence. Palate is thick, sticky, and appetizing. Flavor is bittersweet chocolate that is never overpowering, becomes a little sweeter before it is removed by a light hop finish. Never monotone, never boring, this is a flavored stout that manages complexity as well as a distinct accent.

Rogue Chocolate Stout pours to a beautiful deep ebony color, with a thick, creamy tan head, and a soft carbonation. The first thing that strikes you with this beer is the nose. Incredible chocolate aromas of cocoa, dark chocolate, and roast, flood the nose. The palate is luxuriously delicious. Flavors of bitter sweet dark chocolate, roasted barley, and sweet maltiness coat the tongue. A portion of oats is used in this beer, making it silky smooth and creamy, as it slides down the throat. Rogue Chocolate Stout finishes as impressive as it started. More bitter sweet chocolate flavors up front, followed by some coffee flavor, bitter roastiness, and just a kiss of hop bitterness to balance out this exceptional brew. 

WOW. This beer is like drinking a chocolate truffle. There is chocolate in this beer, and you can tell. This beer as an absolute must for chocolate lovers. A perfect desert beer that would match extremely well with, what else? Chocolate. Pair this glorious beer with milk chocolates, or perhaps a rich and decadent death by chocolate cake. The roasty flavors in this beer, really are wonderful when you pair it with a sweet and creamy chocolate desert. Stout and chocolate is a match made in heaven. I highly recommend this beer.
Dark with a big tan head. Smells like cocoa and some espresso.  Lots of chocolate flavour, rich in the mouth with lots of body.  Smooth finish leaves a chocolate aftertaste.

Thick dark brown/black color with a massive dark brown head and excellent head retention.  Wonderful chocolate aroma - smells just like a chcolate milk shake.  Other aromas include oats, caramel, licorice, vanilla, sweet cigar/pipe tobacco.  Very mouth-watering aroma.  Wow, incredible flavor.  Initially sweet and earthy with a strong taste of oats and ultra smooth floral hops, and finishes like a really good coffee (bitter, but not overly so) with rich dark chocolate in the aftertaste.  This beer has so many complex flavors in it - in addition to the ones mentioned in the aroma, there is brown sugar, molasses, espresso, raisins, and butterscotch, and a smoky finish.  In addition to the gratifying hop kick, the texture is silky smooth and creamy.
Very nice beer. Dark color, with a very brown head. Flavor is dry chocolate with a surprising amount of hops as well. Roasted malt and chocolate really shine with this one.

Bottle. This is a serious beer. Very heavy sweet roasted chocolate aroma mingling with silky cream, and doughy hops. Pours black with a lovely stacked, dark tan head. Tastes quite sweet at first, then moves to bittersweet dark chocolate. Long, complex, sticky, milky, caramelly finish. Fantastic.

Wow! As I open this bottle man the aromas of milk chocolate sweetness, floural hop, brown butter, vanilla, Cadbury milk chocolate. This beer pours a jet black and leaves a silky brown head that looks like you poured too much vanilla in your whipped cream. As I smell this beer all the aromas I talked about milk chocolate, brown butter(butterscotch), coffee, floural hops, caramel, sugar, vanilla, are all on display in this beer. The taste of this beer just explodes on your palate. It starts with a vanilla chocolate sweetness then moves to a bitter hop kick followed by a coffee essence and finally finishes with a silky smooth butterscotch aftertaste. This is a fantastic stout Im sad I took this long to get to it, I will not make that mistake again.
Bottle.  Strong chocolate-coffee aroma.  Pitch black with small brown head - pours like motor oil.  Stong chocolate malt flavor with mild hops and smoky finish.

Aroma is, guess what, like chocolate, maybe Nesquick.  Pours motor oil black with a light brown head that quickly disappears.  Taste is pretty good, again, lots of chocolate.  It is kind a dry, dark chocolate taste.  Not overwhelming. Dont expect it to taste like chocolate milk.    There is a little bit of hop kick in the aftertaste.  Overall a very good stout.
Pours out deep black color with tan color head.  Heavy chocolate aroma.  Very sweet chocolate flavor with hint of hoppiness.  Not bad.

This is a beer that delivers what it says, The aroma is pure chocolate syrup. The looks is black at night. The taste is a combination of Chocolate soda, many hop, toasted malts. This is the type of beer you drink at the end of a big meal with dessert. A perfect appertif.

The aroma is full of chocolate and cream soda. There is also plenty of toasted malt and hops. The appearance is black and the head is of average size but its foamy. The flavor has lots of chocolate with malt, caramel, toffee, and coffee. The palate is just right. The aftertaste is bitter. This is the beer for chocolate lovers!

The usual dark oil pour with the dark head, strong amount of chocolate comes with the aroma. This beer is smooth and a bit chewy with the biggest emphisas on chocolate  out of any beer Ive tasted thus far, if they went any further Id be apt pour it in a mug and stick a marshmallow in it. A very delicoious beer indeed, yet I found it a bit difficult to polish of the bomber bottle. Perhaps a bit too rich to have more than one every once in a while.

Cask conditioned, GBBF 2005:
Big powerful chocolate aroma. Hoppy bitter finish, still with a soft touch of sweet chocolate. Amazing texture and mouthfeeling.

on tap, a tasty beer.  Very chocolatey without being too sweet or having that gross old stale chocolate taste.  Very drinkable, sweet finish.  Kind of like drinking dark chocolate.  Has a slight hop flavor that blends well with the chocolate.  I would suggest this for anyone who is a serious fan of chocolate.
This is a great chocolate stout.  Its almost as if chocolate was melted into this beer.  Very sweet with a bit of malt all roasted together for a very satisfying drink.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2006 Draught, Wow this must be a huge beer! Deep black, with one of the most copious, darkest heads Ive ever seen. Robust, caramel, chocolate and toasted malt aroma. Pushing the envelope of chocolate flavor; roasty notes with a sweet finish. Solid stout.

Bottle. Pours black with nice frothy brown head, some lacing. Slight aroma of a chocolate malt. Flavor is like chocolate flavored coffee, with some hop bitterness. The burnt or dark roast coffee characteristics sticks a tad too much at the back of the throat, but still a very good beer. One  the best Rogue I have tried so far, next to the Shakespeare. This would be great with chocolate cake, screw the after dinner coffee. Gotta keep the buzz going!

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2006 Distint Rogue taste to this beer, sharp with hints of hops.  Bitter finish, good chocolate taste - Head is very light - I find this typical of Rogues, and this one laced well.  Good beer, not my favorite chocolate stout, but its up there.

Pours a nice deep dark opaque brown color with a perfect amount of dark tan head and lovely thin streams of white small bubbles cascading up the sides of the glass.  Aroma is a rich creamy lactic chocolate and a different sweet candyish undertone.  Flavor tastes exactly like one of those damn chocolate drinks at starbucks.  Very very sweet chocolate prescence with barely a bit of bitter finish.  Overall, looks and smells good, but sweetness a bit over the top for me.

"Different for Rogue, not all hopes. Poured a dar brown with a light tan head. Smell of chocolate as it was poured. Tasted slightly of hops and sweet roasted chocolate. very creamy mouthfeel. Overall very good beer. "

poured a black hue and tan head.  Really chocolate rich aroma with some coffee notes but chocolate was most previlant. 
flavor was sweet and rich with chocolate and some coffee notes body was rich and thick a really full beer yet it was smooth.

Black pour, good sized dark tan head. A little bit of light comes through the sides. Aroma, chocolate, with a roasty background. Nice flavor, a mild chocolate with a touch of bitterness, as well as some roasted notes from the malt.

Black pour w/ a large brown head w/ a nice lacing.  Aroma is of milk chocolate almost of chocolate milk and hints of vanilla.  Palate is a nice body some light creminess full feeling.  Flavor is coccoa and lactose and some other roast malts w/ a dry chocolate kind of hop.  Pretty good but not one of my favorites.

Black without a hint of light coming through. Big creamy brown head with nice lacing. Chocolate aroma with a background of roastiness, and I think I could detect just the faintest aroma of the Cascade. Wonderful full mouthfeel complimented by a fine light carbonation. Flavors of bittersweet chocolate and dark roasted malts follow in the steps of the aroma. Finishes surprisingly dry for a beer so dominated by rich malt flavors. Just luscious. Well done, Rogue!
650ml bottle.  Pours black with a creamy, chocolaty head.  Aroma of serious chocolate.  First taste is lots o chocolate, but finishes a little bitter.  Very little.  Dont drink it too cold!

Bottle: Black, blackened coffee edges, large light brown head, frothy, decent lacing.   Cocoa aroma, seems bitter and dry.   Rich dark chocolate on the tongue, high in its percentage of cocao, quite dry, and semi-sweet.   Fairly bitter for a sweet stout, definite hop bite.   Strong bittersweet cocoa finish.   Body and mouthfeel are moderate, at least less thick and full bodied as expected.   Lingering cocoa and hop bitterness after the finish.   Not as smooth or milky as other examples.   This is one for hop heads who like their dark chocolate with a high percentage of cocoa.
Pours a black with brown head.  Chocolate aroma. Milky texture. Sweet flavor.  Hints of smoke. Roasty, bitter finish.  Good dessert beer.

Like a huge piece of chocolate cake with rich chocolate icing.  Poored deep brown, smelled intensely like chocolate.  Taste matched smell well; roasted chocolate, and few other flavors were allowed to penetrate.  So tasty and easy to drink, be careful of this candy in a bottle.

Pours to a huge creamy brown head atop a dark brown/black body with nice lacing.  The aroma is that of M&Ms and Hersheys Milk Chocolate.  OMG.  So exactly like that.  The flavor is roasty oatmeal and chocolate M&Ms.  Definite cocoa powder.  Good but not really what I want in a beer.  The palate is medium bodied and smooth.  Something that doesnt fit.

Fantastic aroma - Smells exactly like melted M&Ms.  Black body with a wispy tan head.  The flavor reveals that its a dry stout (theres some charcoaly dryness) with chocolate extract on top.  The mouthfeel is too dry for the sweet flavor - if it were smoother and richer it would really compliment the rest of the flavor.  Still tasty howerver.

Thick creamy brown head. Dissipates to a ring fast. Dark brown clear body.
Holy Hershey Batman! Very sweet chocolate aroma. Very unimpressively 1-D though. 
Dry chocolate flavor. Very dry, not much sweetness. Smokey old alfalfa greens too. 
Blah... okay but too obsessively chocolate-laden.

Wonderful aroma of chocoloate (surprise, surprise).  Pitch black color with a little brown head.  Flavor is wonderful, mixing the best of both worlds; drinking beer, and enjoying cocoa.  Good body, with the right amount of carbonation.  I absolutely loved this one.

Pours black with a thick creamy brown head.  Smells very chocolate like, a little molasses and a little bitter aroma.  Very nice.  Taste of chocolate as well a little smoke as well.  Some alcohol is evident a little more so as it warms.   Very full bodied and creamy mouthfeel.  Finishes a little bitter, but smooth.

Dark-brown creamy head over near black beer with brown-red shot lining. Nose is as hanging over a freshly opened package of black chocolate, chocolate malt as cacaopowder. Bitter chocolate taste, as the kind sprinkled over chocolate truffles, Belgian chocolates with brandy, or entering a Godiva shop and taking a deep breath - one can taste the air. Well bodied, smoked hints, but very drinkable. Great chocolate beer, imposing in its authority.

Pours a dark brown/black with some creamy tan head that quickly dissipates to a ring. Aroma is some roast, some chocolate, and the cascades in all their glory. Starts out pretty roasty, with some coffee and dry chocolate notes. Strange, I was expecting this to be sweeter. Finishes rather bitter, with some hops and alcohol coming out at the end. Pretty dry overall, wondering why this is a sweet stout. Lacking a bit in the body. A bit too much carbonation on the end, a big pet peeve of mine. Mediocre.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2005 Smells like a scratch-and-sniff sticker from the mid 80s. Yellowish head that disappears quicklya dark stout. Tootsie roll taste that gets smashed by bitterness. After reading reviews, I actually thought it would be more coo-coo for coco puffs in flavor. This isnt bad, but I would drink a Bells Kalamazoo Stout over this any day.

650 mL brown bottle purchased from Armanettis, Mundelein, IL.  Black hued stout having a small diminishing light brown head with good lacing.  Succulent aroma bouquet of chocolate, espresso and raisin.  Full bodied with smooth creamy texture that starts with sharpness and slight sweet roasted malt with hints of dark chocolate, espresso and raisin. Finishes dry with lingering bitterness. An excellent chocolate stout, one of the best that Ive tried so far.
Well think of chocolate milk and then think of how chocolate beer would taste and this is it.  Pretty good stuff.
(draft) A fantastic beer, from the intense chocolate syrup aroma through the creamy mouthfeel to the delicious finish. Beyond yummy.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2005 Dominated by chocolate, rather unfortunately I guess. Aroma and taste are both overrun by it, which blocks out some nice hops in the flavor and more complexity in the aroma.

Beautiful dark colored body, light brown head.  Heavy chocolate aromas, with roast malts and coffee.  Bitter sweet. Taste is of mocha, chocolate. Very nice. Roasted hints and a very well rounded chocolate finish.

22 oz. bottle.  Poured out like motor oil, thick and blackish-brown with a thick light brown head.  The aroma was heavy with chocolate and roasted malt with some hints of coffee.  The initial flavor is bitter hops, roasted malt and burnt toast.  That later gives way to some caramel and a nice, rich milk chocolate finish.  Nice and full on the palate.  This is the best Ive tasted thus far from Rogue, outstanding on a warm Thanksgiving afternoon here in Tampa.

Bouteille-Noire pas de mousse consistante. Arôme et goût chocolaté. Très gazeuse. Rondeur pleine bouche. Excellente!--Bottle-Black with no head. Chocolate aroma adn taste. Fizzy. Full mouth palate. Excellent one!
Pours black with a thin choco colored head.  Smells of chocolate and coffee.  Has a very rich and sweet chocolate taste.  A very nice sweet stout indeed and it washes down smooth to boot.

A big, brown head over a dense black brew. The head was tight bubbled, creamy and long lasting.  The head alone had a light chocolate flavor, a precursor things to come. They didnt come. It was a tad too hoppy to the detriment of the malt and chocolate flavors, slightly out of balance. The chocolate malt was there but it didnt come through sufficiently. Too bad, it started off good.

A pour rivaled only by motor oils.  Nice dark chocolate aromas, chocolate malty flavor with nice bitterness on the finish.  I have to concur with everyone here.  This is fantastic beer, especially in the winter.

Bottle. Black.  Dark tan short lived rocky head giving way to a thick ring around the glass. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma some smoky tones. Medium to full bodied. Bitter roasted flavor well balanced with sweet chocolatey malt, finishing bitterly leaving a smoky aftertaste. What a  beer!.
Rich creamy head with distinct chocolate malts and a hint of real chocolate.  Making a run as my favorite Rogue Ale
Overall the taste is like a tootsie rolll dropped in a dark ale. No fizz to this one, just thick syrupy beer.

A dark brew with a toasty head.  It is indeed bittersweet and chocolately as they suggest, but what is that scorched caramel I taste?  I cant describe it without using the name "tootsie pop."  This beer tastes like a tootsie pop.  It is tasty, but that singular candy sweetness and smoke are not an every day affair.
Poured a dark brown color with a brown head.  Milk chocolate aroma.  Chocolately flavor with a light roast and a bitter finish.

Aroma:cocoa,chocolate,light rosted malt...
Appearance:dark,good tan head...
Flavor:Rosted malt,cocoa,light biterness....

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2005 Bomber from Liqour Barn.  Nice tan head, can already tell the beer has a nice texture from the pour.  To me smells a lot like Rogues imperial porter; dark fruits and roasted malt.  Tastes great.  Fairly complex, really lovely subtle chocolate notes and a great bitter chocolate finish.  Very pleased with its rich, smooth texture.  Felt very full and not overly chocolatey.
Love this beer-stout and chocolate.  Im not sure I need the added chocolate, but still, its a lot of fun to drink.
Good stuff. Nice head, texture, aroma. A favorite of mine for many years now.

Bottle, from Grape Idea. Ok nose, sweet. Hot cocoa, cereal (wheaties) honey. Dark brownish black color, good head that slowly faded to a ring, then to nothing as it warmed. Bittersweet flavors, like aromas with a little seltzer and viney. Medium bodied, lite creamy mouthfeel, bitter dry powdery finish. Tasty brew. Grabbed this while investigating Grape Idea in Wayland MA. Easy to get to, yet hard to see as it is tucked away in the back of a place that look kinda like a house. Still deciding if its places worthy.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 9, 2007 bottle. Its really nice that the pub near me in little, old Gatlinburg started carrying this. Its my regular beer now and Ive had a few times to revisit this. The pour is a nice very dark brown with a rocky tan head. It probably looks black in most normal light, but on the sun-shiny deck of the Fox & Parrot, I can see some brown. Aroma packs sweet chocolate, but then theres the firm, bright hop presence. Same thing in the mouth: rich chocolate, some coffee, and a surprising amount of hoppy biterness for sweet stout. The chocolate flavor is notably distinct and intense.

Dark brown medium foam with Hershey chocolate color.  Beautiful bittersweet chocolate nose.  Bitter aftertaste and first taste is chocolate sweet that modulates  through a few changes on the palate before hitting you with the cascade hops. At Kappys Fresh Pond in Cambridge, MA. A bit bitter for a sweet stout.  It grows on you though after a glass.

Great stuff, not overpowering. Strong aromas of chocolate on the nose greet toasty oats on the palate. I think of this first as an oatmeal stout, send as a chocolate stout. One of my favorite under 7 ABV stouts. A nice sweet finish. If I were rating according to style, this would be in the 4.7 range. Better on tap from the times Ive had it, but my rating is from an 04 bottle.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2006 Aroma is a bit funky with light milk chocolate, mild coffee, lightly malty and lightly hoppy.  I think it is the yeast that makes the aroma slightly funky.  Pours a huge frothy medium brown head which produces good lacing and is mostly lasting.  For a chocolate stout the flavour is not very chocolately.  The flavour is moderately bitter with an average length finish which is slightly dry.
Opaque black, with a beige head. Chocolate and hops aroma. Chocolate milk feel and flavor, and a sweet malt finish.

Deep dark on the pour with a tan head that slowly went away.  Chocolate, toffee aroma makes you want to take a sip.  Nice chewy flavor that finishes with just a slight bitterness that you expect.  One of my favorite stouts.  A must try on tap.
UPDATED: MAY 4, 2006 This is a solid beer.  Picked up a bottle at New Beer Distributors (NYC).  Very dark, chocolate aroma, coffee/chocolate taste, slight bitter aftertaste.
poured like black cream.. blended nice..equal sweetnesswith bitterness  taste semi sweet chocolote slight hoppy after taste.. drinkability..C+.B- ones..the most.. malty.out...

Black pour with a large head. Aroma was hard to pick up at first, but eventually a lot of chocolate came out. Also oats and vanilla. Lotsa hop bitterness here. Flavor is light bitter chocolate. This could have been better made, especially if it was smoother. Better chocolate flavoring with less hops would have rendered a much higher score...

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2005 Wow, theyre not lying about the chocolate in this brew. ... Aroma, is nearly like sniffing a hershey bar. ... Appearance is an appealing black, with a thin head. ... Flavor is a rush of chocolate with a hop bite. ... Very dry on the palate, a bit too dry for my taste. ...Overall, a interesting beer, but I dont believe Id stock my fridge with it.  After smelling its terrific aroma and seeing how beautiful it looked, its flavor left me a tad disappointed.
This dark brown ale poured with a nice tan head, eliciting a strong chocolate aroma. The flavor was primarily chocolate and coffee and was quite tasty.

Pours Dark brown with a thick frothy tan coloured head.  Aroma is quite complex: Sweet Milk chocolate, nuts, coffee and notes of hickory.  Flavours are just as enjoyable - Chocolate, roasted malt and notes of coffee.  Mouthfeel is very rich - almost like chocolate milk.  Finish is fairly bitter with a hint of smokiness...Yummy!

If there was an Iron Chef of brewing, and the secret ingredient was chocolate, this brew would wow the judges.  Tons of chocolate on the nose.  Sweet chocolate, swiss chocolate, Hersheys cocoa, and oats, oats, oats!  Impermeable dark brown beer with little to no head, but who cares?  The chocolate is the star here.  Tasting involves the nose as much as the palate.  Hops up front, melding into a cake-like chocolate center.  The earthiness of the oats rounds out the chocolate and malts finish the job.  Palate is my only complaint.  Not too creamy for a milk stout, and I miss the length of Mackeson in the olden days.  But for the treatment of a single ingredient, this is a blue ribbon beer.
From bottle.  Pours dark with lots of dark brown head.  rich chocolate and roasted malt flavor, smooth palate feel.

Cask (handpump) at GBBF, August 2005. Inky black colour. Massive chocolate in the aroma. Same on the palate. I dont think Ive ever had a beer so chocolaty. Creamy chocolate rather than bitter chocolate. Tastes a little artificial. Fortunately I like chocolate. It would be fair to say its a bit one dimensional. But I dont care. I like it.

Pours shoe polish black with a tasty, chunky, quickly dissipating head.  Absolutely silky smooth with a bit of fizz to add depth.  Flavor of ultra sweet, ultra hefty, bittersweet chocolate with hints of roasted coffee, cookie dough and earthy grain.  Leaves a tasty, bitter smack around the mouth.  Excellent dessert beer.  If Godiva Chocolatiers added a gourmet beer to their lineup, this would be it.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2006 Yummy chocolate, in the aroma, in the mouth, in the whole ambience.  Black in color, thin brown-sugar head, layers of bittersweet chocolate and coffee so complete it can stand in nicely for dessert or satisfy a raging chocolate craving.  A girl beer?  Maybe, but so?

Bomber bottle. Black color with moderate light brown head that diminished slowly and had good lacing. Complex sweet malt and chocolate aroma. Full body with a creamy texture. Good complex bitter chocolate and coffe flavor with a long bittersweet finish. Very good sweet stout.

Bottle, 1 pint:
This is a perfect sweet stout and exactly what I would expect! Pours jet black, 1/2 inch tan head that lasted intil the last drop. Aroma is of strong coffee and chocolate. Taste is sweet and the alcohol is hidden by the strong chocolate tones of this stout. This is a great offering from Rogue and I will be enjoying more!

I knew this brew would be dark, but its darker than my coffee this morning, and almost opaque!  It pours smoothly, and looks like melted dark chocolate.  It smells grainy, doughy, with notes of chocolate and coffee.    The head is creamy but fairly short in height and life.  The taste is very layered, with sweetness first, then the malt and hops.  Its layered, but balanced.  Not too much of anything in there, with a nice black coffee finish.  The alcohol is there too, but its mostly hidden amongst the layers.  A good brew for sure!  I dont want it too often, but I certainly agree its another out-of-the-ordinary offering from Rogue!

Re-rate - 9 mo. aged bottle July 2005 - I wanted to add some points because when RCS settles down, the flavors really harmonze and produce a satisfying big flavor thats remarkably balanced. It becomes a rather monstrous stout actually, chocolate flavored or not. I love you Rogue. Now Im wondering if I shoulda ordered TWO cases of the Tsarina Katerina...

Pours ever so dark with fine tall head... Wow...memories of St-Ambroise (another oatmeal stout with a variety of dark malts and hops.) Well-made stout although the dry cocoa aroma from the added "chocolate flavoring" is a bit up there and in-your-nostrils. Too much of a good thing? -or- would I just complain if it werent so kookoo for cocoa puffs? I have to scrounge up a few more to qualify a less Newbie opinion of this one. Miles of lingering pleasant bitter finish. You have to admit, Rogue likes to craft-brew one HELL of a beer whatever they get up to... and watch your step getting off the couch, theres alcohol in them thar bittersweet malts!

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2006 [bomber] HUGE cocoa aroma, I smelled it as soon as I opened the bottle. Pours a thick black with a very small tan head. Flavors match the aroma with strong chocolate and cocoa, mild coffee and an excellent balance between overall bitterness and sweetness. This is one of my favorites.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2008 Cask at the GBBF 05, yummy!, this stuff is so addictive!, strong cocca butter aroma with little roastiness, the flavour is rich chocolate, cocca butter, dark chocolate, some roasted malt notes, some coffee notes, some bitterness but mostly sweet but not too much, creamy, smooth, dark brown colour with a brown head, so so good!

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 This is a taste explosion, coco smell, nice brown head, like a rich choc cake very sweet and tasty...a joy to drink!

..too fake tasting...
Cask (GBBF): Black with a huge tan head. Bitter coffee/choc flavour. Loads of cocoa in the aroma. Medium bodied, quite nice, but nothing exceptional.
Maybe i missed something but i wasnet much of a fan.  It wasent a terrible beer but i had heard it hyped and didnt see it.  Good color but the not one i have much to say about.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Chocolate is not over baring... 22oz is a perfect service size.  Would not suggest drinking large amounts of this.  Like all of Rogues beers, this one is smooth, malty, with a sweet chocolate start, and finishes with a smooth rosted and ever so slightly hoppy finish to break the sweetness.

22 oz bottle, cellared for about 1&1/2 years.  Pours a nice thick black pint with a craggy chocolate brown head.  Smells wonderful with lots of roasted barley and chocolate.  Had to get my nose in there real deep to suck up the wonderful aroma.  Thick full-bodied mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation.  Packed full of flavor, reminds me of dessert in a glass.  The chocolate really comes out in this brew but not in a sickening sweet way.  The finish hangs out for a long time and sets you up for the next sip nicely.  This is one of my favorites, Ive been drinking this for about 3 years since I tried it at a beerfest where it was served by the woman on the bottle herself.  Cellaring  has certainly not hurt this one.  I find that it has led to a lot of sedimentation that has left the beer a lot brighter and cleaner tasting.  This one deserves a try if you come across it.

Tap. Had this in a sampler yesterday. I didnt take notes but remember a black color with a good sized brown head. The flavor was rather sweet chocolate and dark roasted malt with noticable alcohol that fit in well. It had a flavor like a chocolate liquer cordial. It was interesting but a bit too sweet for me and the body was a bit lighter than the Mudshark porter I consumed just before it.
Wow, I like this. Pours opaque. The chocolate is present in all aspects of the beer, but is balanced well. It would make a good dessert, for its a better food complement than a "drinkin beer."

Bottle: Poured ink black in color with an nice, creamy, chocolate ice cream colored head that left good lacing. To the nose, the aroma was sweet milk chocolate and brown sugar oatmeal. The taste was malty with a light bitterness but moderate flavors of coffee and chocolate. Full, creamy body. Great beer for after dinner.

Pours chocolate syrup dark, with no head to speak of. Aroma is chocolatey and slightly bitter. Mouthfeel comes on thick, then thins out. Bitter chocolate taste. Not very sweet to me. Though theres not a real head on it, the carbonation is still there, for a pleasant tickle on the tongue. A good beer, worth a try.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: dark and rich -- sweet chocolate flavor from start to finish.  Sweet after taste.  this is a great dessert beer.  Not good forthe lets get drunk night. save it for a speicial time

Bomber. Pours an oily black with a foamy, fizzy tan head. Nose is like a chocolate tootsie roll pop. Taste is chocolate, (dark, sweet, hot fudge) with some small coffee notes. My palate felt as though dried cocoa powder residue was clinging to the inside of my mouth.

Bottle.  Amazing color.  Dark as could be.  This was the darkest head I have ever seen.  Chocolate Milk Brown.  Lasted forever too.  Left great lacing for the enitre glass.  Aromas were specatcular.  Pure chocolate.   Flavor was a little thiner but still very tasty.  Classic Stout Flavor with chocolate hints.  Some hoppy bitterness in the finish to make a very good beer.

Sweet stout indeed.  Aroma nice chocolate and light coffee scent.  Poured a deep black with pillowy tan head.  Flavor was most tasty, started with a smooth cocoa/vanilla further eminating a smoked quality tailed off fast to a bitter coffee.  Palate was full and rich, finish was long as the hops showed their presence.  Overall a good brew for after dinner.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 milk chocolate aroma wth some hops accents.  black with small tan head.  milk chocolate flavor with hops.  bitter chocolate finish.  long lingering aftertaste.  thick syrupy mouthfeel.    a little less hops would be ideal.
pretty bittersweet taste.  desert beer.  nice color and finish.  chocolate says it all.

Rogue does it again. This company rules.  Pours dark with a dark brown head.  The chocolate stout does what it promises, delivers a wonderful bitter chocolate finish.  If you like sweet stouts I dont know why you havent had this yet, its absolutely fabulous.
bottled, huge nose of chocolate and caramel.  creamy texture, roasty and chocolatey flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2005 Black with a light brown head, mostly receding.  Aroma of dark chocolate with some roasty notes.  Tastes of extreme roasted barley, dominating all chocolate flavors. Also was surprised at the intensity of the Cascade hops, they were ever present and detracted from the sweetness of the beer.  Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  Finishes lightly sweet, moderately bitter.  Good wtih a cigar.  I usually love Rogue, but this one didn’t do it for me.

This pours nearly black with a very brown head that is medium-bubbled and lasts around the edge of the glass.  The nose is strong of chocolate and perhaps a very dark roast with hints of alcohol.  The taste is dark chocolate with a bit of an oatmeal flavor in the middle.  The end is a bit roasty and bitter on the back and sides of the tongue.  This is a very strong stout, and I like it better than the Shakespear.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2005 This is not a good beer.  It was an overspowering stout.  It was bitter and biting... Had a quite lingering aftertaste.  Made me gag as the body was heavy and full, the texture was creamy and the flavor was a rich dark bitter-sweet chocolate with lively carbonation.
Dark brown/black body with thin light brown head.  Bitter chocolate aroma and flavor.  Smells like a Hershey chocolate factory tour.
Aromatic notes of cocoa and raisen meld well with alcohol heaviness.  The body is beautifully crafted - the sweet chocolate cradles the crisp hop bitterness and finishes light and nutty.  Wow!

On Tap at Kahootz:  AWESOME!  Here is a chocolate stout that actually tastes like chocolate, dark chocolate.  The dark brown color is enticing, the aroma captures you and the flavor and body confirm the deal.  Does Rogue make a bad beer?
Best chocolate flavor ive tasted in a beer. Bought 3 bottles for christmas to see how it goes with rich holiday foods.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2005 Bottle (650ml).  Had put it away for 8 months - wow!  Pours thick, opaque black - decent toffee-ish head, creamy.  Smells .. oh, like a black forest cake, bitter chocolate, aged fruit preserves.  Taste  ...  dark roasts, best belgian 86% cocoa chocolate, hops trying to get in there, sweet grains.  Finishes long, sweet/bitter (depends on your mood!!).  Almost chewy.  Like my sisters famous oatmeal/sour cream chocolate cake in liquid form.  Much better than the first botle I tried - set it aside and enoy it later!

I love this stuff almost as much as I love my two golden retrievers, and thats saying something! One of my favorites in winter. Huge chocolate and coffee tastes. Absolutely delicious to the very last drop.

Opaque dark brown body with a dark brown head.  Smells like chocolate & coffee.  DAMN, the taste is HUGE.  Nice chocolate and hops taste floating around.  Man, this beer is everything a chocolate stout should be.

Poured a dark brown with a decent sized tan head.  Big chocolate aroma and flavor. More so in the flavor as I drank this one.  I had this the same night as a Dark Lord so its going to be tough to really compare them.  For sure a great sweet stout, a nice desert beer.

This is a decent stout but perhaps sweet stouts are not really my thing.  Im more into the imperial and regular stouts.  It did have a lot of choclatiness to it, but not enough carmelization and richness

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2006 Smells like chocolate milk! Awesome!  Very rich milky aroma.  Completely black body with a dark brown head.  Tastes of chocolate of course, also tiny tiny hints of some fruits.  Very smooth, toasty,  and rich.  Chocolate is the dominating item here, and it rules.  Not too rich at all, perfect coating mouthfeel that makes it a joy to drink.  Great stout.

Other than bein a little htin on the palate, this was awesome, like someone mixed the idea of a chocolate malt and beer... it was most excellent.  i liked the mellowed out flavor, and by that i mean marshmallow-ed out.  mmm smores... aroma of nesquick or something.

Bottle 22oz - Pours black with a frothy tan head that goes about half and inch and laces the glass well.  Aroma is milk chocolate and lots of it.  This beer is a chocolate lovers dream.  Flavor is rich milk chocolate over an oatmeal background..  Quite sweet and quite delicious.  Like a big glass of quick, but it is beer!  On the palate this is a smooth and creamy drink until the finish then it is kind of bitter and beautifully mouth coating.  The hops balance the sweetness an make this quite a tasty stout!
Not too bad, but not my thing... I guess I like seeing the flavors come out when you eat the chocolate seperately. Anyways, still good, nice aroma, almost malty.
Jet black with a huge long lasting frothy head with a chocolate & coffee aroma. Tastes like a slightly bitter dark chocolate.

22 oz bottle. Damn near black with a healthy light brown head. Has a strong  sweet chocolate aroma with some earthy qualities. Delicious smelling. Chocolate lovers dream aroma. Dark chocolate flavor hits you first, becoming intensly bitter and quenching at the finish. Creamy smooth mouthfeel, and nice mellow carbonation level. Flavors of dark roasted coffee and hops are also present. The hop bitterness is strong, but perfectly balancing the sweet chocolate and dark malts. Drinks like a dream. If you like stouts, especially sweet or chocolate ones, this is one you must drink.

Pours pitch black with a huge deep brown head. Some lace but not alot. Smells of chocolate and cappucino.

Taste is overwhelmingly of dark chocolate. And bitter coffee as you might expect. But there is another dimension to this beer and thats the sweet milkiness that reminds you of a milk stout. Mixed with the chocolate/coffee bitterness, the creaminess lends a bittersweet quality to this brew. Again, a creamy mouthfeel with a nice bitter finish. But still very smooth. Really luscious and easy to drink. Fantastic stout.
Smells like sweet chocolate with a full tan head.  The chocolate is strong and slightly bittersweet but quite excellent.  Even reminds me faintly of chocolate milk.

#100

Pitch black with a nice creamy/brown head.  Great chocolate and coffee flavors.  If I was rich and could afford sitting around all day....this would be my choice of drink
Black as pitch with a brown head.  Bitter unsweetened chocolate flavors and burnt coffee. Very tasty not as sweet as the young double chocolate.
pours black with a lasting brown head.  very  chocolaty aroma, tastes hoppy and chocolaty, finishes a little bitter.  very nice stout.

Deep tar black pour, with brown even head. Salty and sweet aroma of coffee. Decent lacing. Sharp dry dark chocolate aftertaste, with a burnt sugar finish. Overtones of smoke, light chipotle. Light brandy plum alcohol notes. A little bit too bitter on the back end for my palate. A little basalmic quality. Vinous. Clean finish.
Smells of chocolate and coffee. Has a bitter aftertaste. The texture is watery compared to most sweet stouts.

Opaque black pour with about 1/4" head that dissipates after about a minute.  Smell is distinctively chocolate, with hints of coffee.  Mouthfeel is very smooth.  Flavor was predominantly dark or bakers chocolate, with hints of coffee and toffee.  Alcohol was absent from the taste.  This makes for an excellent dessert-type treat!

Pours ebony with an off-white head. Aroma of chocolate, grassy hops, and coffee. The body is slightly lighter than I like. Flavor of dark chocolate, and slight coffee but I was expecting this to be more rich. Fairly dry bitterness. Tasty and enjoyable but I was expecting more.

Pours black as night with a dark beige head.  Lacing hung on for a good while.
Aroma has chocolate and roasted malt hints.  Taste is of chocolate in the front end and just a little hops and alcohol on the finish. An excellent sweet stout.

This looks like a stout shoud look... black bodied with a creamy brown head. Heavily malted aromas coated my nostrils. If chocolate Ovaltine came in syrup form, this is how it would smell (sans the hint of alcohol, which wouldnt appeal to the kiddies). Tasted like a bitter chocolate milkshake with a bittersweet finish. Reminded me of drinking the milk out of the bowl after eating all of my Coco-Puffs. Medium-bodied with a syrupy texture. A chocoholics dream.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.worldmarket.com/costplus/findstore Plus World Market, Orland Park, IL<font size=-1>

Absolutely gorgeous.  If a beer can be gorgeous then this one is. Pitch black with a huge dark brown head.  Chocolate aroma.  Huge chocolate flavor with just the right amount of bitterness.  It doesnt get much better than this.  Who cares if this isnt complex...its delicious.  I wish I hadnt bought just one bottle. *sigh*

Pours with a one-finger light brown head that leaves a little lace.  Totally opaque black color.  Medium bodied and light carbonation.  Nose is strong chocolate.  Starts with a strong dark chocolate flavor (are there Hersey bars in this??) and finish is a mix of chocolate and hops.  $4.89 for a 22oz bottle from Northend Superette Manchester, NH.

This beer poured a really great black color with a full frothy head, which develops a nice semi-lace. The aroma is a great chocolate scent with a fainter smell of grain and coffee. Smells similar to fresh hot chocolate/cocoa powder. The flavor is nothing but pure chocolate with a rich thick mouthfeel. Though just as full flavored as other stouts this one seems to be easier on the palate for non-stout drinkers. A very remarkable and enjoyable beer with a bitter aftertaste that doesnt distract from the overall flavor.

Opaque black with a small brown head.  Aroma is cocoa and bittersweet chocolate.  Flavor is milky sweet chocolate.  A touch of coffee perhaps, and some bitterness that comes off more as bittersweet chocolate than hoppy bitterness.  The chocolate is center stage.    It may be one dimensional, but I really couldnt care less.  Outstanding.

Pours opaque black, dark brown head, little to no lingering.  Cocoa aroma, also some roasted barley scent detectable.  Very cocoa nose, leading into an intermingling of chocolate and roasted malt flavors.  The finish is rather roasty, with a tinge of hop bitterness as well.  The mouthfeel is that of a lusterous, with a smooth overcoating from the oats.  The imparted qualities from the oats also help dampen the astringency created by the synergistic chocolate and roast barley flavors.

Bottle at APK.  Poured a thick oily black with little and fleeting mocha head.  Armoma of chocolate.  Tasted like dark chocolate and molasses, but not regular dark chocolate, I mean the 85% cocoa stuff that isnt safe for your dog to eat!  Nah, Im kidding, but it was chocolatey and bitter.

Bottled. Pours thick and black with a huge, frothy chocolaty head.  Aroma is mostly chocolate, mostly.  Taste is very stout like with an understated chocolate flavor.  Tastes just like a mild stout mixed with Nestlés unsweetened chocolate from a can.

Pours a solid black stout color. Head is quite dark as well. Smooth milky/creamy aroma. Sweet chocolate and malts. Nice smooth mouthfeel. Lots of roasted coffee bitterness. Mild chocolate flavor. Very tasty.
Big ol head with great lacing. Taste is very malty and carmely. The smell and aftertaste is surprisingly hoppy.

Pours thick and black.  Aroma is of chicory, hops and roasted and chocolate malts.  Tastes lighter and hoppier than expected.  Good bitterness.  Coffee, oats and roasted and chocolate malts come through in flavor.  Body is a little thinner on palate than expected, but solid hops presence compensates.  High in carbonation.  Dark chocolate accents help to balance bitterness.  One of the best bitter-edged stouts Ive had in awhile.  Seems to be a less aggressive version of their Imperial Stout.

On tap, Crescent Moon Ale House, Omaha.  Aroma: bready smell reminiscent of brown sugar used in baking cookies; yeast; cold butter; lemon cream pie sweetness.  Great smell.  Appearance: black, brown-tan head that has OK retention, good lacing and noticable sub-surface "racing."  Flavor was of burnt sugar, burnt roast bitterness emerging in the finish, which was nicely long.  NIce level of sweetness and a creamy/buttery mouthfeel.  Not enough body though, and too fizzy; it wasnt "stout" enough, more like a porter with a stout level of flavor.  Overall: very enjoyable.
Great aroma with a dark delicious appearence. Unfortunatly the taste is slightly inadequatel to the great aroma it offers. Great Choclate taste! John Maeir has out done himself with this dark ale!

Nearly opaque very dark brown with a large diminishing frothy brown head.  Great aroma of chocolate (no surprise there), malted milk balls, vanilla, roast, coffee, caramel, and a hint of plum.  Medium watery body with lively carbonation.  Flavor of roast, chocolate, malted milk balls, coffee, vanilla and a hint of caramel.  The flavor is a little confused, and slightly harsh. Also a little too thin bodied for my tastes.  Good.

black with a thin  tan head. smells heavily of dark chocolate and coffee.  taste is coffee at first then gives way to the dark chocolate.     mouth feel is creamy at first then dry. has a slight bitterness.

Chocolate chocolate and more chocolate, that is what this beer is all about. This brew pours a very very dark opaque brown with a Nestle Quick colored head. This brew is very sweet! If you like chocolate then you will love this for sure. The only problem I had with this one is the over-abundance of chocolate flavor. This one is thick too. Towards the last couple of drinks it felt like I was drinking straight chocolate syrup, but again that was just the last few sips. Whenever I need to cure a chocolate fix I will be picking this one up.

Probably the best chocolate beer ive tasted.   heavy on the sweetness, less emphasis on the dark malt/chocolate similarities.  had more stuff on the bottom of the bottle than ive been used to seeing.  very smooth and at a drinkable strength.  great for dessert or suprising beer haters

dark brown app with huge medium brown frothy head...aroma is full of roasted chocolate notes (not too complex but very appetizing)...flavor is quite similar, but has a metallic tinge to it that doesnt quite complement the aroma...not bad by any means
Dangerous beer for chocoholics. Tastes like a chocolate malt only less filling. I welcome the opportunity to taste this from the tap. This is just too near a desert beer for regular drinking.

Bottle - 650ml. Pours an opaque dark brown body topped with a huge bubbly/frothy  brown head. Wonderful chocolate aroma with hints of coffee, biscuit and roasted malt. Taste is made of a well balanced mix of malty, hoppy, roasty and chocolate flavors that hides the alcohol more than fairly and leaves a long bittersweet finish. Outstanding!

Pours rich brown, dark mahogany and walnut head with tiny bubbles.  Rich Nestle Quik chocolate drink aroma.  Flavor is the same, with very tiny hop nose at the end of the swallow.  Moutheel is creamyand rich, but not heavy--what I find to be the perfect velvet body for this style.  I hope to enjoy this again.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2005 Remarkable. Smells and tastes more like dark chocolate than any other beer Ive tasted. A fantastic experience. Pours much like used motor oil. Light brown head. Lovely little bubbles. Body is thick - lacing the glass and leaving the bubbles behind. Initial smells are a bit of the roasted malts, mostly chocolate though. And after your first taste, all you smell or taste is the dark chocolate. Its as if you took a piece of 80% cocoa lindt chocolate and just let it dissolve on your tongue. Delicious. Im inspired to brew something similar.

On tap at Rogue Brewpub in Portland. Pours black, in the lighting at the pub. Had an awesome aroma of ....sweet chocolate.  Great stout to have with vanilla icecream.  Chocolatey taste with some bitterness after swallowing.  Its not a HUGE stout by any means, but its the most chocolatiest Ive had thus far. I will have it again.

I thought the aroma was not overpowering, but very delightful.  Heavy scent of chocolate, smooth taste and wonderful mouthfeel, and a lovely chocolate-esque aftertaste.  I loved this beer, and will be drinking it again when the occasion is right.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: The taste is homebrew quality, albeit of the highest degree.  I associate this taste with amatuers.  It tastes okay, until the aftertaste kicks in.  No appreciable aroma, and the appearance is nothing special.

22 oz. bottle.  Dark brown with small head.  The aroma is definitely chocolaty.  There isnt much hop bitterness apparent in the aroma but the roast & chocolate could be masking it.  The flavor does have some hops to balance the malt and chocolate.  If you want a chocolaty beer, get some of this one.  Good beer.

Bottle. Dark brown body, tan head, good lacing on my glass. Aroma is nicely malty and kind of smoky, potent. Flavor is malty, lots of chocolate malt, smoke, hop bitterness, a good lingering chocolate taste in the finish. Smooth and creamy, good level of carbonation. Another great stout from Rogue, Ive had the Shakespeare and have a bottle of the Imperial cellared away to eventually complete the trilogy.
Draft. Blackish beer with a very thin lacing of a beige head. Big chocolate aroma with sweet malt. Sweet chocolate flavor. Easy to drink and very smooth - no harsh flavors.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2006 I had higher hopes for this one.  Pours a nice deep black with a pale brownish head.  Aroma is inviting...very chocolate like....similar to a a creamy, cafe mocha from Starbucks.  Theres a lot of bitterness from the middle to the finish and it doesnt sit very well with the choco-roastiness....very strange to me.  I wanted to like this more.

Apr 2005....this bottle is much better...gotta up my ratings a tick or so.

Pours deep ruby black with a pretty layer of tawny brown head. Aromas of smooth chocolate and roasts. The complextion of the chocolate aroma changes as the glass warms. Initially a sweet milk chocolate, and richer, darker chocolate as the glass progresses. Great creamy palate. Good roast and coffee flavors. A surprisingly dry finish, with lingering, bitter dark-chocolate. A solid stout with some nice chocolate notes, rather than a chocolate drink with stout hiding somewhere underneath. Terrific!

Thanks to Mr. Facto for this beer.

Pours black with a fizzy dark brown head, almost as dark as the beer itself.  The aroma smells like fresh baked semi-sweet chocolate chips.  Probably the chocolatiest aroma Ive smelled yet.  Taste is of some roasted malt with a sweet dark chocolate taste, with very little bitterness.  More chocolatey than Youngs Double Chocolate.  I can envision it now, some dark brown cartoon character with a strange accent, holding a bottle and saying, "Everyone wants to get a hold of my Rogue Chocolate Stout!"  Body feels somewhat thin and undercarbonated, the weakest point of the beer.  This may be my top choice for a good examplar of a dessert beer, battling fiercely for the position with Bells Special Double Cream Stout.  Very nice beer.

Smells like opening a bottle of hersheys dark.  Pours black with a brown head that laces surprisingly well.  Flavor is immediately chocolate, both bitter chocolate, and overtones of milky sweet-ness.  This is a rich, thick, stout, milk-shake of a beer.  Finish is a satisfyingly bitter chocolate.  This is a dessert pint for sure.
UPDATED: SEP 15, 2005 Delicious chocolatey aroma.  Tastes like biting into a big block of dark chocolate.  Nice long-lasting, creamy head.  Medium-bitter finish.

Smelled like malted hot chocolate on the pour.  Deep brown, opaque color, solid amount of creamy tan head.  Flavor was outstanding, malts mixed with tons of chocolate. A slightly bitter aftertaste with hints of coffe in the tail end.  This might be the best chocolate stout I have had to this point.  The best part about this is, I can buy it in New Jersey now.

Holey Chocolate Flavor!!  This is superb.  Deep dark opaque brown, milk chocolate colored head with a very fragrant chocolate aroma.  Cant really relate the aroma or flavor to any particular type of chocolate, best I can do is say that the true essense of what makes chocolate great is beautifullly presented in this stout.  Flavors complement each other very well, slight bitterness to balance the sweet barley and oats.  Simply marvelous.  Cheers

Ive been trying to find this beer for some time now and found it a Papago!
Bottle pored black with a huge chocolate head that diminished slowly with good lacing on the glass. 
Aroma was  of chocolate, roast and cofee.
Flavor was very good! Easy drinking roast chocolate with a bitter malty finish.
This beer tasted better as it warmed and my next bottle will be poured at room temp.

Nearly black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of carob and raisens like a raisenette. Luxurious body with a smooth, slightly burnt finish. Amazing gustatory aroma, with the raisenette quality seeping into the sinus. The flavor is like a powdery Hersheys syrup.
Jet black appearance.  Nice light brown head slowly diminishing.  Roasty flavor with the obligatory chocolate.  Came off a little flat when compared to a Sam Smith or Bells.

2004 bomber.  Fantastic pour as usual, per Rogue.  Bottle conditioned, unpasteurised, tons of sediment and a creamy, tan colored head.  Aroma hints at the chocolate, with minor notes of roast, yeast and barley.  Not much hops apparency in the nose, and as I drink it, not much hops apparency in the flavor either.  Which is fine with me.  Strange, though, because it says this has 69 IBUs.  Starts out with a very light mocha coffee flavor, some roasted barley notes emerge, followed by a light chocolate syrup flavor.  Finish has yeast, mineral water, some chalk and more roast and chocolate.  Altogether, the chocolate is well-controlled, with no syrupy sweetness or artificial flavors, but the body is very light for a stout.  I agree exactly with bitter, if they would have upped the OG a bit more, it would have made this much more satisfyingly stoutish.  I think I prefer the more complex, salty, roasty Shakespeare.

poured ebony opaque with a tan glumpy head.  nose mostly of coffee toffee and droste cocoa.  this dominates the palate at the tip of the tongue gives the sweet chocolate we were looking for and as the silkiness slips back towards the palate you get a slight bittering and roasted dark malt feel. slight greasiness.  i felt if they would of kicked up the original gravity a bit more would have made this good beer much bigger.

Deep brown with a lasting khaki head and medium lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, caramel & roasted malt.  Smooth chocolately flavor with hints of toffee, vanilla & a little dark fruit.  Lasting but clean finish with a mild bitter layer.  Very nice.

Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Roasty, chocolate aroma.  Not my favorite kind of beer, but Rogue was able to do the chocolate flavor without going too overboard.  Good balance, with some bitterness in the finish.

very very dark with decent tan head chocolate everywhere smell/taste/aftertaste 
a little bitter in the end...i like this beer quite a bit...was not disapointed (pint 6oz bottle)

On tap: Cap City Diner. Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head. Huge chocolate aroma, biggest chocolate I have ever smelled on a beer. Flavor is, well, more chocolate. Smooth and creamy. This beer is dangerous because it doesnt really even taste like a beer. A chocolate lovers dream come true.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2006 Bottle.  Deep black color and foamy tan head.  Smeels like chocolate, yeast and hops.  The taste, yummy, chocolate, cocoa, roasted oats, nice carbonation, good bitterness.  The best chocolate stout i ever tasted.  

Stout de couleur noire opaque, avec un généreux collet brun.  Au nez, le chocolat est prédominant mais jai également relevé lodeur de la levure, typique aux bières de type Belge et odeur de houblon.       Goût de chocolat, cacao, avoine grillé, bonne amertume et pas trop élevé en gaz carbonique.  La meilleur stout au chocolat que jaie goûté jusqua maintenant.

I didnt really like this one, but having said that, I recognise its greatness. It certainly tastes like a chocolate bar, but is this a good thing? I dont know, I just wasnt feeling this one, although I may very well give it a reprieve at another time.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours jet black with thick brown fluffy head.  Aroma is malty and roasty and only slightly of bittersweet chocolate.  Toward the bottom of the glass the aroma of chocolate is more apparent.  Taste is very roasty and of bittersweet chocolate.  Finish is bitter and hoppy.  Not too shabby.

Pours black with a dark tan head which doesnt hang around for too long.  The aroma of chocolate and expresso can be detected while pouring and is very present as you bring the glass towards you at every sip.  The taste has the perfect balance of bitter chocolate, expresso and some hoppines.  Unique and incredible in every way,  my fave stout but Id love to compare it next to a Victory Storm King Stout.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2009 This beer is absolutely amazing.  Wow.  Beer for dessert anyone? Nice dark color with a thick head.  This beer is thick, smooth, chocolatey, with a nice bittersweet finish.  I think this might be my fav beer to drink in the winter time...
Re-rate: Had from bottle.  This beers flavor comes out better on tap.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2005 Rerate 10/22/05... Poured a dark brown color with a small chocolate head.. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate.. Flavor followed suit with light roasted flavor and some chocolate and cream.. Good stout but had rated at 4.4 and dont feel it is that good my second time around.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2005 My #1.  Chocolate, chocolate, and more chocolate.  For the English among us, this tastes like Smarties (not the smarties that Americans know).  Wonderful chocolate aroma, chocolate taste all the way through.  The most chocolatey beer out there.

My new favorite.  Rich, creamy flavor thats not too sweet.  Great maltiness with a little roasty edge.  Earthiness is imparted in its aroma and palate.  A truly great one from one of the best breweries on the planet.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2006 22oz bottle, pours a thick chocolate, with nice frothy head.  Smells wonderful, like mocha.  Nice rich chocolate flavor.  Finishes nice and bitter.  Im a chocolate lover so this is perfect for me.  It still maintains its beer shape though, it isnt just a chocolate drink, its got some nice stout going on as well.  Nice chocolate lace clings to the glass as it empties.

Bottle, fairly dark beer with mild red tones,  medium brown head, mild lacing, great aroma..smells like chocolate candy, great taste of chocolate too that leads into mild earthy notes.  leads a little taste of hops in the aftertaste.

Bottle.  A seriously nice chocolate stout.  Huge chocolate aroma, smell is just delicious.  Near black in color, Very nice brown head fades out and leaves a decent lace.  Full bodied.  Very smooth mouthfeel, silky.  Taste is chocolate with just a hint of hops in the finish.  Very nice.
Poured a dark, dark black with an averaged sized brown head. Milk chocolate aroma with roasted malts. Nice rich chocolate tastes. Lightly sweet with a light bitter finish. Very good chocolate beer.

Pours very dark and oily, the way a good stout should be.  Strong aroma with chocolate flowing through as if melded perfectly in this sweet blend.  This was a real pleasure to have.  The Rogue Brewery is definitely growing on me.  Im looking forward to sampling more of their brews.

pours a slightly murky brown/black with a tan head that holds well. aroma is rich with chocolate, with some malty sweetness underpinning it. flavor is absolutely redolent of chocolate, with a nice creaminess from the oats, with the hops being perfectly understated. the beer finishes with an inviting dryness that makes finishing the pint a pleasure.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2007 Well, if theres one thing Rogue does exceptionally well is brew dark beers. This one is no exception. Intense chocolatey aroma makes me hungry. Sometimes this one is roasty & some sips are chocolatey but both are very smooth. Growing up a Texan, Ive never been a huge dark beer fan but I crave this one.
YUUM. Pours really dark, somewhat thick. Cant see through at all. Very nice aroma. Chocolately coffee aroma and taste. Tastes like fine roasted coffee.
bottle.  a very nice brew.  a bit too chocolatey for my taste but a very smooth and drinkable stout.

Looks fantastic. Black and opaque. 
Rich chocolate taste well-balanced by a good stout.
Pitch black pouring it out, then big frothy brown head, great flavor , taste like coffee sometimes, taste like chocolate at other times, great all the way through and very drinkable, will get again.

22oz Bottle.  The darkest, blackest beer I ve ever seen.  Pours with a thick brown, diminishing head.  Only the slightest sweetness  followed by a rich, bitter chocolate and hop combination.  Thick, smooth body.  Im not sure the cascade hops are the best choice for this one, their citrusy flavor seems to clash a bit with the smooth chocolatey flavors.  THe finish is long and bitter.
I really like this and I usually hate chocolate in any form.  Better than the Rogue Hazelnut.  Pours nice and thick with a great color.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2005 Original Rating 97-5-7-3-15=3.7): Powdered cocoa aroma.  Opaque dark brown, almost black, with generous, large-bubbled, brown head that recedes slowly with some decent lacing.  Chocolate flavour has plenty of underlying roastiness and a fair bitterness.  Grapefruit hop flavour melds with the flavours nicely.  Even the aftertaste is complex with light underlying sugary sweetness to the lasting roastiness and subtle hop bitterness.  Somehow the flavours never seem to be playing together for me.  It seems discordant despite having so much going on.  Medium body with decent carbonation that engages the front and sides of the tongue.  Bottle.Rerate (7-3-6-2-13=3.1): Huge cocoa, chocolate, marzipan aroma is quite appealing.  Opaque black body with low tan head that recedes to ring.  Cocoa-like chocolaty sweetness is offset by a pleasant roasty bitterness.  Medium body is somewhat sticky perhaps owing to low carbonation.  Cask at GBBF 2005.

Being my first chocolate beer, I didnt know what to expect. Poured out very dark, couldnt see light through it. Dark brown head. Very chocolatey smell. Taste starts off nice and sweet, hoes to quite a bitter taste. Overall I would say a good beer.

Pours a black opaque color, with a creamy brown head. Aroma is chocolate liqueur, brown sugar  and vanilla. Taste is CHOCOLATE, a very good rich creamy one (starts like a milk chocolate and gets slowly closer to a bitter dark one), with a touch of coffee and vanilla, and a nice subtle hoppy touch in the finish. Gentle carbonation and a creamy almost chewy mouthfeel. I agree that this is quite one-dimensional since the chocolate screens out the rest, but its such an unusual one dimensionality!

Pours black with brown head. Smells just like Hersheys powdered coco. Medium bodied unsweetened chocolate flavor ending with nice bitter hops. Avery nice stout. Great with a piece of chocholate cake!!

22oz bottle. Guinness sloped pint glass. 48 degrees on glass #1(cellar temp), 52 degrees/ glass #2. This poured BLACK. I held it right up to 3 60W bulbs on a mirror and I got no color except for a dark red halo on the bottom of the glass. That last other two beers I tasted tonight had no heads so I poured glass #1 a bit too hard and got a HUGE head that was fun to watch fall into billowy, cloud-like shapes. #2 poured a nice 2 finger head that stuck around for a miute or two and left me with a nice "coating" head. Head was mocha brown. I got nice lacing throughout the glass. The nose is roasted malt, extra bitter 70% chocolate with some tart fruit undertones.
